name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I greet The President of the Commission, Mrs von der Leyen, and the Minister for the Presidency. The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the proposal for a mandate for negotiations for a new partnership with the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (2020/2557(RSP)).

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, following the entry into force of the Withdrawal Agreement and the actual withdrawal of the United Kingdom, we are about to embark on the new phase of negotiations. In order to do so, we obviously need to give a mandate to the Union negotiator. Such a mandate should be put on sound foundations. I would like in this respect to set out a few considerations that should guide us when preparing this mandate. First of all, given the comprehensive mandate called for by the European Council, the scope of the negotiations is very broad. We cannot therefore afford to delay their start. An early start calls for an early adoption of the mandate. We intend to do that at the General Affairs Council on 25 February. This time constraint is made all the more stringent by Prime Minister Johnson’s decision not to extend the transition period beyond the end of 2020. Given the broad scope of the mandate, this will require that several strands of negotiations have to proceed in parallel. This is a negotiating mandate, not the final outcome of the negotiations. Therefore, it cannot spell out in full detail our expected landing zones, our final offers and the trade-offs we may have to contemplate. Adequate negotiating space should be preserved. Besides – and this goes back to my point about unity and time constraints – a very prescriptive mandate would require more time to resolve possibility, diverging interests and priorities. What we should focus on is the Union’s interest in achieving an outcome that is fair and equitable for all Member States and their citizens. Last, we have to factor in the UK red lines. The UK Government’s intention is to discontinue free movement, with an obvious impact on mobility and citizens’ rights, and also to diverge from the Union’s regulatory framework with no less obvious consequences in terms of access to the single market and trade in general. On the substance of the mandate, regarding the various sectors that should be covered, I think that we largely share the view in the Parliament’s position, as reflected in your draft resolution. This means a fair degree of ambition as compared to the Union’s relationship with other countries. It should be clear, however, that this cannot amount to giving the UK the same benefit as a Member State, especially in the light of its red lines. But let me focus briefly on more horizontal aspects of the partnership: governance and level playing field. There should be no doubt here. The EU might be prepared to offer an ambitious free trade agreement with significant market access, but this cannot be to the detriment of the competitive position of EU companies, social and health standards, or state aid rules. In other words, the partnership should include wide ranging provisions on a level playing field, based on high standards. This is all the more relevant given the UK’s stated intention to diverge from the European Union. In my view, this is closely linked to the issue of effective dispute settlement enforcement and remedies. There is no point in developing wide ranging level playing field provisions if they cannot be enforced. I will make two important remarks before closing. First, although we are well aware that the line of the UK’s Government is to put an end to the free movement of persons, we should see to it that the future relationship that we will start to negotiate shortly will be ambitious enough in terms of mobility. Second, and this is a link to my previous remark, these negotiations will keep both our institutions and the Commission busy for quite some time, but this should not make us forget about the Withdrawal Agreement. We should continue to monitor its thorough implementation. There is therefore once again a shared interest all along the coming negotiations in pursuing the good cooperation that we expected during the Brexit phase.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, it’s just two weeks ago that we bid farewell to our British friends by singing ‘Auld Lang Syne’, and I think it was a most emotional, a very powerful moment in this Parliament: a moment to celebrate the good old times, and I thank you very much for the grace and the kindness of this gesture. This was extraordinary. Since then, we’ve set our sights on the future of our relations with the United Kingdom, and we will enter these negotiations with the highest ambition. Because good old friends like the UK and us shouldn’t settle for less than this. Prime Minister Johnson said in Greenwich earlier this month that the United Kingdom will, I quote, ‘be a global champion of free trade’. Frankly, this is music to our ears, because at a moment when the rules-based trade system is so challenged, we need our partners to join us in making the system fairer and stronger. And this is what we Europeans have always fought for over the years: a trade system that is open on one side and that is fair on the other side. Because what do free trade agreements do? Free trade agreements must replace uncertainty with a sound set of rules. They create new markets for small and medium enterprises. Free trade agreements must benefit the people. And this is just the rationale that is behind our trade agreements, for instance with Canada and Japan. They are not just increasing our bilateral exchanges of goods, services, people and ideas. They do that too, but not only. They also raise standards on a broad range of issues, from labour rights to environmental. And this is what makes us proud of them: ask our Japanese friends or ask our Canadian friends. They are glad that we have joined forces to put fairness into our globalised economic system. They are glad that they could join forces with the European Union, because frankly, in today’s world, size does matter – and we have a Single Market of 440 million people. What I just described – this is the ambition we have for our free trade agreement with the United Kingdom. And when we agreed the Political Declaration with the United Kingdom, we ambitioned zero tariffs and a zero-quota trade relation for all goods: something we have never ever before offered to anybody else. A new model of trade, a unique ambition in terms of access to the Single Market. But of course, this would require corresponding guarantees on fair competition and the protection of social, environmental and consumer standards. In short: this is plain and simply the level playing field. We are ready to discuss all different models of trade agreement. But all these models, whatever you choose, have one thing in common: they all come not only with rights, but also with obligations for both sides. For example, if we take the Canada model – and this is a model Prime Minister Johnson referred to – of course, our deal with Canada eliminates tariffs on a wide set of goods, but not on all. And of course, our deal with Canada eliminates most quotas, but certainly not all. For instance, there are still quotas on beef and sweetcorn. And of course, we still have our standards that have to be respected. And honestly, I was a little bit surprised to hear the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom speak about the Australian model. Australia, without any doubt, is a strong and like-minded partner. But the European Union does not have a trade agreement with Australia. We are currently trading on WTO terms. And if this is the British choice, well, we are fine with that, without any question. But in fact, we are just in the moment where we are agreeing with Australia that we must end this situation, and we work on a trade deal with them. Of course, the UK can decide to settle for less, but I personally believe that we should be way more ambitious. And the Prime Minister’s speech in Greenwich is an encouraging starting point. He recalled everything the United Kingdom has achieved in terms of social protection, climate action, competition rules, and I commend the UK for all of that. Indeed, it is not the time to lower social protection or to be lukewarm on climate action. It is not the time to decrease in terms of competition rules. I have heard ambition in Boris Johnson’s speech: ambition on the minimum wage, ambition on parental payments, and he has an ally in me where that is concerned. I have heard ambition on cutting carbon emissions. Ambition on guaranteeing that our firms are competing in full fairness. This is what we also want. Let us formally agree on these objectives. We can trigger an upward dynamic competition that would benefit both the United Kingdom and the European Union. To our British friends I say: it’s in our mutual interest. And most importantly, it would be consistent with the values we share – values of openness, values of fairness, values of social justice and free enterprise. These are not only values for the good old times. These are values to stay. Thank you very much for your attention. I just wanted to inform you that the Task Force is ready to start the negotiations. We’re all set. (Applause)

name: David McALLISTER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the resolution on the draft mandate, which we are debating this morning, is the first proof of work of the newly created UK Coordination Group. As the Chair, I would like to thank all members of our group, as well as the involved Committees and the political groups, for their contributions in an extremely short period of time. In my opinion, the result is a very good and balanced resolution only nine days after Michel Barnier presented the Commission’s draft mandate. Our resolution contains Parliament’s views on the content and on the architecture of a future EU-UK relationship. Let me highlight three main principles of particular importance. Firstly, the integrity and the correct functioning of our internal market, the customs union and the Four Freedoms must be maintained. Secondly, a third country cannot have the same rights and benefits as a Member State of the EU. And thirdly, a level playing field is an overall priority and precondition for any future agreement. We should not, and we will not, enter a race to the bottom. As Ursula von der Leyen has pointed out, together with our British friends, we should aim for a partnership that goes well beyond trade and is unprecedented in scope: everything from climate action to data protection, fisheries to energy, transport to space, financial services to security. We are indeed ready to design a new partnership with zero tariffs, zero quotas and zero dumping. However a free trade agreement with the UK will not be equivalent to frictionless trade. Ladies and gentlemen, besides the negotiations on the future relations, the implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement is of particular importance. This concerns especially citizens’ rights, financial duties on the protocol on Ireland-Northern Ireland. Our chief negotiator Michel Barnier, whose work is highly appreciated across party lines in the institutions, has already assured us in the UK coordination group’s first meeting to keep Parliament fully informed at all stages of the procedure. (Applause)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, on behalf of the Social Democratic Group we would like to thank the European Commission, and in particular Mr Barnier's team, for their efforts in drawing up the guidelines for negotiating the future framework for the relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom.  With the resolution that this Parliament is about to adopt, together we send a strong message: the ambition of the future relationship will depend on the British Government's willingness to accept conformity with Community rules on social, labour, tax and environmental matters.  On 1 February the UK formally became a third country and lost all its political rights. But in everything else nothing will change until this transitional period ends. We have eleven months to negotiate a complex agreement that defines our future relationships. In building this new partnership we must assume that nothing will be as prosperous as the rights and benefits of membership of the European Union.  The Social Democratic Group is committed to reaching a comprehensive agreement with the United Kingdom. However, the more barriers the British Government raises, the harder it will be to reach an ambitious agreement. On the contrary, if the United Kingdom is willing to remain on a balanced playing field as a fair competitor, we will be able to offer an association that guarantees the prosperity of citizens on both sides of the English Channel. And, to ensure this prosperity, we are ready to offer an ambitious free trade agreement, without tariffs or quotas, for all goods entering the common market and another for services. Moreover, if we want this benefit to be real, we also need a strong partnership on judicial cooperation, security and defence, support for the multilateral order, as well as addressing issues such as fisheries, transport, energy and financial services.  But our offer cannot be made at any price. Let me be clear. The United Kingdom must ensure fair competition, authorise European fleets' access to their waters and maintain its commitment to the European Court of Human Rights in compliance with its judgments. In addition, we will require that Spain have the final say in the discussions between the European Union and the United Kingdom affecting Gibraltar, as ratified in the Commission's guidelines.  Our success in the negotiations will depend on whether we are able to prevail what has so far been our best weapon: unity. Only with the Commission as the sole interlocutor with the United Kingdom, and with the full involvement of this Parliament for final approval, will the European Union be able to preserve the level of unity achieved so far. Together we have managed to protect the integrity of the single market, the Customs Union and the four freedoms, including the free movement of citizens.  Let us not forget that our project is articulated on the basis of a commitment to values that are exactly contrary to those manifested by some British leaders, imbued with nationalism and a false idea of superiority. Now that we face the future relationship, we have an obligation to defend the democratic principles and fundamental freedoms that have enabled our European project to move forward.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, the United Kingdom has chosen to leave the European Union and we have chosen to strengthen it. Some might see it as a contradiction that would make negotiating the future of our relationship more difficult. I do not think that is the case. That is not the case, because we respect the choice of the British. This choice to leave not only the European Union, but also the single market and the customs union, is a fairly radical choice, but we will respect it. It has consequences that are far from negligible and profoundly change the relationship we can build together.  This is not the case, because a strong Europe is in the interests of the United Kingdom. We are neighbours, allies and we are London's largest partner in terms of trade, but also in terms of human exchange. Geography is stubborn, facts are stubborn, and we have to face them. This is not the case, because we have huge challenges together: climate change, terrorism, cyberattacks, viruses are making fun of borders. We have to invent new ways to fight them together because separately we would all lose.  We are ready for a close, strong and lasting partnership with the United Kingdom, but we also hold strong convictions that we are deeply attached to and that Brexit cannot challenge. We have high standards to protect consumers, protect workers, protect the privacy and personal data of our citizens and protect our planet. We are not prepared to haggle over what we fought so hard for, why we continue to fight.  The draft mandate we support for negotiations with the United Kingdom is an illustration of these strong convictions that drive us; it proposes a partnership unprecedented in its scope and scale, at the height of what brings us together. It therefore asks for counterparties that are out of step with those in other agreements with other European Union partners - because the United Kingdom is not for Europe Canada, Japan, South Korea or Singapore; it is much closer, much more important, much more interdependent. Brexit is not meant to destroy the bonds that have united our economies, cultures and peoples for centuries, nor to destroy European integration.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: for the ID Group. Mr President! The British are and should continue to be our good friends, closest allies and closest collaborators. I want an agreement with the British that clearly favours and respects the British desire to be able to decide more even at home in the nation state, for example over who one wants to grant access to one's own country or to provide access to various services.  At the same time, I would like to see strong cooperation with the British, for example in the field of trade, where it is essential at home, in my own country, in Denmark, in order to continue to hold on to one of our closest and very best trading partners. In fact, Denmark at the time entered what was the forerunner of the European Union precisely because we wanted to continue to do business with Britain. When the British signed up, they made it clear that it was not an exit from the world or Europe, but that it was just an exit from the EU system. I think that in many ways is sympathetic. I hope we can make a deal with the British that will respect Brexit while continuing to have a very close partnership for the benefit and benefit of the British and for the rest of us, where we genuinely share interests and values; This is unfortunately something that can happen in this house.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two facts: the first is that the United Kingdom and the European Union are bound by geography. That is not going to change, so we have an interest in maintaining as close and friendly relations as possible. Secondly: not everyone in the UK, far from it, is an English nationalist. The European Union has many, many friends in the United Kingdom; let's not alienate them. In trade, on the face of it, the ambitions of the European Union and the United Kingdom are antagonistic, since the United Kingdom wants maximum access to the European market, but refuses the regulatory alignment required by the European Union. So I invite all of us to be creative in this area. Let me explain: as a general rule, free trade agreements are used by the business community, I mean the holders of capital, to force a levelling down of working and pay conditions, social, environmental or fiscal standards. We could take the opportunity of a free trade treaty with the United Kingdom to do the exact opposite. Today, the legislation of the United Kingdom and the European Union is perfectly aligned in the areas of competence of the European Union, but therefore not in everything. In some areas - I am thinking of privacy, I am obviously thinking of social standards - the European Union has more ambitious standards than the United Kingdom. But there are other areas where the UK has more ambitious standards than the European Union - for certain aspects of environmental policy, or in banking regulation. We could set a rule in the new agreement by which both partners would commit to applying the two standards which is the most ambitious - and by the most ambitious, I mean the most protective of health, privacy, working conditions and remuneration, the environment. In this way, we would have a form of up-to-the-way emulation between the UK and the European Union. You will tell me that it never happened. Well, I think that's the kind of free trade agreement that many of our citizens want today, in other words, miles from the one we're going to vote on with Vietnam soon.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the EU and Britain have entered a tense year. Time is limited and pressure is mounting to agree on an FTA this year. Formally, the negotiation is aimed at agreeing to a legal set of rules, but there is more to it. There is a mindset that varies on both sides of the Channel.  Every bureaucracy tends to cling to its own rules, awarding them holy status. In that respect the EU bureaucracy is not much different from the mandarins that once ruled the Chinese empire. It regards itself as the centre of the world, and of all wisdom. The British mindset is different. Having been an empire itself, Britain derives cultural self-confidence from the idea that it is still is an empire. The old empire does not want to be run by a possibly new one, so it left. What are the lessons, Mr President? The EU should not be bitter. Brexit is done and we have to put our citizens first. The EU has to be pragmatic and purpose-driven rather than rules—obsessed; focussed on tangible mutual interests, not on bad feelings. The current British government is the most stable in Western Europe – a big majority for five years. Who else can say that? But it should not overestimate the margins of divide and rule that worked for centuries – but not anymore.  Results will only be attainable through political will: the will to succeed. This – though wordy – resolution is the starting point to negotiate. Mr Barnier, you are an experienced negotiator. I hope you will be able to bridge both mindsets – divided by 30 kilometres of water, but still two worlds apart.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Negotiations on the future relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union are not just about how future economic and trade relations will be structured – no, it is about much more: it is really about the future of the European Union and – do not misunderstand me, this is not the endgame, and the next eleven months will not be an endgame, but it can be a decisive game changer. The outcome of these negotiations will also determine whether membership of the European Union or development outside the Union is the more attractive development model. So far, there is no central aspect of this debate here today: it is not the economy, ladies and gentlemen, in the end, but the citizens, it is the so-called ordinary people who will decide which will be the more attractive development model. That is what Brexit teaches us. The mandate we are discussing here must therefore put the interests of the people of the European Union and the British people at the heart of the negotiations. My group welcomes the clear statements on the prevention of tax dumping, on the protection of workers' rights and labour standards, on consumer protection and on environmental protection. No one needs further increased competition for tax dumping, no one wants worse working conditions, except for those who benefit from it, and that is not the workers, ladies and gentlemen. In short, we want the highest standards, the protection of peace in Northern Ireland and democratic control of the negotiation process. However, we are very critical to negative about many other aspects of the mandate, such as the issues of military cooperation, the positive reference to NATO, intelligence cooperation. We will engage constructively in the planning process in the interests of our constituents, knowing that a hard Brexit is still possible and that is not in anyone's interest.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Mr President, by the end of the transition phase, the cost of Brexit will have exceeded the UK's cumulative contributions to the budget since it joined 47 years ago. This fact only confirms the conviction of all those who say that Brexit is an economic folly. The UK is leaving the EU, but remains in Europe and will undoubtedly remain one of the most dynamic economies on our doorstep. As rapporteur of the Committee on International Trade, I make it clear that what we offer the United Kingdom goes beyond all the free trade agreements concluded to date by the European Union. We offer a relationship free of tariffs and free of limiting quotas. What is being asked for in return is equal competition, to avoid any race to the bottom in terms of regulation, taxation, environmental and social matters. What we call in our jargon the level playing field must be worthy of the Premier League, today and after the transition phase. to that end, we also need a referee who is up to the challenge. For this Parliament, it is clear that when it comes to European law, this ultimate body can be none other than the European Court of Justice. It is clear that a free trade agreement will never be able to replicate membership of the single market, but let us be clear: the level of ambition of this agreement will also depend on the limited timetable imposed by the British counterpart.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, we are here to discuss a very important resolution on the political guidelines for the negotiations between the European Union and the UK – 21 pages, 103 paragraphs, but perhaps the most important is the front page, the signatures of the leaders of a number of major political groups in this Parliament, showing that there is a vast majority supporting this resolution and how united we are in defending our common vision and our common interests. We call on the Member States to do the same, to refuse any bilateral negotiations at this stage, and to act as a bloc, with the Commission and Mr Barnier being the sole negotiators on our part. We are clear about what we want to achieve – a sound and ambitious strategic, political and economic relationship – but we also say, loud and clear, that we will ensure open, but also fair, competition, a proper level playing field and no regression on the high European standards of environmental, social and labour protection, and also consumer rights and food safety.  We’ve heard some messages of refusal of this by the UK Government, but this will have proportional consequences in terms of the access of the UK to the European market, undermining the ambition of our trade agreement. Let me conclude by recalling that the first pillar of the future economic relationship with the UK was already agreed in the Withdrawal Agreement. It has to do with Northern Ireland, the alignment of Northern Ireland and border controls in the Irish Sea. So we will work for a new agreement for the future, but we will also ensure full implementation of the commitments in the existing Withdrawal Agreement.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Madam President! It is in every way sad that such a large and close-up country has chosen to leave. It's sad for them, it's sad for us. On the other hand, it is good and strong that the resolution we are debating here today is so comprehensive and that it has been drafted by as broad a majority in the European Parliament as it is. Because it sends a very important political signal that we in the European Parliament will ensure a level playing field in the future cooperation, known as level playing field. Why? Because it is not going to work if we are to compete on lower standards in the environment, in climate, in consumer protection. It will not work if we are to compete on lower tax rates, and it will not work if The UK were to expect full and free access to the EU single market without at the same time complying with the rules and requirements that may apply here.  We must not gamble with the EU's single market. It's a crown jewel in the collection that we have to look out for.  In the very short term, we have a very particular challenge in terms of fishing: there are many jobs at stake, there are many people's livelihoods at stake. It is important to say in this context that the negotiations on the future of fisheries cannot and must not be seen in isolation from the negotiations on trade in general.  So it will all be difficult negotiations against a very sad and dramatic backdrop, but the ambition must be that we create a strong partnership for the benefit of all.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, yes, we must, of course, have a special relationship with the United Kingdom. Our similar standard of living and our common civilization invite us to do so. But that doesn't mean you have to give it all away.  Mr Barnier, you proposed a few days ago, I quote, to "eliminate all tariffs and quotas on goods traded with the continent". Clearly, it would be a free trade agreement and Philippe Lamberts, a few moments ago, made the same proposal. You have free trade agreements with the whole world - as you do later with Vietnam - but you do not support, in the end, that the United Kingdom is no longer part of the customs union. It is now a third country, and we have to be aware of that.  The risk would be to turn it tomorrow into a gateway for products from all over the world that do not meet our standards and of poor quality. The priority is to protect our interests, for example those of French fishermen who make 30% of their turnover in British waters. Seventy per cent of the UK's fishing exports go to the European Union; we have a huge leverage here for future negotiations, so that they are favourable to us. I know you do not like the Trump method, but it works in economic matters. We need to build on that. Our market, our consumers and our fishermen are entitled to these protections that you systematically deny them.  Brexit is an opportunity to change the model and put in place a new one.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, I have to be honest: it’s a very special moment I think, because it’s the first time that we discuss Brexit here in this House without having our UK colleagues being here, and I must say that apart from a bunch that was sitting over there, I really truly miss them, and I think it shows again how sad it is that this Brexit is happening. Now, I had the great pleasure and the honour to do my Erasmus year in the beautiful city of Edinburgh. Still, when I go there today, I really feel at home, and I think these are really the ties that we have to cherish also for the future. And the economic and trade relationships are going to be absolutely crucial in the future. But if we want to build strong foundations, we also have to look at other issues, and that is why I think we have to fight to keep the United Kingdom in the Erasmus programme. Young people did not vote for Brexit, and I think it would be wrong to take away the opportunities from them that I and many millions of Europeans had in the past after Brexit. And that is why, if we want to build a strong relationship for the future, we should fight for a strong Erasmus programme with the UK in it. Let us leave a light on and build bridges so that the Brits can find their way back home.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The motion for a resolution contains many good statements and I think the ECR Group can support it. What is more worrying, however, is the spirit that can revive, or on the contrary, negotiate. The recent exchange of arguments between Brussels and London is not very optimistic. It is clear that a third country cannot have the same rights and benefits as a Member of the Union, an EFTA member or a member of the EEA, but the United Kingdom will not be one of many third countries. Outside the Union, too, it remains a great European country associated with other European countries in history, the economy and security cooperation. It should be recalled that, in the darkest moments of European history between 1939 and 1945, it was The United Kingdom, like Poland, that heroically defended European values. It is in the interest of Europeans on both sides of the English Channel to ensure that our relations are as good as possible. Our negotiators should not forget this.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: – Madam President, the departure from the United Kingdom opens a window of opportunity for us to learn from mistakes made and not to make them again. Hate speech, disaffection or uncertainty weigh on those who understand that the European project should be an area of progress and solidarity and they are disappointed. We can't delve into failed models who are expelling citizens outside. We now have a responsibility to guarantee the rights of people, of citizens living in the UK — almost 140,000 Spaniards currently reside there. We are concerned about the situation of workers, of the 15,000 people crossing the Gibraltar border every day, whose situation is still uncertain. We need to fight social and fiscal dumping decisively. We do not agree with much of the content of this mandate in the field of foreign and defence policy. We believe that it is necessary to move towards much more anticipatory positions of conflict and not to delve into sanctions paid only by peoples. From this parliamentary group we will continue to work to shield the rights of citizens, environmental rights and those of the primary sector – agriculture, livestock – to avoid the depopulation of our peoples. They must be prevented from becoming a currency of exchange of other interests.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the text we are going to vote on aims to strengthen unity among the 27 countries and to strongly support Michel Barnier in order to protect our interests during the negotiations. First of all, it is important to protect the defence of the internal market. The United Kingdom cannot fall back on it, like a Trojan horse, without respecting rules and standards. All this in order to guarantee more and more citizens and businesses. The health of Europeans must be guaranteed by preventing agri-food products from entering that do not meet our standards or compete with unfair competition. We are Italian and we want to eat Parmesan and not Parmesan and I believe that all Europeans prefer to eat Parmesan and not Parmesan. Citizens' rights must be protected, for example, by ensuring the use of paper documents and not just online. And then our parliamentary committees will have to work to protect key areas, such as fisheries, space, energy, and then the interests of peace in Ireland and Spanish interests in Gibraltar, and of course the defence and fight against terrorism.  In conclusion, we must prevent the UNITED Kingdom from turning into a European Singapore, which may not have strict anti-money laundering rules. All this in order to have ever more positive relations with London, which has left the European Union but remains Europe.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The resolution shows that we are ready to negotiate. And I believe that we can also manage to organise trade agreements within nine months, because the situation is now a little different. Normally we have two different partners who are somehow moving towards each other, and we agree on common standards or recognise standards. Now we have a harmonised system and we have to decide how far we can go. In this respect, this is a little more comfortable than in other trade negotiations. That is why the three pillars, normal trade negotiations, must be taken into account. The issue of duty-free is the common objective. This can also be negotiated if it is ensured that the products coming from the United Kingdom that come to the European Union are actually British products and not products that come to the European Union via the United Kingdom from other countries. Secondly, there are the standards of products and services. We have a clear set of rules on consumer protection and health protection. The SPS standards will not be attacked in any way. So I think it will be easy to come to an agreement. And the third pillar is the most complicated. Of course, we must also discuss rules relating to trade, so that there are no distortions of competition. In other words, the question of equal workers' rights, the question of the same environmental standards, the question of the same aid scheme – very importantly – and the question of a harmonised tax rate. Otherwise, we would have distortions of competition, and that cannot be the case. If there are distortions of competition, then of course we will have to introduce legislation to compensate for this. It is completely absurd to think that there is a dumping island beyond the Channel with full free market access.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Barnier for his work and his words. As the EU and the United Kingdom embark on this new relationship, which I hope is a fruitful one, I want to send a very clear message to the United Kingdom. This Parliament will not allow the United Kingdom to become a tax haven or a money laundromat just offshore Europe. I want to remind you about paragraph 21 of the resolution. It says, ‘We strongly believe that the UK should adhere to the evolving standards on taxation and anti—money laundering legislation within the EU acquis, including tax transparency, the exchange of information on tax matters and anti—tax avoidance measures’. This applies to the territories as well. I would remind you that British overseas territories include Bermuda, the Cayman Islands, Gibraltar, the Virgin Islands: crown dependencies include all of those islands that have no taxes on deposits, etc. Mr Barnier, this is an existential question for Europe. If we allow tax avoidance and money laundering just offshore Europe, our way of life is in danger and our welfare state is in danger. This has to be one of the highest, if not the highest, priority for our negotiations.

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I see so much hypocrisy. Of course, tomorrow's resolution is a text that is probably also done very well, but our hemicycle in Brussels, where we met two weeks ago, is still wet with the tears of many of you. I also see a schizophrenic attitude in the words used by the President of the Commission, who continues to insist by calling friends, friends and friends who you have tried to humiliate for three years. Because of three years lost, we're talking, because we could have been much further ahead if someone hadn't pretended that Brexit would never have happened, that the British people were wrong.  So let's talk about standards, but tomorrow you're going to vote on a trade deal with an Asian country that is a long way from these standards that you expect from Britain. So you just have to hope that they don't make the deal first with the United States, which would replace our products, and you have to listen to our producers who export so much to Britain. The time lost in these years is bad for them and it is all your responsibility.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, it is now up to the Commission to act quickly, to act in a clever manner and at the same time to act pragmatically. In this context, I agree with the very broad mandate for the European Commission and put my full confidence in Michel Barnier, who has done an excellent job so far. The aim must be a comprehensive trade agreement without barriers, with respect for our red lines: the correlation between a level playing field and the depth of the agreement, but also a "plus treaty": R&D, security, fisheries, defence, you name it.  In this context, a question to the Commission: does the Commission indeed intend to end cooperation with the United Kingdom in the North Sea Energy Corporation? Firstly, I do not think the Commission has the competence. Secondly, it would be a capital mistake. In the 21st century, we need to work more closely together in the blue economy: the 21st century will be the century of the ocean!

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are all aware that there are very many and important aspects of our relationship with the United Kingdom that now need to be settled. That is our task – in the interests of our citizens, in the economic, social, environmental and also cultural dimensions. That is why it is not so much a free trade agreement that it is about fair and inclusive trade relations. I find it worrying to want to regulate everything in a single de facto association agreement, as was the case with TTIP. Issues of cooperation between armed forces, energy and network cooperation issues, police cooperation issues or the regulation of airspace must not be removed from parliamentary control and handed over to the committees set up within the agreement. I appeal to the Council: create transparency, uphold democratic demands! I commend the Commission's approach of ensrising the UN Sustainable Development Goals, giving great scope to the Paris Agreement, the ILO and fundamental rights, including data protection. Just don't slow down the ambitious expansion of our future regulation to protect the environment and product safety by treating issues as a matter of trade barriers.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, when someone organizes a Brexit it is to leave, not to stay otherwise. The UK can't have more advantages being outside than the ones inside. We've spent three years lamenting that they're gone. Now nostalgia can't confuse us because they're gone. Now they're a third country. Let us negotiate with them harshly – as we do with every third country – and defend our own.  We defend the decolonization of Gibraltar; that it doesn't become a tax haven, that it's not a tax haven an longer. We defend our fishermen, who every day have to make a living in order to earn their bread. We defend our farmers. We defend our products. If they, if British politicians have wanted to be a third country, let us treat them as what they are in the negotiation, a third country. The UK has left Europe. Let us not consent to it becoming the new Southeast Asia at the doorstep of our homes.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Dear Chairman, the European Parliament must clearly present its priorities on the future relationship with the United Kingdom.  Is it possible to reach an agreement by the end of this year? What kind of agreement? It should be emphasised that no country outside the Union can enjoy the same rights as a member. The negotiations are based on four fundamental freedoms, and the well-being and rights of European Union citizens in the Uk and vice versa must remain in focus.  In the context of foreign affairs and defence, I hope that the UK as a permanent member of the NATO Security Council will continue to share with us the objectives and values. The same applies to joint civil-military missions, sanctions compliance, the Iran agreement and arms control and non-proliferation agreements. I hope that as a European Union and during these negotiations we will maintain unity, successfully achieved in the exit negotiations.  Thank you again to our British colleagues for their many years of work and their great contribution to European standards that have improved our citizens' quality of life.

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: – Madam President, today it is time to start building our future relationship with our British friends. So let’s look at our common interests and goals and see how these can best be served instead of only looking at what divides us. Therefore, I insist on an ambitious Free Trade Agreement that creates the right conditions for open and fair competition. Having said that, a third country can obviously not enjoy the same benefits as an EU Member State, and the openness of our markets must directly correlate with the willingness of the UK to align with EU rules and standards.  It remains essential that the EU continues to stand united. We need to maintain our high standards, have clear rules on state aid and competition and strive for a Fisheries Agreement before the summer.  I regret Brexit and will continue to do so, but now it is time to move forward and build our new relationship.

name: Ivan DAVID
text: – Madam President, I fear that many enthusiasts for an integrated EU without nations and borders are in danger of seeking revenge for Brexit. Mr Verhofstadt has made it clear that the United Kingdom should not have been granted autonomy in any way. But today, the UK is a member of the European Free Trade Association, so under the Treaty the EU cannot impose restrictions on trade in industrial products. In fact, truck transport, financial services and agriculture remain as an instrument. But in the age of internet banking, British banks cannot be effectively hindered. Attempts to obstruct the agricultural market may be much worse for the EU, similar to retaliatory sanctions by the Russian Federation. Without imports from Europe, it has achieved self-sufficiency in 2 years. The United Kingdom hardly stands for the damaging of its agriculture by imports at dumped prices. Indentation with the UK will do much more damage to the EU than vice versa.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Madam President, Mr Barnier, ladies and gentlemen, the circus of the UK's departure from the Community club is over and we have to get to work. Trade and economic agreements must be agreed to guarantee the rights of our nationals. As an example, the right to fish in British waters of Spanish fishermen or trade treaties that effectively ensure free competition for UK agricultural products, but also in matters such as security or judicial cooperation. Let us negotiate strongly, but let us negotiate no less strongly than we have to negotiate with other countries outside Europe with which we also close trade agreements. In this regard, I believe that it is the right time to take the battle and end gibraltar's decolonization process, preventing that British colony on Spanish national territory from still parasitizing the Spanish economy with unfair tax practices. Under the umbrella of the European Union, Gibraltar has established itself as a basis for money laundering from criminal activities. We therefore require the Commission to lay the groundwork for this decolonisation process. We know that it is the responsibility of the Government of Spain, but of loyal members, such as those of this club, collaboration and respect for the dignity of our nation must be demanded.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, I would like to talk about financial services, which I believe are crucial for future relations with the UK. We know that an FTA can have only a very small chapter on financial services, addressing only the right of establishment and prudential carve-out mechanism, and EU financial services are about the single market, and it is clear now that it will be an equivalence mechanism that will provide the main framework for the relationship. The Commission has just a few months to prepare all those unilateral equivalence decisions – around forty, I understand – and the financial industry should be fully aware of how little time they have to adjust to the future situation. Efforts have been made recently, also in this House, to enhance the equivalence framework as the main regulatory tool for financial services in the future relationship with the UK. As equivalence is a unilateral discretionary policy tool, in order to make it deliver, we will need constructive cooperation with UK regulators and supervisors to protect the financial stability and integrity of our financial markets, protect investors and consumers, as well as ensuring LPF. But all of us here in this House must also be aware that for an ambitious, beneficial and successful future relationship with the UK in the area of financial services, it is our duty also to complete as soon as possible the Banking Union and build a genuine capital market union. The EU will preserve regulatory and supervisory autonomy, but so will the UK, and we just heard from the former governor of the Bank of England that the UK will not be a rule-taker. So let me emphasise that, while we should maintain close and ambitions relations with the UK in financial services, we should also spare no effort to reduce potential systemic risk.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Chief Negotiator Barnier, after one of the darkest pages in the history of the Union, we have an obligation today to do everything possible to guarantee our citizens the results achieved in 45 years of European integration, safeguarding our relations with the United Kingdom and basing them on the principle of social and environmental equity and fair competition. We need an ambitious agreement that commits the UK to maintaining our production and food safety standards and avoids the risk that access to the single market for products across the Country is a Trojan horse for products that would put the health of our consumers and the economic sustainability of our businesses at risk. Future relations cannot be separated from the sharing of a common cultural heritage, which also includes quality agri-food production. That is why all our excellence must be guaranteed the current level of protection. It is precisely on these principles that we are convinced that after Brexit there will be no vacuum, but an increasingly strong and sustainable Europe, ready to defend its citizens.

name: Barry ANDREWS
text: – Madam President, it is with mixed feelings that I make this first contribution to the proceedings of this Chamber because, naturally, it has been difficult to see the departure of the UK for any Irish person, given the very close political, social and cultural affinity that we have with the UK. I’d much rather be here in very different circumstances, but it is fitting that I should speak, for my first contribution, on Brexit, because essentially it is one of the reasons I put my candidacy forward a year ago and, ironically, one of the reasons that I’ve ended up here in the difficult circumstances. We’re at a delicate stage in proceedings, and there is no example in history where negotiating parties are seeking to impose trade barriers. So it will be difficult. It is amazing to continue to hear UK government officials expressing astonishment that the EU would exercise power, leverage and influence in trade negotiations, given the fact, on the one hand, that the UK were one of the architects of this system and that they have benefited from it so much. So I would call upon Mr Barnier to continue to speak about the UK as a trading partner and not a trading competitor, and not to imagine that the UK has to be punished in order for the EU to thrive.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to take this opportunity, as the British Mandates are no longer with us for the first time, to wish Britain all the best for the newly won independence and that Brussels is no longer the centre of its decisions, but that the epicentre of political decision-making is there in London. You may like that, or you can't like it. The fact is that it happens on the basis of a democratic majority vote. Long enough, with tricks of a second referendum and the like, the British have tried to stay in this community. But it was only the elections to the House of Commons that made it clear that this British majority decision was an unshakeable one. Now it will be up to you, the European Union, how to deal with the British in their newly won independence: in friendship and with flexibility, or to continue to paint the British with a regulatory frenzy in such a way that they will continue to say 'no, thank you' and they will be driven into a transatlantic axis with the Americans – to the detriment of Europe too– , to the detriment of jobs and the economy in Europe. And you will have to manage to treat the British with friendship and flexibility.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, the framework for the future relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union will inevitably depend on the nature of the forces that negotiate it. What we have, on the one hand and the other, are forces committed to the liberalization and commercialization of public services, on the attack on the social functions of the State, on limiting the intervention of states in the economy, on social and labour deregulation, on a dangerous militaristic escalation within NATO and on an aggressive and interventionist foreign policy. We oppose and fight this path firmly. We see no reason why mutually beneficial cooperation links with the United Kingdom, beyond the economic field, should not be maintained and even strengthened, in areas such as science, education and culture, among others. A framework of loyal cooperation, respectful of the sovereignty of each country and the rights of migrant communities, in which peoples gain, and not a competitive framework that takes advantage of great capital at the expense of peoples. It is not acceptable under any circumstances for states to be prevented from building this framework based on bilateral relations with the United Kingdom, nor is it acceptable to attribute the exclusive right of negotiation to the European Union. In this way we always know which interests will be served and to the detriment also of which interests.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, dear Michel Barnier, please continue to work as you have done in recent years, preserving the unity of all European institutions. Dear colleagues – let’s be aware – let me underline that Brexit was tearing apart the UK society for years. It was tearing apart political parties, it was tearing apart the UK government and it needed two early elections to settle.  Meanwhile, in the European Parliament, we have fulfilled our mission. We work in a noiseless, very professional way to fulfil our missions. For this I would like to thank colleagues from all political groups which were part of this united majority.  What do we need to achieve as of now? Priority number one needs to be citizens’ rights. We need to give certainty to students, to farmers, to researchers about the future relationship. The objective needs to be as close a relationship as possible, but the instruments are clear – a rules-based relationship. The principle is clear – please respect the rules – and the outcome needs to be in line with today’s mandate of the European Parliament. Only then can we approve it in the end.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Brexit is a sad chapter in the history of Europe. We need more cooperation, not less. In this way, we safeguard stability and peace on our continent – a continent where conflicts and wars once resolved.  Now that the nationalist forces in Britain have had their dream fulfilled, it is important that those of us who believe in cooperation ensure that we get an agreement that puts the future first.  It is a question of achieving an agreement that enables good trade to be trade, but still stands up for the EUROPEAN internal market, protects the EU legal order, does not compromise on environmental and climate policy, stands up for the rights of our workers and fundamental rights and freedoms.  Boris Johnson can't eat the cake and keep the cake. His lies have already made too much noise. If he wants to ensure a good free trade agreement, he must also stand up for the demands I have just mentioned.  Finally, to the youth of Great Britain, who voted in favour of remaining in the EU in a superior majority, I would like to say: do not give up! There are many of us who are looking forward to a future where you can govern. Our paths can come together again.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, we have heard tough language on assuring a level playing field and not lowering our European standards, for example when it comes to food safety or environmental standards. But I do hope that the negotiating team will be just as tough when it comes to data protection standards. I’m quite worried to see the eagerness of the Commission to issue a so-called ‘adequacy decision’ when it is far from clear that the UK Government can be trusted with our data. I refer to recent scandals like the gross abuse of UK access to the Schengen database.  In addition to discussing our future relationship, let’s not forget the implementation of what has been agreed so far and in particular citizens’ rights. I strongly urge the Commission to make sure that the rights of 3.5 million EU citizens in the UK and 1.5 million British citizens in the EU27 will be secured not just on paper, but also in practice.

name: Markus BUCHHEIT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. here in the Chamber, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am perceived as a representative of a group that would generally stoke fears, unfounded emotions and the like. Well, at least we have not said anything about food or drug shortages in the UK after Brexit, or even border traffic chaos. These were not our words, these fears were stirred up here by representatives of the self-appointed bourgeois centre. I can only ask you for one thing – and I know it is difficult for you especially these days – and that is the recognition of a democratic process, of a democratic decision in the United Kingdom: accept The United Kingdom as a partner, as an interlocutor on an equal footing, and see the opportunities for a new free trade agreement that are now coming up as a possibility of a new start, as a way of building bridges – rather than here with a hard hand. , as has just been called for, to proceed – and to restart our relations on both sides of the Channel.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, we are well aware that the relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom, between our countries and the United Kingdom, will be decisive in many sectors. A lot of important things have been said, but I would like to go back to a fundamental point, which is the issue of fishing. Indeed, as we well know, fishing has been a key issue in the British debate that has decided Brexit. Today, we would have everything to lose if the fishery were to be separated from the overall negotiation with the British. I welcome, I am very pleased that, thanks to the energetic work of Michel Barnier, in particular, fisheries has been included in this negotiating mandate to ensure that a comprehensive agreement is negotiated, including this dimension. Indeed, if we do not reach an agreement on fisheries, tensions will be very high at sea and the disaster could be great from an economic point of view, but also from an ecological point of view. We need a common fisheries policy to preserve species and this is fundamental to the future of our countries.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! The aim of our negotiations here must be to have an ambitious free trade agreement between two close allies, the EU and The United Kingdom. We must be at the finish, i.e. this is a bottom-up task; but we also have to be very clear in our demands on the British. And our demand is that we say no to the British weakening workers' protection or environmental protection. We say no to the British lowering their taxes and raising their state aid. In other words: we must be crystal clear in our demand to ensure fair competition, equal competition, level playing field. Having said that, it is also in the EU's interest to get a deal and we must therefore not allow the annoyance that we had a Brexit to stand in the way of finding solutions that, for example, ensure that EU fishermen can continue to have access to British waters. It is in the interests of all of us that we have a good trade agreement with the British.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, Croatian Presidency, Commission, Michel Barnier, I think it will be worth stressing two aspects which have perhaps not yet been properly underlined here. The first is that it is essential, under any circumstances, that security issues are regulated in the relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union. Just think about what the terrorist attacks were, what was police cooperation between the UK services and the services of several European states to get an idea of what it would be like not to have a basis for agreement between the two sides of the English Channel. Finally, It also seems important to me that this agreement can be extended to the area of defence and to some areas of foreign policy. It is enough, for example, to look at what was the issue of Iran to see that the United Kingdom is much more aligned with the vision of the European Union than with other visions. And that is why we must work, both in the field of criminal cooperation and security, and in the field of defence and foreign policy.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, Mr Barnier, you have been a good negotiator throughout the process and I am convinced that you will bring us to a great deal. We need, first of all, that there be agreement. As my colleague Juan Fernando López Aguilar says, we need an agreement earlier to avoid the abyss.  Secondly, we need the agreement with the United Kingdom to be ambitious and to defend and represent well the interests of the European agricultural sector and the agri-food sector, with our quality standards, which the United Kingdom is well aware of. One of the important aspects of the negotiating mandate, to which a number of ladies and gentlemen have referred, is fisheries. You also know him perfectly, as he has dealt with these issues as Minister of Fisheries in France. It is important that we could close an agreement before 1 July so that we can know whether we can make a responsible allocation of the TAC and quotas and that, of course, our fisheries sector does not look helpless in the face of this situation and, finally, preserve Spain's opinion in everything that is negotiated with Gibraltar. It is very important to our country and I believe that for the European Union.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, first of all, many thanks to the Commission and Michel Barnier for their excellent work, and also thanks to the team drafting Parliament’s resolution. This is a very good resolution and I guess the debate was also good. At the end, almost everything was said, so let me just stress a few points.  First of all, free goes together with fair. These elements cannot be divided. And the second, rights goes together with obligation. Based on those principles, we would be able to build a very extensive, very deep agreement with the UK. We could, but it’s probably not very likely, because we have two constraints. The first is too many red lines and the second is too little time. Nevertheless, we should try our best, and there should be two principles guiding us. First of all, we cannot give up our principles. Principles are very important for us and for our partners. The second was stressed by the Council. Time is short; we must be quick and flexible to get the best results for all Europeans.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is important that the negotiations now take place on clear principles. Firstly, we must negotiate as a Union; parallel bilateral negotiations. Secondly, any degree of access to our common market must be followed by the corresponding compliance by the UK. The future relationship, as several have already said, will be based on competition on equal terms, including labour and social standards.  Take the transport area as an example. In order to guarantee continued transport between the EU and the UK, we need an agreement. Without an agreement, no transport, which would be a disaster, both for the EU and for Britain. At the same time, it must be noted that the UK is no longer a member. For road transport, for example, it is not reasonable for the UK to still have the possibility of cabotage traffic in the EU, and the possibility of transit through Continental Europe must be accompanied by full respect for the EU acquis.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: – Mr President, Brexit is a fact and the next step is a new association agreement with the United Kingdom. The British Government wants to conclude this agreement within just eight months, if not we will end up with a hard Brexit, which means that 42 000 jobs are at stake for Belgium. It is therefore essential that we conclude an agreement which can enter into force from 1 January 2021. But make no mistake: concluding a full association agreement in eight months' time is practically impossible. That is why we must dare to set priorities.  Firstly, our fishermen must be able to continue fishing in British waters. Secondly, there must be a level playing field for trade. Our food, textile and pharmaceutical sectors deserve certainty. Thirdly, there must also be an agreement on cooperation in the field of defence and justice. After all, the United Kingdom will remain a nearest neighbour.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, I would just like to refer to a matter of great importance in relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom: fisheries; in particular, the continuation of reciprocal access to much-needed fishing waters and resources, as Mr Barnier knows, is well known. I think it is essential , as others have already mentioned, for European fishermen to maintain access to the UK's waters and resources. Many important fishing communities and regions are highly affected by this issue. On the other hand, we cannot forget that European consumers are the main market for the fishery products of British fishermen. They are therefore complementary interests, so to speak. But what I would like to stress especially here is that we have to be firm in defending a bond that goes beyond what was stated above. For me , as for Mr Barnier himself, according to his public statements , an agreement that maintains access to the uk's waters and resources is a necessary condition for a free trade agreement to be possible. I would like this to be very clear in the negotiating mandate adopted by the Council and, of course, I welcome parliament's motion for a resolution to clearly reflect this linkage in paragraph 24.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Mr Barnier negotiator, after three agonizing years to avoid the chasm of an unrequited Brexit, we are now facing in just ten months a scenario no less stressful – the need for an agreement – and which can only be addressed from the criterion of unity, the demand for reciprocity and respect for European standards with the United Kingdom , which was never Schengen, was never a euro and has now become a third country with all the law.  And it is important to ensure this in order to avoid a tax haven on our borders, for example in Gibraltar, avoiding this tradition of fraud, capital concealment and smuggling, but above all by ensuring in the inclusion of the agreement the treatment that deserves the movement of people, judicial and police cooperation in the field of security and data protection and preventing a scandal such as the violation of European data protection rules from ever again. data in the Schengen Information System. It is therefore very important to pay the attention that this chapter deserves on the movement of persons and the freedoms to which I refer as Chairman of the Committee on Freedoms of Justice and the Interior.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, I say to Michel Barnier: to use your phrase, ‘the clock is ticking’. And we all know that it took three years, three torturous years, to negotiate the Withdrawal Agreement with only three key points in it. So, therefore, in 10 months we have to do much more and we have to be very careful of the detail. As others have said, we need a level playing field, we need a good relationship with the United Kingdom, so I wish us well in those negotiations. Colleagues will also know that there is and has been a general election in Ireland and there will be a new government. We hope that that government gets into place rather swiftly, because there is much work to be done. I hope, too, that they can build on the incredible work and achievements of Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, Tánaiste Simon Coveney, and Minister for European Affairs Helen McEntee, who helped and worked with the European Union to reach that Withdrawal Agreement, in particular on the Irish Protocol. Ten months is a very short space of time. This Parliament will be watching under the leadership of David McAllister, and we have to work together to keep our unity.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, sometimes, when I come in here I wonder am I living on the same planet as everyone else. I heard someone say that we shouldn’t allow the UK to become a tax haven. My God, right now sub-Saharan Africa loses three times as much in capital flight each year as it gains in aid investment and loans. And much of it is channelled, illegally and legally, through the banks in the city of London. It is a tax haven, and it has a network of tax havens to work with. If you are in denial about that, I just don’t understand the thinking. Unfair trading practices, talk about the merits of a free trade. The truth be told: unfair trade practices are killing farmers, indigenous people trying to make a living all over the planet. When is it ever going to stop? Brexit should be used as an opportunity to move towards a system in which capital is embedded in local economies, and not moving all over the planet at the expense of the environment and the people of the planet.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, we need a comprehensive partnership with the UK. It is obviously in our interest, but it is also in the interest of the United Kingdom. Such a partnership requires us to negotiate in detail every component of this agreement, in the interests of the citizens we represent.  We talked about data protection, the protection of innovation, trade, European standards, but obviously all of these things must also take into account the need for a partnership that includes other dimensions: the security and defence part, the protection of the rights of Europeans living there and, why not, can the continued participation of the UK in a number of European programmes , to the extent that they want it and we do.  That is why I am convinced that our negotiator, Mr Michel Barnier, is more than capable of doing so. I have had the pleasure of working with him in the past and I am convinced that we can deliver such a strategic partnership in a timely manner so that all these things are guaranteed further.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, Mr Michel Barnier, we have a situation that we did not want. We did not want Britain to leave the European Union, we did not want to create this moment that we have to manage today. But, I ask you, very importantly, to firmly reject any unacceptable conditionalities, any absurd issues that the Government in London will want to discuss with us. But you have to think about three important elements: to think also about the British who did not want Britain to leave the European Union; when we talk to London, think that there are 3.5 million European citizens in the UK and 1.5 million British citizens in the European Union. They're the ones we have to protect. And last but not least, all our action must be thought of in perspective, because one day Britain will have to come back with us.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In Poland, it is said that it does not harm roses when the forest burns, so together we should put out this post-Brexit fire. I stress: together. And I hope that this is the intention of all of us here. Of course, that was not what Brexit was like. As the European Union and the United Kingdom, we will work together a little bit, compete a little bit. But one of our first needs as Europeans is security. So would you like to say a few sentences on this? I am talking about external security in particular. Do you not see any danger in this area? This is very important for all of us.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, as an Irish citizen, we’ve obviously always had a very close and intertwined history with the UK – not all of it welcome, but that’s another story. But that relationship will continue, and it is in our mutual interest that it should be a cooperative one. Now, Ms von der Leyen talked about there needing to be rules to bring fairness to the heart of business. But the key question is: fairness for who? Because if the rules continue to favour big business, the big corporations, the arms industry, the big farmers, and so on, then citizens will be left behind. That was one of the reasons for Brexit, and it was one of the key reasons for the almighty trouncing that Leo Varadkar’s team got in the Irish election this weekend. It was a rejection of neoliberalism. Now, I wish you well in your negotiations. You have a number of issues to deal with, not least the situation of the medical profession and the need for you to work inter-institutionally to deliver progress. I echo the points of my colleagues about the data issues and the breaches by the UK. But critically, I urge you to protect, and have no backtracking on, the Good Friday Agreement.

name: Alexander ALEXANDROV YORDANOV
text: – Madam President, Mr Barnier, there are still problems between us and Britain. It is already clear that they will be visible in the negotiations for the trade agreement, but these negotiations, these problems, should not affect the common security and defence interests and policy. We need to strengthen our cooperation within THE EU as the only guarantor of European and global security at the moment.  We need to be in a position to coordinate our relationship with Britain in foreign policy. I mean the existence of hot or frozen conflicts like Russian aggression against Ukraine, the Syrian crisis, tensions in the Middle East, Iran's policy, terrorism. The post-Brexit situation actually allows us to better cooperate in the European Union triangle – Britain – United States.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, I would really like to stop at what our relations with The United States should look like for the future. We really need to strive for the highest possible level of relations and strive for something more than a simple treaty or free trade agreement. We must also remain credible partners during these negotiatings, who can also rely on each other to push through foreign policy priorities. We need fair competition so that there is no dumping, so that we can really trade together without any barriers, but at the same time, for example, Britain cannot apply exorbitant State aid, it cannot, cannot, cannot release from its high European, european social and environmental standards, but it must stick to its commitments to combat climate change. First of all, however, it is about ensuring the highest possible level of rights for our citizens who study, work or trade there. We need to give them the confidence to live as best they can.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Head of the task force for relations with the United Kingdom. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Minister, at your last session in Brussels , and Ursula von der Leyen referred to this moving session - you said goodbye to all your British colleagues leaving Parliament because of Brexit. At the beginning of this session, you will allow me to greet the new colleagues who join you and also to tell them, too, the availability that we have, that of the Commission, for their mandate. I would like to start by thanking you for your confidence, which touches me, and encourages an exceptional team that I have the honour to lead and which is that of the European Commission, which is also your negotiating team. I would also like to thank you for the content of your resolution, which marks principles, values and positions. Your negotiator needs and will need this determination, this resolution, throughout the coming months to help him in this difficult negotiation. Earlier, Mairead McGuinness said: "the clock is ticking." I just want to remind you, on this subject of time, that the time of transition, which is set out in the Withdrawal Treaty, is indeed a limited time, which can be extended by one year or two years by a common agreement. If it is not extended, as we understand it, it means that the UK will leave the single market and customs union on 31 December this year. It is a choice, and this choice of time is determined by the British Prime Minister, not by us. And everyone must understand that this time constraints, before the United Kingdom leaves the single market and the customs union, this constrained time chosen by the British Prime Minister has consequences. Of course, everyone has to take responsibility for them. This constraint of time is not us who put it in the negotiation.  But that constraint also means one thing, because we are not in a trade negotiation — when we negotiate with Canada or with Japan, we try to get closer, to converge. Some people think that convergence is not enough, but we are getting there. If we do not reach an agreement with those countries, we take more time. We give more time to negotiation: one year, two years... For Canada, it took seven years. And until an agreement is reached, it is the status quo for both sides. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you that, in this particular case, it will not be the status quo. If we do not reach an agreement on 31 December on trade, it will not be the status quo because that day, as the British Prime Minister has chosen, and no later than that day, 31 December, therefore, the United Kingdom will come out of the single market and the customs union and go back, if I may say so, within the WTO.  This means that beyond the controls we will do anyway, because of Brexit, on all the products that will come from the UK (as we do these checks on all products that come from third countries and enter the single market, to protect consumers and businesses), beyond these controls, which in any case are necessary , in this particular case, if there is a failure, if there is no agreement, there will be quotas and tariffs on all British products. That is the consequence, if we do not reach an agreement in this time constraint chosen by the British Prime Minister. Ladies and gentlemen, all your groups have called for a strong relationship, at the height of our common history. And we do not forget, I do not forget, this common history and solidarity of the United Kingdom, especially in the darkest hours of the last century.
