A logical relationship, of course, Philippe Lamberts said, when looking at geography. A necessary relationship, when we measure economic interests, but also climate issues or security issues. A lucid and demanding relationship, when we listen - which I am doing very carefully - to some Of the British discourse at the moment about the use that would be made - I am speaking on conditional, I do not want to make a trial of intent - of the new capacity for regulatory divergence that the United Kingdom wanted to achieve with Brexit.  This strong, ambitious, lucid, demanding relationship is the state of mind of the European Commission, as our President Ursula von der Leyen said earlier, and that is what is contained in the proposed mandate which is on your table and which is being discussed in the Council to be approved, I hope, on 25 February. A negotiation, ladies and gentlemen, with a partner - I repeat the words of Barry Andrews while time - a partner who must understand - and I say calmly but firmly - that the opening of our markets, access to data - I answer, Mrs in't Veld, to your question - the equivalencies for financial services, referred to by Danuta Hunner, I repeat: the opening of our markets, access to data, equivalencies - I mean equivalencies for financial services - will be proportional to the commitments made together to respect a real level playing field. Regulatory coherence in certain areas, the protection of citizens and, I would add, let us not have a short memory: the financial stability of our continent and the euro area. I would like to tele telegraphly respond to a few specific points. First, Geert Bourgeois spoke earlier about the issue of cooperation, particularly in the North Sea, on energy. I will be taking stock today with Vice-President Timmermans on this issue. Of course, Mr Bourgeois, we would like to see cooperation with the United Kingdom in this region of the North Sea on energy issues. This cooperation is also included in our draft mandate. But Brexit has mechanical and logical consequences. The British are no longer in the European Union, so the framework for cooperation must be reviewed, logically. The United Kingdom no longer participates in European forums because it wanted to, it is its choice, and therefore we must find, Mr Bourgeois, another way to cooperate with them and we will look for it. Paulo Rangel earlier, Mr. Lopez Aguilar at the time, Mr. Rzo-cca also, spoke about internal and external security. It is also in our mandate to open several negotiating tables on the subjects of internal security, cooperation in the field of extradition, Europol, Eurojust, anti-money laundering, Pum, PNR... These are all subjects that require an agreement with the British in the common interest, for the protection of the security of citizens. But also, and Mr. Alexandrov mentioned it at the time, external security. I mean on this subject of defence and foreign policy that Brexit should not normally have an impact on the bilateral cooperation that many of your countries have with the United Kingdom - I am talking about cooperation between this or that country of the Union and the United Kingdom - and therefore should not have any impact on what we are doing together in NATO. What this is about, for this negotiation, is the cooperation between the European Union, in particular the new initiatives we are taking for defence, and the United Kingdom, if it so will. So we made a proposal and confirmed this proposal to open a negotiating table on these issues. The political statement makes clear reference to external security and defence. We need texts on these subjects to insert administrative or political cooperation into the law and legal texts - I think of the Defence Agency, I think of the fight against cyber attacks, I think about cooperation between the intelligence services, I am also thinking about the possibility for the British to participate, if they want to , to external operations of the Union, military or civil-military, and I am obviously thinking of political cooperation with a very important country which remains a member of the United Nations Security Council. All of this has to be translated into texts and we are ready to discuss it, but there must be two of us to do so. So we are open and we remain open to this negotiation to improve the joint management of the security issues and stability of the continent.  We are also ready to discuss everything else. Earlier, Terry Reintke was referring to Erasmus. Of course, we must continue to cooperate in academic field, research cooperation, and the participation of the British, if they wish, in European programmes. And we will have a negotiating table, from March, on all the European programmes - I mean all the programmes, including Erasmus - but it will be with a different legal framework and a different financial framework today. Danuta H-bner spoke earlier about the issue of financial services and the relationship we need to have with the United Kingdom. Beyond what is written in the draft mandate and what we usually do in agreements with third countries, there will be no actual negotiations on financial services. On the other hand, we have to find a relationship with the United Kingdom, given the importance of London Square and the City, which I am familiar with. So we're going to use the equivalency toolkit, Danuta H-bner referred to. As we will in terms of data, we will use the adequacy decisions toolkit. We do not negotiate on these issues with the United Kingdom, we check consistency and, when we see it as possible, we give equivalencies on a particular sector of the financial industry. That is what we have done with Canada, what we are doing with the United States, what we are doing with Japan, and it is working. So I don't see why it wouldn't work with the UK. But I would like to take this session to make it clear to some British officials that there should be no illusions on this issue: there will be no general and comprehensive, or permanent, equivalence on financial services. There will also be no co-management of financial equivalency with the United Kingdom. We will retain control of these tools and maintain decision-making autonomy. At the same time, I would like to point out that in this period we have additional reasons to continue to act, and that is the purpose of our Vice-President Valdis Dombrovskis' work for the union of capital markets and the continuation and consolidation of the banking union. I mean, fishing. Mr Bellamy, but also Mr M millon Mon, Mr Peeters, Mrs Schaldemose, Mrs Aguilera, among others, raised this issue, which I am familiar enough to have had the honour of being Minister of Fishermen of my own country for a few years. I just want to say that reciprocal access to territorial waters and markets - I mean reciprocal access to waters and markets - will be an inseparable point in the trade agreement, because it is trade. This will therefore be an inseparable point of the trade agreement and the level playing field in this negotiation.  Ladies and gentlemen, we have always respected, even if we have regretted it, the choice of the United Kingdom to leave the European Union. The Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, whom we respect, said that by leaving the European Union, the United Kingdom was not leaving Europe. We are pleased with this resolution. The question that is being asked and to which we do not have an answer at the moment is the following - it is quite simple, but quite serious: the United Kingdom is leaving the European Union, leaving the single market and the customs union, but does it also want to leave or move away from our European economic, social and regulatory model? A model he knows well, since we have built it with him for 47 years. That is the question we are waiting for an answer to. How far does the UK want to move away from our social, economic and regulatory model? And I would just like to say that it is he, ladies and gentlemen, I say this with great clarity and calm, it is the United Kingdom that will set the level of ambition for our future relationship in these areas, it is it that will choose the level of regulatory coherence, who will determine, therefore, the ambition, or who will choose the level of regulatory competition. And I recommend that the answer to this question that we ask be well thought out in the constrained time we have before us. I end with three telegraphic reflections. Ladies and gentlemen, I have always told the truth before you and I will continue. Brexit can't be business as usual. There are changes in all areas. Some changes may be more or less large or temporary, other changes are final. Brexit means that the UK financial service loses its financial passport. There is no mutual recognition.  The result of Brexit is that, in any event, ladies and gentlemen, we will impose controls on 1 January on all products that will enter the single market, as we do for all other third countries in the world. We owe this protection to consumers, to national and European budgets, and we also owe it to businesses. So it won't be business as usual. But we will try to limit the consequences by finding a good agreement. The second thought is that we must work to enforce and respect the withdrawal agreement ourselves. It is not a banality. The 600-page withdrawal agreement is now ratified by you and the House of Commons and must be implemented. I will report publicly to you and to the Council on a regular basis on the state of readiness throughout this year, in particular on the implementation of the protocol in Ireland, which guarantees a still fragile peace. Finally, this negotiation will be difficult, very difficult, ladies and gentlemen. I therefore recommend that we remain prepared for all assumptions, including one where we will not reach a basic agreement until 31 December. We remain ready to conduct this negotiation with respect, as I have always done, and a lot of calm, without any aggression. I will never lose sight of, beyond the difficulties of daily negotiation, the need to find, on your behalf, an ambitious agreement with a great friendly, neighbouring and allied country, and I will always continue, with total determination, to defend the interests of the European Union, its citizens, its businesses, to defend the integrity of the internal and unique market, which will not be , has never been and will never be negotiable. Finally, of course, Madam President, Parliament can be assured that the European Commission, as your negotiator, will always be ready to work with you, to listen to you, to report to you. I will therefore mark the same availability, as I said throughout these three years before Brexit and as I said the other day - it was a group led by Guy Verhofstadt, in the presence of David McAllister and the coordination group and in the presence of all the group chairs - I will continue to be fully available to work with the European Parliament , in confidence with you.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I also join Mr Barnier in greeting the new Members of the European Parliament and I’m looking forward to our discussions here. With your vote on the resolution on the proposed mandate for negotiations for a new partnership with the UK, you will provide a timely and useful input into the finalisation of this mandate. We should aim to build a relationship that is comprehensive, based on high standards and that guarantees a level playing field. The very comprehensive nature of the proposed mandate and likely long negotiations that may ensue in certain sectors will probably call for further debates in the coming months and years. This new phase should not make us forget about the Withdrawal Agreement, which has just been concluded, and the need to remain vigilant as regards its implementation, first and foremost with respect to the preservation of citizens’ rights, be it during the transition period or under whatever future relationship with the United Kingdom. But our vigilance will have to be no less thorough when considering the intended economic partnership, where strong safeguards and robust governance will be called for to protect the integrity of the EU single market and the competitive position of EU firms. We will therefore count on your cooperation in this respect as well.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 12 February 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – Apparently, from Brexit, the EU comes out weak, as an image, but also numerically. But the strength of the Union does not stand in numbers, because if it had stood, it would not have been so strong and attractive from the beginning. Member countries have voluntarily chosen to ad, have not been forced. The strength of the Union is derived from values and principles and from its constant concern for its citizens. The sum of these elements makes it not only strong, but also a model that others have chosen to either respect or want. That is why, even if this year's negotiations have to take into account that there are people behind each sector, it is vital that we do not give up any of our values, principles and beliefs. They have held us together all these decades and made the European Union the most successful geopolitical project in history. A unique supranational partnership. If we showed that we are willing to compromise our values, we would encourage other Member States to resolve their various disputes by threatening to exit. We must ensure that the Union's positions are respected. We must negotiate as before, from a position of strength, firmly.

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: Writing. – After Brexit, 31 January 2020, it is important to build a strong new EU partnership with the UK, for the benefit of UK citizens and for the benefit of all European citizens. The United Kingdom will cease to have the privileges of a Member State and access to Community funding. We believe that the final agreement between the EU and the United Kingdom should be aimed primarily at free trade, but on the basis — always — of the principles of free competition. We also think it is an important issue of the free movement of students, tourists and workers; a right that must be guaranteed. Areas of close cooperation must also be those of the fight against terrorism and security. Finally, we call for the Union to safeguard the interests of European businesses and European citizens, to the extent that they are shaken by Brexit.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – Britain's departure from the EU is not a joy, but it is a fait accompli. The focus must now be on the Agreement between the EU and the UK. Without fees and allowances is a principle that would be beneficial for both parties. It is important to comply with product standards in order to have fair competition and consumer security. Economic partnership, security and respect for the principles of non-discrimination and full reciprocity in the field of mobility are things to be contained in the agreement. Land and European transport must be addressed ambitiously in the agreement negotiated with the United Kingdom and optimal solutions must be identified on these topics. Citizens' rights must be respected and placed first in the Withdrawal Agreement.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Writing. – The EU's future partnership with Britain must be based on a level playing field and the association agreement as close as possible must be based on economic partnership, partnership on foreign affairs and specific sectoral issues. Likewise, the UK as a 'third country' cannot enjoy the same benefits as EU Member States and, in all circumstances, ensure the indivisibility of the single market and customs union. Britain's competition with the EU must be open and fair, which means guaranteeing equal standards in terms of social protection, environmental protection, taxation, state aid, consumer protection and the climate. It also means 'dynamic harmonisation' between Uk and EU norms. We in the EP are also asking for British guarantees in the area of citizens' rights and freedom of movement, as regards data protection, financial services, the situation in Ireland, and the role of the European Court of Justice in settling disputes.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: in writing. – In the discussions concerning future relations between the European Union and Great Britain we have to remember that we are talking not only about the economy, not only about capital flows, taxes or physical borders. We are also talking about education, culture and exchange of scientific research. We should create such conditions in which the latter are not hindered by the mere fact that Great Britain is not a member of the EU anymore. Most young people in Great Britain voted against Brexit – some polls say that 7 out of ten young Britons, aged from 18 to 24 years of age, voted against it. Thus, it is my strong belief that Great Britain should be as closely involved in programmes like Erasmus+, Creative Europe, Horizon Europe etc. as possible. If the bridge between the EU and the Great Britain is to connect and be ready for a future come-back of Great Britain to the EU, it has to be open. As a former Erasmus student myself I can testify to the power of such connections first-hand.

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: in writing. – The result of the Irish election this weekend was a Green wave of two shades, delivered big gains for Greens and for Sinn Féin. Brexit did not figure in the election, thanks to the EU’s work in minimising the damage to Ireland from the UK’s exit. But challenges remain, and this election result could foreshadow more issues regarding the Irish border into the future. This Parliament, and the Commission, must do all they can to ensure that the free movement of peoples and the permeability of the border is maintained into the long term. We need clarity from the UK government on the protocol for Northern Ireland, and the highest level of alignment possible. Another immediate issue facing the negotiations is the July deadline for an agreement on reciprocal access to each other’s waters so we can allow our fishers to keep fishing in a sustainable manner, with minimised disruption. Such a timeline seems unrealistic for an area of such complexity, and the Parliament’s PECH Committee will have to play an active role in ensuring we reach a deal that prevents significant damage being done to both EU and UK fishers and the sustainability priorities of the CFP.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. – Britain may have left the EU, but it remains not only a close neighbour but also, preferably, a loyal ally with which we have close relations. Parliament is clear: we are demanding an ambitious deal with our British friends, not only on our future trading relationships, but also on other issues where cooperation benefits us both. Such a close relationship presupposes that the UK respects European social, labour and environmental standards.  But let us be clear: we want a close, lasting relationship with the UK, its citizens, entrepreneurs and scientists, not necessarily with the current government. Governments are temporary. The deal we're aiming for has to last a long time. So let us remain cold-blooded when the Johnson Government makes bizarre proposals that might lead to a No Deal and aim to break up the European Member States. We must now show fortitude and make it clear to the Johnson Government that we want very close cooperation, but if the British Government still takes the plunge, Europe is ready for a No Deal. The Johnson administration must be aware that the EU is united in solidarity.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: in writing. – The mobility of persons and workers was always directly linked to the smooth functioning of the internal market of the European Union the United Kingdom would like frictionless access to. Over the years, however, it has also changed the social fabric of the societies on both sides of the channel. A too severe approach to immigration risks tearing apart a myriad links in this fabric. We can just think of the relatives of the 3.5m citizens of EU countries who have the right to remain in the UK, whose relatives would not be able to move back and forth between their countries of residence and the UK under current UK plans. But we can also think of UK citizens remaining in Europe who would be tied to their EU countries of residence and the young britons who treasure the possibility to go to Europe without a visa and get study, work and life experiences on the continent. Any ambitious agreement on the future relationship should be mindful of these social links and would need to ensure the continuation of rights for EU and UK citizens to the largest degree possible.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the recommendation of Geert Bourgeois on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (06050/2019 - C9-0023/2019 - 2018 /0356(NLE)) (A9-0003/2020), – the report by Geert Bourgeois on behalf of the Committee on International Trade with a non-legislative motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (2018) /0356M(NLE)) (A9-0017/2020), – Geert Bourgeois's recommendation on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on a draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Investment Protection Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other (059 31/2019 – C9-0020/2019 - 2018/0358(NLE)) (A9-0002/2020) and – the report by Geert Bourgeois on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on a draft motion for a resolution a Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Investment Protection Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, on the other (2018/0358M(NLE)) (A9-0014/2020).

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, tomorrow we will vote on the EU—Vietnam Free Trade Agreement and the Investment Protection Agreement. These are the first state—of—the art trade and investment agreements on which this newly-elected Parliament is asked to give its consent. It’s a unique opportunity for this Parliament to underline the ambition of the EU to become a geopolitical actor and player: not as an empire that imposes rules, but as a global power that defends multilateralism, resists protectionism and reaches out to partners such as Vietnam. It is up to the European Union to promote rules-based trade and show by example that trade delivers, brings peoples together and raises standards worldwide on safety, labour, environment and human rights. It’s also a question of credibility. We need to show Vietnam and future trading partners that the EU is a credible partner that sticks to its commitment and that we are still able to negotiate, sign and conclude trade agreements. Eight years after starting the negotiations with Vietnam, this Parliament has been given the opportunity to debate the most comprehensive trade deal between the EU and a middle—income country in its history. As such, this deal with Vietnam sets a new benchmark for Europe’s engagement with emerging economies. If we look at this trade agreement, it is of the utmost importance to stress, first of all, the economic value that will give a boost to the prosperity of both the EU and Vietnam. It represents a great opportunity for European exporters and investors. It will eliminate 99% of tariffs within seven years, and this will result in additional exports in both directions. This will clearly result in many tens of thousands of new and, on average, better-paid jobs through increased use of international standards. This deal will also cut non—trade barriers and reduce costs for our companies. We will gain better access to each other’s public markets, including for SMEs. Vietnam has a vibrant economy of more than 90 million consumers, a growing middle class and a young, dynamic workforce. The country is open to the world and embraces modern standards. Vietnam was the first in the world, even before Canada, to accept the principle of a modern investment court system (ICS), a modern ICS proposal that has mostly been drafted by this very Parliament with independent judges, a code of conduct, protection of the right to regulate and facilitated access to the court for SMEs. This agreement thus brings new opportunities for companies, both big corporations and SMEs. Vietnam is also the gateway to the entire Asian region. This agreement brings the long—term goal of an EU—Asian trade agreement from region to region a step closer, and this should be our objective. These agreements are also instruments to promote and protect European standards and values. Vietnam respects clear commitments to the ratification of two additional core International Labour Organization (ILO) Conventions: its revised Labour Code, its improved labour and human rights situation and the implementation of the Paris climate agreement. For all these reasons and the creation of prosperity by free and fair trade and the fact that the EU is taking responsibility to set the standards worldwide and taking the lead on rules—based trade in times of rising trade tensions, protectionism and unilateralism, I therefore ask for the consent of this House so that the peoples of the European Union and the people of Vietnam can further strengthen their ties in the future and so that we can allow free and fair trade to bring people closer together. (Applause)

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, the Free Trade Agreement and the Investment Protection Agreement with Vietnam are the most ambitious ever concluded with a developing country. The agreements will further reinforce our already-strong trade and investment ties, and they will also provide an additional opportunity to strengthen the cooperation established under other EU instruments, for example on illegal logging or IUU (Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated) fishing. The agreements will strengthen our presence in Asia, following the ‘new generation agreements’ in force, such as those with Korea, Japan and Singapore. They will constitute an additional stepping-stone towards our engagement with the ASEAN region. The benefits of the agreements are many: preferential access to a vibrant economy of almost 100 million people; removal of non-tariff barriers for our exporters, which they currently face, for example, on cars, on wines, and spirits; harmonised sanitary and phytosanitary rules allowing for more predictable procedures; and removing access barriers for EU products. EU companies will have access for the first time to the Vietnamese public procurement market, and there will be protection of the European geographical indications such as Parmigiano-Reggiano, Champagne and Rioja wines. We will also have improved access to the Vietnamese market in services, such as finance, distribution, logistics or environmental services. The Investment Protection Agreement, similar to agreements with Singapore and Canada, includes the modern and reformed investment protection framework with an investment court system for the resolution of investment disputes. However, our agreements will be on trade and investment, and I’m aware that the European Parliament has put a strong emphasis on the trade and sustainable development chapter of the Vietnam Agreement. And I fully agree with this approach. It is encouraging to see the level of engagement by Vietnam in order to prepare for the implementation of their commitments, with important progress made even before the agreements are in force at all. The pressure that has been exerted by the European Union is bearing fruit, and I welcome this development. On labour issues, Vietnam adopted a new labour code last November, which recognises the principle of freedom of association at enterprise level. The revised code also includes new provisions on collective bargaining in line with the ILO Fundamental Convention, which was recently ratified by Vietnam. Vietnam has now ratified 6 out of the 8 ILO conventions, and it has a clear plan to ratify the outstanding conventions by 2021 and 2023. Work is also ongoing in Vietnam to eradicate child labour, with encouraging preliminary results unveiled recently by the ILO, which is a significant reduction of more than 40% since the last survey of 2012. So these developments are remarkable. But nevertheless, the Commission will scrutinise implementation to ensure that Vietnam effectively pursues this ambitious labour reform agenda. Vietnam has also started preparing the ground for the institutional structure that is foreseen under the Free Trade Agreement, including the involvement of independent civil society organisations, such as domestic advisory groups.  The human rights situation is certainly an area of concern in our relationship with Vietnam, but I remain convinced that constructive channels of communication, including the Annual Human Rights Dialogue, is the way to voice our concerns and address these shortcomings. So Madam President, I firmly believe that these agreements will create the best platform for further engagement and constructive dialogue with Vietnam in all fields. On the other hand, our failure to ratify the deal would leave the European Union with fewer options to pursue a reform agenda in Vietnam and would undermine the credibility of the European Union as a reliable partner.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the AFET committee. I will vote for these two agreements with Vietnam, because I am deeply convinced that they are an opportunity for both the Vietnamese people and the Europeans.  From the point of view of human rights in Vietnam, of course our reluctance is enormous, but here too I am convinced that we must take advantage of the openness created by the establishment of European companies and investments subject to European criteria and obligations. The isolation of Vietnam would be the worst situation in my opinion. With this agreement, the Vietnamese government is committed to respecting fundamental rights and, above all, it accepts the monitoring of the application of the rules by a joint committee of the European and Vietnamese parliaments. The agreement also provides, and this is a great victory, for the European Commission to establish an independent human rights complaints mechanism. Finally, Vietnam proposed that the European Parliament's Human Rights Committee participate in the Vietnam-European Union human rights dialogue. This is a first and allows Parliament to be present at a negotiating table where it usually does not sit. Let us take advantage of all the openings to advance human rights.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Madam President, free trade is one of the best tools to lift people out of poverty. History proves that with all clarity. With this agreement, we ensure that Vietnam can go forward on a path of inclusive growth, and also with this Free Trade Agreement we set a very high standard as a comprehensive agreement with a developing country. And, as Chair of the Development Committee, I’m very pleased that this agreement has a very dedicated chapter also on sustainable development, and this needs to be effectively implemented. I would also welcome the timetable from Vietnam on when to ratify the outstanding core ILO conventions, and I urge both parties to make full use of the provisions in the agreement in order to contribute to strengthening human rights in Vietnam and towards the Sustainable Development Goals. I also urge the Commission to work closely with civil society to ensure that growth in Vietnam now also will strengthen environmental protection and labour rights. To conclude, the Committee on Development recommends that we give our consent to this agreement.

name: Pietro BARTOLO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the free trade agreement with Vietnam includes a chapter that includes the important trade in fish products that already exist between the two partners. Together with our colleagues in the Committee on Fisheries, we have worked on an opinion which is not limited to passive acceptance of the agreement but which could contribute to the parliamentary debate by raising the bar and setting specific priorities. Vietnam has undoubtedly made significant efforts to bring its fisheries sector into line with our standards and has shown that it wants to continue working to improve the existing situation in the future. At the same time, we cannot deny the many shortcomings that still persist, particularly in the area of illegal fishing. That is precisely why, in the Committee on Fisheries, we called on the European Commission to remain vigilant and careful in order to ensure that Vietnam continues its efforts and, at the same time, uses all the means at its disposal, including the red card if Vietnam fails to fulfil the conditions for sustainable development agreed with the European Union.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, honourable colleagues, distinguished Commissioner, the negotiations between the European Union and Vietnam started in 2012. They were first concluded in 2015, subsequently reopened and then finalised in June 2019. These eight years has witnessed dramatic progress in Vietnamese society, economy, labour conditions, environmental protection and sustainability. One of the crucial ferments of these changes is the European Union. The perspective of enhancing EU—Vietnam cooperation by implementing the Free Trade Agreement and the Investment Protection Agreement gives positive motivation to the Vietnamese authorities.  Just recently we have received a work plan on domestic advisory groups, a work plan and implementation plan on the Labour Code and a positive answer to the establishment of a Joint Parliamentary Oversight Committee between the National Assembly of Vietnam and the European Parliament. This House faces tomorrow a crucial choice: to grant or not to grant consent to the EU—Vietnam agreements. Postponement would be the 20th century choice. When we give homework to Vietnam and then send them home to do the work. Granting consent is the 21st century European choice, when we formulate our expectations and then we say to our Vietnamese partners: ‘let’s do it together’. As the shadow rapporteur for the EPP Group, my appeal is to vote for consent tomorrow and then to work together – the EU and Vietnam – for a better, freer and more sustainable future.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Fifty years ago, Willy Brandt developed the concept of 'change through rapprochement' in order to be able to enter into dialogue with countries that have fundamentally different views and to discuss how to improve the situation for the people on the ground. This is exactly the right way to try, also in the relationship with Vietnam, to try to improve the situation of the people on the ground through dialogue – especially with Vietnam, a country with which we trade a lot. I am convinced that many of you, ladies and gentlemen, are wearing clothes from Vietnam, wearing shoes from Vietnam, all Samsung smartphones are from Vietnam, all Samsung tablets are from Vietnam. And I would like us to set rules here so that production is in order in terms of standards, in terms of the use of chemicals and, above all, in terms of workers' rights. And Commissioner, with all due respect, these achievements have been achieved by the European Parliament. Over the last two years, we have been negotiating intensively. And I am proud of this Parliament for taking advantage of the opportunities we have by enforcing fundamental ILO core labour standards and implementing them, by getting it, for a binding implementation plan controlled by the ILO to be put on the table by Vietnam, by ensuring that the Domestic Advisory Groups of civil society organisations are staffed by independent civil society organisations. , that the space for civil society has been enlarged, that we have really managed to improve the human rights situation, that the European Parliament's Subcommittee on Human Rights has been integrated into the human rights dialogue for the first time – and that we have never done so before – and that we have also enforced parliamentary cooperation in the implementation of the agreement. So in that respect, we as a Parliament can be really proud that we have achieved this. But I also say that the work is starting now, because we will continue to fight for the agreement to improve the situation of the people on the ground. So the work starts!

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, honourable Commissioner, Members of Parliament, Europe stands strong for free trade. Tomorrow we can make history. These are the most ambitioned agreements that the EU has ever negotiated with a developing country. There will be an economic win-win for both parties. The EU and Vietnam are already important trading partners. This trade will continue, with or without agreements. But with these agreements, our trade will become more equitable, more predictable and more sustainable for the environment, for the people and for the climate. During the negotiation, Vietnam has improved workers’ rights; 6 out of 8 ILO conventions have been signed; child labour has been significantly reduced. We know that some voices have been raised wanting to postpone tomorrow’s vote, as the democratic development in Vietnam has not been enough, and yes, we wish that we could have seen much more progress when it comes to democracy and human rights. But we have to ask ourselves in this Chamber: do we want to have a better chance to promote democracy without the Agreement? Let’s not make the reformists or the freedom fighters who want more EU presence disappointed. We should take every opportunity to use these agreements as platforms for freedom and for democracy, and during the last week under the Parliament’s scrutiny, some small positive signals have come. Let us now vote in favour of these agreements, and let us use the monitoring time to promote democracy, to promote human rights in Vietnam together.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, even before any commercial assessment, we must remember that Vietnam is a politically repressive state in which the Communist Party has a monopoly on power and there are no independent media. No dissent is tolerated, criticism of the government is punished with long prison sentences, there are no free trade unions, religious cults are controlled by the state. Many of the commitments made by the Vietnamese authorities are made without specific deadlines. To be content with overly general declarations of intent is unforgivable naivety. On the environmental level, the contrast with the sacrifices that the EU imposes on its Member States is clear: in Vietnam coal is the main resource for electricity generation, coal is expected to contribute more than 40 % to the energy mix and about 100 coal-fired power plants are expected to be completed by 2030. There is also a lack of projects and a serious financial commitment to the purification of industrial water and those of the Mekong River, a threat to the seas and to the wholesomeness of vietnamese rice, which would like to be granted access to zero duty in Europe amounting to 80 000 tonnes per year, with the risk of triangulation from neighbouring countries such as Cambodia. Unfortunately, this is an indication of the Commission's lack of sensitivity to an important and sensitive sector such as rice.  The issue of the protection of intellectual property, which is now entrusted to cumbersome and not at all effective legislation in Vietnam, remains dangerously in the balance. This could cause harm to our companies.  We have a duty not to forget these considerations at the time of the vote, so that the values that our Europe has always proclaimed and which it should also defend instead of thinking only of economic profit are not betrayed.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, after voting against a postponement of the agreement yesterday, our Assembly is about to make the first major gap since the inauguration of the European Commission: between its values, its principles, its statements on respect for human rights - including your report, Madam, the Wiseler-Lima report on human rights in the world, which we were voting on as recently as last year , but also the Green Pact, by ratifying the free trade and investment agreement with Vietnam.  Vietnam has committed to reforming its labour code, and will ratify ILO conventions, but to make effective freedom of association and expression and the emergence of independent trade unions, a reform of the penal code must take place; it is indispensable. And that is what we have asked for in letters to the Vietnamese authorities; we have called for a postponement of the ratification process to work together with Vietnam through dialogue. But, Mr Lange, Vietnam has put a real end to these questions, these demands.  So we now know that the reforms requested will not take place, especially at the criminal level, and yet we, as a parliamentary assembly, would be prepared to accept that, in the name of what? Economic interests. But which ones, Mr Hogan, which ones, Mr Bourgeois? Since the report, the European Commission's economic assessment shows that the deficit in our trade balance will be further aggravated by this agreement. We have apparently not met the same economic sectors of wood, textiles and rice, which, like us, are calling for a postponement of this agreement. Worse, the Vietnamese authorities justify the arrest of independent journalists, not to mention Mr. Pham Chi Dung, in the name of limits on press freedom. A nice snub for our assembly which, through the voice of its president, had challenged Vietnam on this matter. A big gap also with the green pact. Indeed, we will reward a country that practices illegal fishing and deforestation by unconditionally strengthening a free trade agreement and our investments there.  This is not to mention the potential conflict of interest that has shaken this file from the beginning, since we have continued our work as if nothing had happened. Colleagues, in recent weeks you have received calls like me from hundreds of NGOs, citizens and trade unions who apparently do not have your ear today. The request for postponement is also relayed on the grounds of the deterioration in recent weeks, in recent months, in recent years, of the human rights situation in Vietnam.  I dared to hope, dear Socialist Liberal colleagues, for a reversal on your part from the negotiation we have had in recent weeks. It is clear today that the Green Pact and human rights are not yet being respected by this Assembly.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: for the ECR group. – Madam President, after eight years of negotiation and negotiation, we are almost at the end of the line. Let me therefore say a few words as a former rapporteur for these treaties from the beginning until last autumn. First of all, I would like to stress that the Treaty was duly negotiated by the European Commission in accordance with the principles of EU trade policy and the mandate given by the European Council. I think that the EU must send a signal that it is on the side of free trade, that it is on the side of removing trade barriers at a time of increasing protectionism and at a time when the United States has withdrawn from an already negotiated trade agreement with the countries of South-East Asia. We have a unique chance to fill this vacuum. No other agreement with any other Southeast Asian country is on the way at the moment, not in sight. I think Vietnam is growing into a geopolitical power, it's a country of over 90 million people. It is an ASEAN presidency, it is a volatile member of the UN Security Council and it is in the POLITICAL and economic interest of the EU to have this agreement. If we do not close it, the EU will not win, the United States or China will win, but we will certainly not profit from it.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, then, should a partnership with Vietnam be deepened? Yes, we all agree. Does that necessarily mean a free trade agreement? Well, no, and that's where the debate comes in between us.  You think - it's a bit of a magic thought - that a free trade agreement necessarily solves all the problems. No, that is not true. Firstly, I do not share the Commission's optimism that it is a win-win agreement. No! Today, the EU's trade deficit with Vietnam is $30 billion. In the Commission's impact study, we are told that within 10 years it will be $40 billion. And who's going to pay? Undoubtedly, a number of European employees in the most vulnerable sectors, for example textiles. So, to make Vietnam a kind of great workshop of the world, the risk is still relocations.  We are told that Vietnamese employees will benefit because they will adopt ILO standards, but finally, we have examples! Look at South Korea: we were made promises that were never kept.  So I think you are either very naïve or true hypocrisy, hypocrisy about human rights, because frankly, we cannot say today that the Vietnamese government has met our expectations. The opposite is true: in the latest press freedom ranking, Vietnam ranks 176th out of 180 countries in the world.  But above all, I refer the Commission to this incredible double language: we vote on the climate emergency, we vote on the European Green Pact and at the same time we pass, business as usual, a free trade agreement that is clearly climate-friendly and does not protect sustainable development. Frankly, it gives the impression of a European Union that always prefers trade to fundamental values that should normally animate us all in this Chamber.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, three years ago, in voting for my resolution on the Trade Strategy for the European Union, Parliament was loudly calling for agreements with countries with a high rate of growth. And he was listened to! Vietnam is the new Asian tiger: with GDP increasing by 7 % a year, it is a country that is becoming faster and is therefore increasing its demand for high value-added goods, precisely the goods that we produce here in Europe. The agreement will bring almost all customs duties on these and other products to zero. Some of these duties, such as those on wines and cheeses, for example, now reach up to 50 %, not to mention those of cars up to 80 %. This agreement will then protect 169 PDO, DOC and PGI, 38 of which, 22 %, are Italian. So, if I think of my own country, for example, trade is only increasing. Our exports increased by 12 % last year, pushing import-exports to 3.7 billion and making Vietnam our main trading partner for the ASEAN countries. That's a number that's going to get even better thanks to the deal. The demand for Italian products is very high: over 300 million euros for our fashion export, over 65 for food and almost half a billion for machinery. Ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that the agreement from a strictly commercial point of view is beneficial, and therefore deserves our vote in favour, but there is a problem. The human rights situation in Vietnam does not seem to be making any progress and some improvement reforms in this respect are still being approved. Personally, I am sure, like other Members, that the agreement will bring prosperity, help to change the situation in the future, and that is why, if there is a vote tomorrow, we will approve it. But I would ask you colleagues to postpone the vote. I would ask that we allow our Vietnamese friends time to complete the democratic reforms that we have asked of them, and show us a little more goodwill. I would also like Vietnam to release political prisoners and prisoners of conscience, to approve the fundamental conventions on workers' rights. Ladies and gentlemen, Vietnam is a friendly country. There is no doubt that the agreement will come into force sooner or later, but it is precisely friends who must be asked for more.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Madam President, the U.S. government says that the rule of the strongest would be the guiding principle of 21st century business models. Tomorrow, ladies and gentlemen, we will have a historic chance to prove them wrong, showing the world that our commitment to fair trade based on clear rules, regardless of the size of the partner, remains the golden rule to follow.  Yes, Vietnam is a developing country and of course the process of economic, environmental and above all social modernization is far from complete. However, ratification of this agreement does not, as President Bernd Lange rightly pointed out, amount to ending the conversation, it does not amount to turning a blind eye to the human rights situation in Vietnam, and certainly not to give a blank cheque to the Vietnamese government. In fact, our President Sassoli is meeting with the Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bùi Thanh Son, today here in the European Parliament.  Forty-five years after the end of the Vietnam War and thirty years after the opening of our diplomatic relations, the approval that I support and which is just waiting to be pronounced will allow us to intensify the dialogue with our Vietnamese counterparts, this time relying on real and credible levers and platforms. The joint committee claimed and obtained by this Parliament will allow us to lobby for socio-economic change and the improvement of the lives of all Vietnamese.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are undoubtedly advantages that this agreement can bring both to the European economy and to the Italian economy, to Italian exports, and certainly also to that country, in order to make a leap forward in their development as well. We are well aware of this and consider it an important factor.  However, we cannot hide. The situation is still very critical and remains in that country. Criticism from the point of view of human rights in general, as far as trade union rights are concerned, with regard to political freedoms and prisoners. I continue to emphasise this, and I am surprised that there is also no attention from the Commission – Commissioner, can I have your attention? Can I get your attention? I am addressing the Commission! Well, we will write – to ask for something consistent, including with regard to development cooperation. I would like to highlight the issue of forced child labour and the work of women under unacceptable conditions.  It's not just Vietnam's fault. It is the global value chain that leads some countries to be subcontractors to the lowest decline. We must rebel against this. I do not know then, certainly progress has been made, and I say this with pride on behalf of those in my group who have dealt with and achieved a great many things. But perhaps we still need to ask for more for the work of people, women and children. So we're going to have to monitor this deal very closely. This will be the seriousness of the Commission and, in particular, of those involved in international cooperation.

name: Svenja HAHN
text: – Madam President, let’s be clear: Vietnam is a communist country. It’s not a democracy, and a trade agreement won’t make it one overnight. But the agreement will boost economic development. It will lift people out of poverty and give them more rights and protection. The new Labour Code especially protects vulnerable groups. Unions will be allowed and freedom of assembly will follow. Increased transparency and international observation bear huge potential for better protection of human rights.  We are already trading with Vietnam. This is not about if we want trade or not. This is about improving the circumstances. So let’s send a strong signal of cooperation to the whole ASEAN region, to reformist forces that believe in cooperation with the European Union, and let’s not give room to actors that don’t want to combine trade and values, like China. Let’s support the agreement and let’s support the people of Vietnam in their development.

name: Herve JUVIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we will not vote for a treaty which we believe is not good for the European Union, that it is not good for France and that it is not good for Vietnam. For years, we have denounced the ecological aberration of supply chains that go around the world three times. For years, we have highlighted the dangers of strategic dependence on sources of supply thousands of kilometres away where, despite our good intentions, we have no real control. And for years, we have also denounced the interference in the internal affairs of sovereign countries that are all too often the subject of free trade treaties. That is why we will not sign this treaty, because we believe that the 21st century is turning the page on free trade and globalization. We believe that the 21st century will be one of relocations, of the pursuit of industrial autonomy of nations, aware of the demands of their independence. Above all, we consider the 21st century to be the century of economic patriotism. We hope that Viet Nam, like the European Union, will work on its independence and strategic freedoms.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: – Madam President, this Parliament decided in November that the Paris Agreement should be anchored in all chapters of our trade agreements, and this Parliament decided in December that all our trade agreements would have enforceable environmental and social standards. Also, this Parliament considers itself to be at the forefront of human rights, and yet the majority of this House is ready to vote ‘yes’ on the trade and investment deal with Vietnam, in a situation where human rights are deteriorating in Vietnam and the numbers of political prisoners has been on the rise since 2016; in a situation where civic and political rights are systematically being cracked down; and in a situation where the deal on the table still does not contain enforceable social and environmental standards – and not only the Social Democrats in this House always pretended that this was a red line. I understood that there is a majority in this Parliament to make trade more sustainable and climate-proof, which is good. But dear colleagues, we really make a fool of ourselves if we then, at the first best opportunity, give in and let a trade deal pass that does not live up to the Green Deal. I urge you today: say no to this deal. Let’s ask the Commission to renegotiate and to align the Vietnam deal with the Green Deal. And let’s send a strong signal to the Vietnamese Government to improve the devastating human rights situation before we sign the deal and not after.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, we just heard it this morning. Overall, the Trade Agreement with Vietnam benefits several sectors of the European Union and, in the agri-food field, meat or wine or cheese may be several of them. However, it is regrettable, once again, that the European Commission will give up protecting one of its sensitive sectors, such as rice. Vietnam has the lowest rice prices in all of Southeast Asia and competes directly with varieties produced in Spain and Italy. Spanish arroceros are outraged at this new concession and its impact on the prices of an already crisis sector. Being in deficit in rice production does not mean that opening borders does not cause irreparable damage to European production. I cannot understand why, after applying the safeguard clause in early 2019 with Myanmar and Cambodia, the European Union continues to make the same mistakes and does not appreciate the impact these imports will have on the European market and on a sensitive product such as rice.  The European rice sector plays a key role both in the economy and in the conservation of geographical areas with high environmental value. We call on the authorities of the European Union to carry out studies of this impact and to take the necessary steps to implement new and more effective safeguard clauses.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, there are many reasons to reject this agreement. It should only be said that this contract, i.e. contracts since we have a unified discussion, is written in such a way that it is adapted to the interest of corporations.  I'll give you three things. First thing, the contract grants special rights to the investor, therefore it isds, i.e. the state dispute settlement mechanism, it is that when there is a dispute there is no jurisdiction of the domestic court, but some distant international arbitral tribunal there.  There are many tragic examples here in Europe on the people of Europe where such a mechanism proved harmful, I will state only from the Abruzzo region where it was refused, therefore, the extension of the concession on the exploitation of hydrocarbons and then the oil corporations sued the region. Or let's say with us in Dubrovnik where the investor in the case of golf on Srdj lost in croatian courts. That wasn't enough for him, so he started an arbitration dispute for $500 million.  This mechanism simply undermines its own institutions, as they are, and the sovereignty of countries and so will Vietnam. Imagine one big conflict between a municipality in Croatia of a few thousand inhabitants and a ten million kuna budget against some mega corporation in billions. Just imagine how it could be in Vietnam.  There's no question here about the green deal that the Commission swears so much into. Also, just as human and fundamental rights are violated, say in Croatia, which the Commission ignores, Croatia is a member, imagine what is yet to happen in Vietnam. We in Croatia know well what it looks like, that's where the real environment gets hurt, only the rich establishment.

name: Jörgen WARBORN
text: Madam President, Commissioner Hogan, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent Vietnam, after Singapore, is the EU's most important trading partner in South-East Asia. With the agreement, we are removing almost all tariffs and giving European companies access to a market of almost one hundred million consumers, a rapidly growing middle class and increased purchasing power.  This means great opportunities for the approximately 600 companies from Malmö in the south to Vilhelmina in the north that export there, but also a great potential for all those who import from Vietnam. My hope is that it will be even easier for companies to start trading with this large market.  I travelled with the European Parliament delegation to Vietnam last autumn. Everyone we met – from party-loyal ministers to human rights activists, business, humanitarian organisations and the International Labour Organisation – all called on us to ratify this agreement.  EU exports to Vietnam are expected to increase by 16%. This is good for Swedish companies and European competitiveness. It's good for growth, it's good for jobs. It's good for business. That is why I will vote in favour of these agreements.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have declared a climate emergency, we voted for the Green Pact just a month ago and tomorrow we are being asked what? We are being asked to vote on one more free trade agreement, as if nothing had happened. This agreement, contrary to our promises written in black and white in the resolution on the European Green Pact, does not include any binding mechanism for the sustainable development chapter. So the question before us is simple: do we give any price to our words, to our own words? Colleagues, Vietnam is locking up environmental activists, trade unionists and human rights defenders. One of them, Pham Chi Dung, was arrested precisely because he wrote us a letter asking us not to sign the agreement as it stands. If you do not give any price to your own words, have the decency to give value to his words to him. Don't validate the agreement while he's in jail for talking to us. Colleagues, there is something above the god Commerce. There is our future for all, there are our principles. Well tomorrow is an opportunity to demonstrate it.

name: Marie-Pierre VEDRENNE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Vietnam is our second largest economic partner in South-East Asia and the European Union expects many benefits from this trade agreement. Yes, this agreement will protect 169 geographical indications, including 36 French PDOs. Our companies will be able to export many products without tariffs. We will have better access to public procurement. So many offensive points obtained in these negotiations. But the human rights situation remains a concern. Many political prisoners and journalists remain in detention, despite repeated calls for the release of the European Union. If progress has been made with the ratifications of international conventions, we must be uncompromising on respect for the chapter on sustainable development. Our trade policy must be guided by our values and respect for human rights, but ratification of this agreement, ladies and gentlemen, is not an end in itself. The key to success will be the success of its implementation, all in an international context synonymous with trade war.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her To be clear, I will vote in favour of this agreement. I am, in principle, a supporter of free trade. Free trade has always proved to be profitable for both sides and also a growth engine. This is also particularly true of the links between Europe and East Asia. Vietnam is also a particularly dynamic country in a very dynamic environment. Vietnam's economic growth has been consistently above 5% since the 1990s, and infrastructure and legal certainty have also been greatly expanded in recent years. And Vietnam is also particularly interesting as an export country for Europe. As positive as all this sounds, I do not want to hide the negative aspects of Vietnam: critical journalists, religious minorities, human rights defenders are oppressed by the socialist regime, driven out of the country or die in unexplained circumstances. It is therefore to be hoped that this free trade agreement will also help to improve the human rights situation in Vietnam.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what have we not heard during the European election campaign, all over Europe? Free trade agreements that give rights to multinationals against states, against environmental legislation, against health protection laws or social rights were over. These free trade agreements that contribute to climate change, especially through deforestation, were over. This was the end of free trade agreements that attack biodiversity, for example through illegal fishing. These free trade agreements that were contrary to democracy and individual freedoms were over. And then the first agreement arrives and all these groups, the Social Democrats, Bernd Lange, the Liberals and En Marche, the Conservatives: you will all vote on a free trade agreement contrary to the statements and commitments of the European Commission on the Green Pact, on the values of Europe and on a regulated globalisation. As luck would have it, we have this debate after a debate on Brexit. But did you not also understand that Brexit was voted because we are abandoning the working classes here to exploit them in abominable conditions without freedom, without social rights, on the other side of the planet? So, ladies and gentlemen, a little decency towards the Vietnamese, a little decency towards your constituents. Reject this free trade agreement which is in no way compatible with the values of Europe.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President, although Vietnam is not a democratic country, I support the Treaty with it for the following reasons: in 2009 Vietnam was the 32nd largest importer from eu countries, to EU countries, and in 2008 it was already in 10th place. This change has taken place and will take place with or without a contract. The difference is that, if the treaty is to take place, there will be a dramatic increase in the chances of more democracy being pushed through vietnam thanks to the Treaty. With Britain leaving the EU, there has been a growing risk of a shrinking of the business space, hence the potential for economic growth. Moreover, the EU remains free to impose sanctions or even withdraw from the Treaty if democracy in Vietnam does not improve. I believe that, ten years after the signing of these treaties, Vietnam will be much more democratic and closer to the market economy than it is today. It will be richer, there will be fewer poor, the market economy will prevail and human rights will be better protected, as will the environment.

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, I will support the agreement concluded with the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, which is why, on 5.2.2020, I attended a conference in Brussels with the participation of the representatives of Bangladesh. Among other things, the director of the Bangladeshi Association of Clothing Manufacturers and Exporters said: "By adopting agreements between the European Union and Vietnam, Bangladesh would lose 13 billion barrel exports of textiles to the US." It is clear to all of us that the European Union is the largest clothing importer from Bangladesh. If Vietnam, as Bangladesh's main competitor, receives zero import duties into the EU, Bangladesh's market share will be significantly reduced. I believe that opponents of the EU-Vietnam agreements are not affected by major cooperation in the garment industry. We all know what working conditions, including for minor children, in the manufacture of the clothes we wear are in Bangladesh. And one more thing, I am one of the few MEPs who remembers the Vietnam War. He remembers the village of My Lai, he remembers Dien Bien Phu, we owe it to Vietnam, the heroic people of Vietnam, to conclude this agreement. By not making this agreement, we would bomb the Vietnamese people again. That's all.

name: Sven SIMON
text: – Madam President, this trade agreement between the EU and Vietnam is proof that we can establish European standards in the world through trade agreements. A significant improvement in workers’ rights; a ban on forced labour; the approval of independent unions; an enforcement mechanism for the Paris Agreement, which we wouldn’t have without the agreement. What a great success. Colleagues from the Greens and the left are generally against trade agreements. They share this in common with the right-wing populists, by the way.  The question you have to answer is now: how do you want to implement European standards worldwide? Through speeches in this House? Demonstrations? Letters?  The only realistic way to promote European influence globally in an age of shifting geopolitical distribution of power is through trade agreements. Those who vote against it will have to explain how they want to realistically achieve our common goals while, at the same time, following an agenda which is isolating and disabling the European Union as a trading partner.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the figures tell us that in 2018 trade in goods between the European Union and Vietnam amounted to around EUR 40 million. This means that Vietnam is already an important trading partner and that every day our citizens use "made in Vietnam" products.  This agreement can improve trade and political relations with a strategic partner in a very important area such as South-East Asia, placing these relations in a system of certain and shared rules. Vietnam has, in recent years, embarked on a path of significant reforms, especially on labour law, the progress of which has been certified by the World Labour Organisation. Of course, this is only a starting point and we should demand, both on this and on respect for human rights and freedom of expression, concrete facts and actions on the part of the Vietnamese authorities.  In this respect, the trade agreement is an important lever in the hands of the European Union to encourage and call on Vietnam to honour its solemn commitments.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, Mr Commissioner, this will be the first major trade agreement that this new Parliament will ratify, and it will send several positive messages. Firstly, to an ever more protectionist world, that the EU still believes in rule-based free trade. Secondly, to the region, bringing us one a step closer to a regional ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) agreement. Thirdly, to our citizens and businesses, that we are dedicated to expanding better conditions for business to thrive, grow and generate more jobs. And finally, it is proved that trade can positively influence other areas. The negotiations helped push Vietnam towards important labour reforms. By having this framework in place, we will now have a way to constructively engage on topics ranging from human rights to the environment and, as with any agreement, implementation will be the key. And you can count on this Parliament to do our job.

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the right words must be used to comment on what the European Commission says. Lie: no local development, it will not create development for Vietnamese companies, it will only serve to encourage the relocation of European companies and large multinationals to a country like Vietnam. Another blow, moreover, to the Italian and European rice sector in general. Shame! Shame, because – as many people have said – human rights are certainly not respected in Vietnam, social standards are very low. Yet another trade agreement that will promote downward wage competition, and our workers are well aware of this.  Hypocrisy! Hypocrisy because the Green New Deal that you want to impose on our companies and that will cost them a great deal, obviously cannot be imposed on Vietnam and Vietnam will be careful not to go in that direction, moreover with standards that you perhaps claim to ask The United Kingdom, which already respects, and instead does not make any problem, in your failed trade policy, to make agreements with countries very far from any level of social and environmental protection.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Madam President, agreements between the EU and Vietnam are undoubtedly important geopolitically, and Vietnam has also made progress in reforming its labour laws – but it has, on the other hand, failed to amend its penal code to allow workers to enjoy those rights. Oppression has become more severe even during the last stage of the finalisation of these agreements. Parliament, if giving its consent tomorrow, takes a heavy responsibility of making its own demands happen in reality on sustainable development, human rights and participation of an independent civil society, and, as our own Committee on Foreign Affairs demands, the Commission and its Vietnamese counterparts still must set up an independent monitoring mechanism on human rights and an independent complaints mechanism with the recourse to remedy. So this all is why our Group, the Greens/European Free Alliance, cannot yet support these agreements.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Both the FtA and the Investment Protection Agreement (IPA) are indeed the most ambitious agreements of its kind ever concluded with a developing country. In negotiating them, the Commission sought to achieve two main objectives: firstly, to provide the best possible conditions for Eu economic operators to access the Vietnamese market; secondly, provide a valuable second reference point (after the Singapore Agreement) for other Union-led negotiations in the region. Both of these objectives have been fully achieved. The agreements go beyond existing WTO commitments in many areas, such as services, procurement, non-tariff barriers and the protection of intellectual property rights, including geographical indications. In all these areas, Vietnam has also agreed to accept new commitments that go far beyond what it has committed itself to in other agreements, including the comprehensive and progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement. The agreements will remove almost all customs restrictions on mutual trade. They are well balanced and will have a positive impact on the economy of both the Union and Vietnam. Through these agreements, the Union will have greater opportunities to put pressure on Hanoi on human rights issues. I therefore call for a vote in favour of the ratification of these documents.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I see the extremes are clashing in this House today. I suggest to the detractors that we consider what our priority is. Our job is to create opportunities for European companies, and our citizens will benefit from that. More trade is also a chance for the citizens of Vietnam to develop and to achieve their freedom by following our standards. There is a role-playing role for those who believe that the Union must constantly educate and lecture, rather than approaching partners with little respect and seeking good relations. Dialogue and monitoring of commitments will contribute to Vietnam's human rights, labour and environmental development, not turn our backs. Anyone who argues against the two conventions does not want European companies to have access to the public procurement market in Hanoi or Ho Chi Minh City. Dear detractors, do not want to harm European companies and Vietnamese. I ask the Commission to provide up-to-date, practical information so that European SMEs can make the most of the two conventions.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Madam President, Mr Hogan, the agreement between the European Union and Vietnam is of great strategic importance because of the momentum it gives to our trade relations with the ASEAN region and by Vietnam's strong commitment to multilateralism and sustainable development when the world needs it most. Ambitious tariff reduction, enhanced cooperation and, above all, a binding chapter on sustainable development have been negotiated that defines a framework for industrial relations with Vietnam more in line with ILO principles and conventions. The European Parliament, thanks to the push of my parliamentary group and also other groups, has achieved strong measures and commitments from the Vietnamese Government on labour rights and respect for human rights, specified in work programmes. And I want to thank the Vietnam authorities for their efforts. But much remains to be done and we Socialists are still concerned about the human rights situation, especially with respect to fundamental freedoms. That is why we will closely follow the agreed implementation and ask you, Commissioner, to also take appropriate measures to ensure that this agreement does not harm European farmers and, in particular, rice producers. But I believe that this agreement is an important tool for moving forward and I will support it.

name: Pierre KARLESKIND
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to join our colleague Bartolo, who was rapporteur for the PECH committee, on the need to combat illegal fishing. Fighting illegal fishing, of course, means ensuring sustainable management of fisheries resources, it is also ensuring that we avoid unfair competition with fishermen who are subject to the constraints we have on our continent. Vietnam has a yellow card on illegal fishing, but it is worth noting the efforts that have been made by Vietnam, particularly in the negotiations that are now leading to this free trade agreement. It should also be noted that in this agreement it is explicitly stated that the parties that sign the agreement will actively fight against this illegal fishing. So is that enough? Well, if that's not enough, let's go further. Let us go further and put in place safeguards, such as the abolition of preferential tariffs for fish products as long as, in the future, there will be a yellow card. That is the meaning of the amendment that Renew tabled and which I invite you to support.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Trade basically benefits both sides. As a permanent rapporteur for Bangladesh and other countries, I know how developing countries look to Vietnam, because for the first time an emerging country is given the opportunity to connect and develop with the European economy through an individual free trade agreement. It is precisely because this agreement is important because it offers the many emerging countries an opportunity and a path that we should give them. That is why I am seeking your approval. The free trade agreement is balanced, it reflects the different views here in this House on trade with other countries, and it makes all emerging countries a separate European offer for further development, so that there is prosperity at home and not that these people have to seek their happiness elsewhere and in other countries. In this respect, a good, balanced agreement that casts a positive light on Europe and trade. I ask for your assent.

name: Markéta GREGOROVÁ
text: – Madam President, free trade generally creates wealth for both sides. So how, as a pro-European politician, can I oppose the ratification of the current EU-Vietnam agreement? Because we're going to give the authoritarian regime a blank cheque for trade with the world's largest economic bloc without enforceable conditions. By ratifying the treaties, we will today tell the Communist Party of Vietnam that the EU supports a surveillance state with a one-party monopoly that oppresses its people. Make no mistake about the so-called guarantees of human rights and democratic reforms. In eight years of negotiating this agreement, the situation in Vietnam has deteriorated. It's not just human rights if they're not enough. Throwing away a strong negotiating position is also a mistake for the trade itself. Vietnam will make considerably more money from the agreement than the EU, and at that point we should want guarantees for our politics and business. The question is: do we really want a Europe that the authoritarians of all countries can move as they need without having to loosen their regimes?
