Moreover, it does not believe that, after extraordinary operations such as QE, which have increased the budget of the European Central Bank to more than 4.65 trillion euros by blowing up the M3 money supply without however either reaching, if not marginally, the real economy or the inflation target, obtaining a state of permanent deflation, the time has come to consider strategies from "Helicopter money" to revive consumption , given the catastrophic industrial production figures recorded in the eurozone?

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Madame Lagarde. Last week in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), you said that more attention should be given to the cost of housing and home ownership when it comes to the European Central Bank (ECB) inflation measure.  I want to welcome those comments. We just had an election in Ireland where the cost of housing was one of the main issues that dominated voters’ intentions. Serious advances have been made to address the problems but in Dublin, for example, rental prices have doubled since 2010 and property prices have gone up 85% since 2013. I think one should be putting more focus on the fact that house prices and rent rises are increasing rapidly across Europe and I think that we need to have more diverse financial instruments to deal with this. It goes back to a very important remark that you made yourself before you were appointed President of the ECB. You said the ECB needs to understand and explain to people not only the markets.  I think if we are to rebuild trust with citizens, I think your consultation project in the Member States is very important. I see that as really democracy building, very important, but I think the housing issue is crucial because if we want to keep in touch with our citizens, we need to understand properly and account for the serious issues that they face in society. I think that we really need to look at this. It’s an emerging serious social and economic issue across many, many Member States and I think it’s one where you and the ECB could have a very crucial role to play in terms of leadership and understanding and looking at alternative solutions.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, congratulations to my friend Costas Mavrides on an excellent report. I would also like to focus on an area which merits greater attention in my view, but from a different perspective to what has been done up to now, namely the situation of banks, big and small, in the eurozone. We are underestimating how difficult the situation has become. Discussion of the subject is constrained because many would not like it to sound as an attack on the ECB’s monetary easing policies. True. So long as fiscal policy is not being deployed to bolster economic growth, such policies remain essential, and I agree with that. But, they’re also causing collateral damage to banks. Other very significant factors are adding to the damage, like an overload of regulations raising operational costs. Yet, while the Capital Markets Union is being promoted in Europe, the reliance on banks for business financing has grown. Banks are curtailing their services to cut costs and to remain profitable, with negative economic and social consequences. It is illusory to hope that this will lead to the emergence of European champions in the banking sector. If eurozone banks retract their capillary outreach in national economies, citizens and SMEs – but not only they – will suffer.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This report is, to say the least, a mockery of the European Parliament. This report is a prime example of fine-colouredness on the one hand and cover-up on the other. The slight economic growth in the eurozone is presented as a result of the fatal low interest rate policy, although there is no evidence of this at all. The huge losses that eurozone savers are suffering – not a word in this report. The ever-increasing risks that institutional investors, such as pension funds, have to take – not in this report. The overheating of financial markets by loose monetary policy – not in this report. The rise in social inequality caused by monetary policy – not a word about it in this report. The sprawling sovereign debt in the eurozone caused by monetary policy – not a word in this report. This report reminds me of the reports in the Communist Eastern Bloc. It always contained only what the party leadership wanted, and what that led to, we all know full well.

name: Aurore LALUCQ
text: Mr President, I thank Mrs Lagarde for being with us. You have chosen, Madam, to pursue a monetary policy called quantitative easing to support economic activity, and many of us in this house have received this announcement with some relief because, because of the national selfishness and the prevailing ideology on this continent, we unfortunately still do not have a real budget, which is absolutely incredible and inconceivable for the world's leading economic power. But this situation means that a lot rests on your shoulders and your policy must be perfect. We have heard a great deal of progress in your speech, but there is still one point missing, which is speculation. On this point, I remain hungry. We know that quantitative easing policies in recent years have certainly supported the real economy, but they have also led to an increase in the financial sphere, and I would like to know what the European Central Bank intends to do in practice to combat speculation.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Ms Lagarde. A fresh wind is blowing through the ECB. No public spats, but a constructive dialogue: how can we prop up eurozone growth? How can the ECB stop funding polluting activities? How can we promote gender equality among ECB decision-makers? And of course, every new job starts with credit, and the trick is: don’t waste it. That is why, Ms Lagarde, I call upon you to make real progress now that you can. The ECB needs to get in gear to implement the EU taxonomy and avoid activities that do ‘significant harm’. Besides, you should encourage governments to invest substantially in sustainability, reaping the benefits of the low interest rate and pushing that rate upwards, and in that way restore the full potential of monetary policy. Continue confidently along this path, Ms Lagarde, and I have no doubt that the male central bankers will dance to your tune.

name: Agnès EVREN
text: Mr President, Madam President, Commissioner, the annual report on the European Central Bank 2018, which we will vote on tomorrow in plenary, will be the first document we will send to you on behalf of the European Parliament. I hope that these recommendations will serve as the basis for a frequent dialogue with our Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. In this report, we discuss in particular the challenges facing our economies, and therefore the European Central Bank, in the years to come. In January, at the World Economic Forum in Davos, you mentioned the need to strengthen cyber resilience in Europe. In the top 5 global risks for 2020, a large-scale cyber attack would have considerable consequences for the European economy. It is therefore more urgent than ever to renew the architecture of European and international cooperation in this area. We need to develop common strategies and make coordinated efforts to address the risks created by digital transformation. Acceptance of the risks we face is a first step, but the next step must be action. We must ensure the resilience of financial market infrastructures and promote cooperation in this area between euro area banks. I know, Mrs Lagarde, that I can count on your firmness and your involvement to meet this challenge.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Mavrides and those who have worked with him on his very good report, and to wish Mrs Lagarde an extremely important speech — even more important than those of Mr Draghi — along the way. I would like to add two questions — to a bombardment of questions, of course.  The first has to do with the Greek banking system. We know that since 2018 his situation has become better, but I would like if he can briefly tell us two things, namely in which direction we should move and how quickly. There is a second issue, which is of wider interest and raised by colleagues who preceded it. It is clear that in order to go to the green transition we need additional investment and, as Draghi said in 2018 and more generally, we need to improve the composition of public spending in order to make it more qualitative and — if possible — investment. I would therefore also like a comment from Mrs Lagarde.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: Mr President, congratulations Mavrides on your report, thank you, Mrs Lagarde. We all know that we need significant progress in the banking union and capital markets. To date, this progress has been slow and very limited. The third pillar of the Banking Union is far from finalised. A strengthened role of the euro needs, first of all, political will. Economic and monetary union must be completed as a budgetary instrument capable of responding to exogenous and safe asset shocks. The ECB needs to play a key role in this debate, as it needs to play a key role in combating climate change. The ECB has to work with the other European institutions and their peers to strengthen the role of the euro as a reserve currency, particularly in the international for a where it is present.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, just to say at the outset, Madame Lagarde, I want to raise the issue of the Stability and Growth Pact and the restrictive practice that it has on European economies and their ability to invest in both the Green Deal, but in just normal fiscal stimulus that is required to stimulate the broader economies of the European Union. And I think in that context, the EU Commission is carrying out a review of the Stability and Growth Pact in the near future, and I’m wondering whether or not the ECB will have an official role in observing that particular review and having input into that particular review. Because we have to accept that if we want to create a dynamic European economy, I believe that the Stability and Growth Pact is too restrictive on the ability of governments to invest in the economic aspects of economies across the eurozone. Finally, I would ask that you would also look at Irish banks and the interest rates that they are charging for mortgages and small and medium-sized businesses. Bearing in mind we’re in the eurozone and our banks are charging two to three times the interest rates that the rest of Europe pays in mortgages and lending to small and medium-sized businesses.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, as has been acknowledged here, the prolonged unconventional monetary policy measures alone have not been sufficient to halt the pronounced economic slowdown, and they tend to exhaust their scope. We do not know when the next peak of the crisis will come, but we know that you will find the economies on the periphery of the eurozone as unprotected as it was a decade ago. With a high indebtedness, it itself has a consequence of the single currency, and exhausted the scope of unconventional measures will be exposed, more exposed, all their vulnerability, the vulnerability of these countries, trapped in the trap of the euro, a trap that imposes policies, particularly in the budgetary plan, which slows growth, crushes investment and wages, degrades the productive system and public services. Those who say that a growth-friendly fiscal policy is necessary to enforce the stubborn fulfilment of a revised and strengthened stability pact. Here's the euro trap. They say you have to go deeper. What is needed, however, is to take it apart.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the road to a stronger economic and monetary union is full of unresolved issues. Issues that require efforts on the part of all for their solution. After some tentative progress during the crisis, the pace of reform has slowed down completely. Some projects, although among the least controversial, have been implemented, but a key proposal to complete the banking union such as the European Universal Deposit Insurance System still struggles to move forward. Given the eurozone's persistent vulnerability and the completion of EDIS, a key piece to ensure savers with increased risk reduction measures, they remain a necessity for the Union. Moving forward with EDIS, we could reduce financial fragmentation by ensuring a wider role for private capital in cushioning economic and financial shocks. But I would like to reiterate this: to insist only on risk reduction as a precondition for the launch of EDIS is wrong. We cannot try to reduce risk by weighing up, for example, government bonds. That would be absurd. We will leave a more fragile European financial system under the influence of quotas. We must act now, the price to be paid would be terrible to remain immobile.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, first of all, it is good to see Madame Lagarde here. I congratulate her on her appointment. And, indeed, herself and her predecessor Mr Draghi are to be congratulated on keeping the euro afloat and keeping the European economy in a stable position. Having said that, I want to ask one question in particular. We have had an election in Ireland and one of the big issues there was in relation to housing. Mr Kelleher referred to the interest rates, but not only the interest rates, but also the rules of borrowing. We have a situation now where people who are well educated, with very good jobs, cannot afford to buy a house. There are other issues in relation to the supply of housing, but even where the supply is available, this is causing a huge concern for them. And many people are now living with their parents because, while having been well educated, as I said, good jobs, well paid, they cannot afford to buy a house because of the rules implemented by our banks. Can she offer some leeway in that regard and some hope to those people that what was the norm in the past can apply in the future – you have a good job, you can buy a house?

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Mr President, Madam Lagarde, Vice-President Dombrovskis, I would first like to transfer my support to the report prepared by Costas Mavrides of the Socialist Group. I think it's very complete and contains the essentials. Perhaps an additional element, in line with what the Socialist Group's spokesman, Mr Fernández, has also pointed out is the consideration of new instruments. I think it is clear that, only with the ultra-low rates and with the purchasing programme, it will be difficult to achieve the goal. It is true that fiscal support is needed, but the European Central Bank's inflation target is unconditional; must tend, it must fulfil its mandate, unconditionally. Perhaps this instrument, in its view, could be a direct transfer to eurozone households to boost consumption and therefore achieve the target closely but below 2%.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate has demonstrated that there is a large convergence of views on most aspects of the report and I’m very pleased to see the common ground emerging from the views of the three institutions. Let me conclude by mentioning the point directly concerning the Commission. Your last report encouraged the Commission and the ECB to study schemes such as a central bank digital currency and digital base money and to liaise closely. Like many central banks and institutions, the Commission and the ECB are now analysing the potential benefits and challenges associated with these schemes. Further work is needed, but these examples show that the three institutions – and this includes the European Parliament – can fruitfully interact in respect of their respective roles. So we count on your continued support in building the foundations for sustainable growth in Europe.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I would now like to ask the President of the European Central Bank, Mrs Lagarde, and at the same time thank her for the nice reception of the members of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs yesterday in France and the very open and constructive debate.

name: Christine Lagarde
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Mr President, I didn’t know that you had to be standing to address this Assembly, so I offer my apologies for not having done so in the first place and therefore I will align with the rule that you seem to have amongst you. I would like to first of all thank you very much for this dialogue that we had. It’s very much part of what we at the European Central Bank, and more broadly within the euro system, want to actually have with public opinions, with civil society representatives, but more importantly, with those who represent the citizens of Europe: that is you, Members of Parliament, who have been elected by them. This is very much part of the accountability that we have towards you and, through you, to the citizens of Europe. We have conducted a few changes in the last few months, but certainly one of those that I very much look forward to implementing as we go into the strategy review that has been approved last month, is the constant dialogue that we need to have, and what we have called the outreach with you and, through you, with the citizens of Europe. So thank you for that. I thought I would just touch on some items of our strategy review to address some of the points that you have made. First of all, some of you have touched on the monetary policy and the current components of the instruments that we use in order to implement our policy and have been doing so since 2014. To those who argue that this monetary policy, and particularly its unconventional tools, have been counterproductive, I would very strongly encourage them to look at the impact that those unconventional tools have had on the economy – in which way it has actually increased growth and helped our economies around Europe and the euro area in particular to fare better than it would have had it not been for those instruments that were used as part of the unconventional policy. It’s obviously very difficult to quantify carefully and precisely by how much growth has been lifted in the euro area, but our models actually indicate that that growth has been probably higher by a margin of about 2.5% to 3% ever since those policies were put in place. In the same vein, it has contributed to inflation which, as you know, ever since the euro was put in place and ever since the strategy was revisited in 2003, is measured with reference to inflation, and clearly those unconventional tools that have been used since 2014 have helped inflation go up a bit. Well, certainly we would have liked it a lot more than that, and maybe this would have been the case if other tools had been used in conjunction with our monetary policy. But be it as it was, certainly inflation has increased by a factor of about half a percentage point probably, which is certainly not bad, given the level where we are. To those who were mentioning, by the way, that inflation was hovering around 1%, I would simply remind you that in January inflation was at about 1.3%, which is certainly not the goal that we have, but certainly a bit more than the 1% that was mentioned. Those unconventional tools that were used and the instruments that were deployed helped our economies and continue to help our economies. When you look at the volume and the number of new financing that are put in place for the real economy, whether it’s the corporate or whether it’s the households, we are seeing clearly financing that is very low in terms of cost, and I take the point that you made, sir, about the Irish banks and how much they charge and what interest rates they include, and we’ll look into that for sure. But the cost of financing has been low and lower for the real economy. And number two, the volume of financing of the economy has increased and has continued to increase. You will have seen some comments recently about the fact that this continuum is slowing down. Yes, it is a little bit – for the corporate, not for the households – but it is continuing to grow nonetheless. So I would contend that, in the main, it has had a very positive effect on our economies, and as part of our strategy review, we’ll look at how much and how effective it has been. But we will also look, as some of you have mentioned, to the potential side effects and to the accumulated side effects that it could have on citizens and on the economies as well. So that will be very much part and parcel of our review. The second point that I would like to emphasise briefly, and I’ve focused on the monetary policy tools and how we will look at them and measure them and measure the benefits as well as the negative effect, is climate change. Nobody can ask the European Central Bank to substitute what governments should do and what policies should be in general. As former managing director of the IMF, I think I’d be remiss not to remind all of us that one of the key tools in relation to climate change is clearly the proper pricing of carbon, and this is not something that a European Central Bank or any central bank in the world can actually decide. So as we go through our strategy review, we will determine where and how the issue of climate change and the fight against climate change can actually have an impact on our policies, whether it’s in relation to our price stability primary objective and how it impacts this primary objective, or whether it’s in relation to the management of risk that we are accountable to our European citizens and to you when we look at the composition of our portfolios and the one that we manage, and whether or not risks are actually properly priced and whether the climate change risks associated with some of the collateral that we have in our portfolios, for instance, are measured or not. So in that respect, climate change will be one of the items that we will take into account, together with the more traditional aspects that we will be measuring, and it’s in the context of that strategy review, Mr Vice-President, that we will continue this dialogue, not only with you, but also with the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON). The president of ECON was here and many members of the Committee are present in this room. We will continue to engage: we will have that dialogue, and we want that very much to be a two-way street. Now, I offer our apologies to those who had very specific questions on particular countries, but I propose to take that up bilaterally with those who are interested in specific countries or banks going forward.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I can only wish you all the best for your work personally and in the interests of the European Union and in the global interest.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I too will be brief. I’d like to note two points. Madame Lagarde, today you have seen that in the European Parliament we can have different views. And a thing about the past, about Mr Draghi. Mr Draghi might not have been perfect, but his legacy was that he was determined to save the eurozone, and in fact I would say that maybe he has also saved the European project. Some people cannot forgive him for that.  As far as today is concerned, though, you rightly said in your initial statement that we basically share the same view about challenges, and I would add that even Mr Dombrovskis and to some extent the Commission shares that same view.  That’s why I would add to that, though, that certain elements, just like what you noted before, are missing. I think that the major challenge for all of us is to deliver – to deliver to the European citizens and to improve their lives in certain specific ways – completion of the Banking Union, completion of the Capital Markets Union, and much more. Therefore it is up to you, Madame Lagarde, and we are going to support you in striving towards a real convergence of the economies. Thank you for being here today with us.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 12 February 2020.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statement on the breach of Council Decision (CFSP) 2017/2074 on restrictive measures in view of the situation in Venezuela – Illegal entry into the territory of an EU Member State by a person named on the sanctions list (2020/2564(RSP)).

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the current subject of debate concerns an alleged breach of European Union sanctions currently in force vis-à-vis Venezuela. These were put in place in 2017 as part of the European Union’s efforts to foster a credible and meaningful process that can lead to a peaceful, negotiated solution for the reinstatement of democracy and the rule of law in Venezuela. These measures include a travel ban and asset freeze regarding 25 individuals, among them the Vice-President of Venezuela, Delcy Eloína Rodríguez Gómez, included on this list having been designated by the European Union on 25 June 2018. A travel ban requires the European Union Member States to take the necessary measures to prevent the entry into, or transit through, their territories by the listed persons. As you know, there is a division of competences in the area of sanctions within the European Union. First of all, Member States are responsible in all cases for the implementation and verification of sanctions adopted by the European Union in their own jurisdictions. Member States, I repeat, are responsible in all cases for the implementation and verification of sanctions adopted by the European Union. Therefore, when the issue of a possible violation of sanctions arises, for example an assets freeze or, as here, a travel ban, it is for the Member States concerned to investigate and determine whether this has in fact been the case. With regard to the wider oversight of the implementation of sanctions, the Commission has an overall monitoring role concerning the uniform application of such measures in an area with these competences. For example, this is the case for asset freeze and sectoral measures, but it is not the case for travel bans or arms embargoes. We can discuss the political appropriateness for Member States to give this competence to the European Union, although this would require a treaty change. But the situation, for the time being, is clear. The Commission cannot initiate any infringement procedure regarding a possible travel ban violation. Travel bans are, in practice, only contained in Council decisions and they do not therefore fall under Union law. Consequently, the Commission does not play a role in monitoring the implementation and cannot initiate an infringement procedure. As High Representative, talking here from the side of the Council, I am also responsible for ensuring the consistent application of the common foreign and security policy, including sanctions adopted by Member States in Council. In this context, the European External Action Service, in consultation with the European Union, where competent, would be directly in touch with the European Union Member States regarding alleged violations in order to ensure that these sanctions are being applied in a homogenous way in all Member States.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Venezuela and Venezuelan politics have come to Spain with Iglesias and Monedero. It is not my words, but those of Pedro Sánchez, current president of the Government of Spain. He said them in 2016, and now we know that for him it was not a criticism, but a compliment. Today, Iglesias is the vice president of his government and Chavista politics soils the image of his government.  The Government of Sánchez has opened Europe's doors to chavismo, because a socialist minister, José Luis Abalos, met with dictator Maduro's vice-president, Delcy Rodríguez, on Spanish territory, on European soil, violating the sanctions regime imposed by the European Union on a totalitarian regime, which tramples on human rights.  Sanchez's government hasn't just breached. Sanchez's government is lying. Any new version about the encounter makes the old one a lie. It has lost all credibility and it must be the European institutions that investigate the truth.  Venezuelan is a sister town for Spanish. For the millions of Venezuelans trampled by the despot Maduro, for the millions of Venezuelans who have fled their country, we need to know the truth and that the sanctions regime be complied with.  The Spaniards and the rest of the Europeans, this Parliament, have always raised our voices in defence of Venezuela's freedom. We therefore call on the Council of the European Union to investigate what has happened, to help clarify the truth and never to repeat a scandal that shames Europe again.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Cristina MAESTRE MARTÍN DE ALMAGRO
text: "blue card" question. – Mr President, I would like to ask Mrs Montserrat if she sees it appropriate to use the European Parliament as a tool to attack the Government of Spain, even knowing that this House has no competence in what you are moving. If the answer is that it is appropriate, some political groups may be tempted to bring other matters of national interest, on which many citizens want to know, such as that for the first time two presidents of the Government, Aznar and Rajoy, have been called... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: "blue card" response. – As always, smokescreens. The campaign against Spain is what you do, opening Europe's doors to chavism. You know that, you have breached the sanctions regime. You have lied, explain why. You have lost all credibility and you want all Spaniards to lose all credibility behind you. We therefore ask you to be the ones who move away from populism and chavism and to really defend Europe, today, here.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Dolors, Jordi, in this debate nine of the ten speakers are Spanish. I ask the promoters of this initiative , besides the House is almost empty - : Do they still think that this is a European debate? Aren't they making a fool of themselves? Do you intend to continue to use this House to make unfair opposition to the Government of Spain? Ladies and gentlemen of the EPP, Citizens and Vox, you are irresponsible and unfair that are seriously damaging Spain's image in this Parliament. You have not thought for a minute in the Venezuelan people, that what you expect from us is support, dialogue, unity, and not division and confrontation. The Government of Spain has acted and acts as a recognized interlocutor by the Venezuelan Government and opposition to a political, democratic and negotiated solution leading to free and fair elections. And, at that point, at that time, the European Parliament will act by sending an electoral mission. Please learn to work in this house and don't make a fool of yourself. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Mick WALLACE
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I would like to put a question to the last speaker. He says that the European Union is doing the right thing by recognising Spain’s position here. I have no problem with Spain’s position on this, but I have had a big problem with Spain’s position on a lot of aspects in relation to Venezuela, and in particular to the Europeans’ attitude. Do you not agree that the recognition of Guaidó is an absolute embarrassment to anyone who has to occupy this Chamber and it is a disgrace on the part of the Member States of Europe that so many of them have recognised an unelected gobshite?

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: "blue card" response. – Mr President, briefly , I think I have already said this – the Socialist Government of Spain is coherent. What we want is to find a solution with all Venezuelans. The difference is that we seek dialogue and not confrontation and division. Solutions can only be found—because the people of Venezuela are suffering—if we unsote Venezuelans and do not divide them, and that is why the Government of Spain is doing everything it can to find a solution , as I said – negotiated, agreed, democratic, and that allows it to... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Moreno Sanchez.  Mr Wallace: I call you to order for the use of the term 'dirty guy'.

name: Jordi CAÑAS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, it will be difficult to fly over the socialist mud, but I will try. I, Mr Borrell, would have liked you to have acted as a senior representative and not as a former foreign minister for Mr Sanchez's government. And I'll explain why. Because this is not a national debate. This is a debate on the legitimacy, credibility of European foreign policy and respect for this House. I don't know how they respect this House by bringing this chapapote here. Honestly, I'm terribly sorry, I'm terribly sorry. Because respect for this House means respecting what drives. And this House, for example, has asked to redouble efforts, to redouble sanctions against the regime of Nicolás Maduro— with his vote, I would like to recall. Therefore, when a Member State decides to violate the Resolutions of this House, it is lacking in the legitimacy of this House and all its institutions. How will others trust the European Union when even the Member States do not respect the decisions taken by this House and its institutions? We must remember that these resolutions oblige us all, also the Member States, the Council and, forgiving, the Commission. Because the Commission has the role of ensuring that non-compliance is sanctioned. It is clear that the Government of Spain has lacked the truth, it is clear that it has failed to comply with the decision taken by this House. What is clear is that the Commission has done nothing. And it's very simple. Did the Government notify the Council of the exception to Mr Maduro's government? No, he didn't. Is this document available to citizens? No, it's not. And you're not worried... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, sir.  You no longer have the floor, Mr Ca'as. I would point out that it is my constant practice not to give a 'blue card' to colleagues whom I have been deprived of the floor because of excessive speaking time.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, there is no European case, because the application of sanctions and the Council's decision is a national competence. What is there is that a debate has been brought here that should be taking place in the Congress of Deputies. And I would like to apologise to all the honourable Members for having occupied part of the European Parliament's debate with a debate which we are basically holding nine Spaniards among us, and I think it is quite regrettable.  I have to say, moreover, in a very honest way, that I believe that, by doing this kind of thing, we degrade the image of the Spanish delegation in this house, and it seems to me that we should not do this kind of exercise — I really say this and say it in all sincerity. And then I would like to send a message to the European Members of Renew and the European People's Party who have not come today - the vast majority, some do; I have a lot of respect for them—and instead on Monday they decided to vote for this debate. What are we going to do from now on?  Every time there is a national policy debate in any Member State, are we going to bring it here? What are we going to turn this House into?  I ask for a little respect and responsibility for the very serious and important jobs that we have to do here in this house.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Urtasun. I would like to explain this again, because there have been questions. It is part of my constant practice that I do not reward a speaker whom I have withdrawn the floor because he has exceeded speaking time by sending him a question.  And I will not allow your 'blue card' now, too, Mr Ca'as.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, the truth is that it is a joke, Mr Borrell, that we — Parliament, the Commission, the Council - who are constantly interfering everywhere, it turns out that it is an interference that we are reacting to the violation of a decision of the European Union to impose sanctions on a number of criminals who rule in that communist and drug-trafficking mafia in Venezuela. It has a good thing that before that it turns out that we can't do anything, when we're getting into the education of Hungarians, we're getting into the justice of Poles, et cetera, et cetera. And, on the other hand, for God's sake, let's not say this is a Spanish debate. This is a debate about respect for the rules of the European Union, which have been grossly violated by a social-communist government that we have in Spain for a month and which has already made a clandestine date with a criminal regime in Spanish territory, who knows for what, who knows under what conditions and who knows for what dark reasons.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, look, the use of the people of Venezuela is absolutely grotesque and irresponsible. It only exposes you—pretty little does Venezuelans and Venezuelans care about you. Venezuela is a divided country. What you need is responsibility; it needs us to put an end to the sanctions suffered by the people, to support dialogue, to negotiate and for guaranteed elections to be held. We saw Mr Tertsch send a message to the whole European Parliament saying that in Spain he created enormous anxiety with whom the minister of our country is located. Seriously? Really? Anxiety? Anxiety, Mr Tertsch, generates the power to give a future to our young people; anxiety generate farmers who are not receiving fair prices; anxiety generates power outages in Granada by multinationals like Endesa who skip fundamental rights. But I see little of you defending the rights of Spaniards and Spaniards against these elites.  You criminalize dialogue, encourage armed rebellions. And I tell you just one thing. Our country, Spain, is much better than the black and white with which you want to paint it. Our country has a future and it's going to be carried out by our people.

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: – Mr President, the truth is that this is not a debate on Spain or Venezuela. It is a necessary action on the value of our sanctions and our principles. There are values intrinsic to the formation of this Union, such as the functioning of a country that respects its rule of law, transparency, legality. We have recently known how the Government of Spain has mocked the implementation of the sanctions approved by the Council in June 2018. These measures prohibit the entry into European territory of the vice-president of the Maduro regime, sanctions punishable by violating democracy, for usurping powers to the National Assembly. We call on the Council to investigate this matter thoroughly through the sanctions section of the Group of Foreign Affairs Advisers – RELEX – and to report in a timely manner to this House. Certainly, no one should be above the law. Neither do states or their rulers.

name: Mónica Silvana GONZÁLEZ
text: – Mr President, indeed, this is not a European debate, this is a debate which must be discerned in the Spanish Congress.  You're making a fool of yourself, and as much as you all get together, you're who you are. They are a minority who cannot build a majority in the Spanish Parliament.  I also apologise to the other Members for having to endure a debate which should have taken place in the Congress of Spain. He obeys the fact that his political strength has only ten Deputies; their political strength is going to disappear, because all the statistics, all the polls, rightly say they're insignificant. So, Mr Cañas, ladies and gentlemen of the Renew Party, Ladies and gentlemen of Citizens, bring to this Parliament constructive solutions to alleviate the pain of the Venezuelan people.  I invite you to come to the Committee on Development and find solutions together to alleviate pain with humanitarian aid and development for the Venezuelan people.  Ladies and gentlemen, there is no case here, because the Vice-President of Venezuela was not in Schengen territory. Therefore, it did not cross any passport filter. Do you think this brings anything to alleviate the pain of the Venezuelan people? The Government of Spain will continue, led by Pedro Sánchez, to seek a democratic solution... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, it seems that I am the only foreigner in this debate. Well, I want to say that we have the debate today because yesterday the majority of this House voted in favour of this debate. And I regret that this has become a Spanish national debate, when it comes to European sanctions and what is at stake is the credibility of the European Union. This case seriously undermines our credibility with Venezuelan citizens who expect justice and our support. You, especially those who were here in the last term, will know that every time we have a debate about Venezuela, I have said the same thing: selective sanctions. It was three years before the Council finally took the first step. Selective sanctions are the strongest peaceful tool we have to pressure the regime to negotiate and stop violent repression against Venezuelans. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ibán GARCÍA DEL BLANCO
text: "blue card" question. – Mrs Charanzová, I wanted to ask the honourable Member, who deeply regretted that this had been transformed into a Spanish debate, which he hoped for. If, in the end, of course, this is a matter of national policy, which will also be discussed in the Congress of Spain, which has a debate planned for the coming days. In the end, here, it is simply the impossibility of a group that has not just found its political space and which somehow wants to know what it has to do and what are the powers of each of the parliaments Do you not feel deceived by your fellow Citizens?

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: "blue card" response. – You voted against the investigation in the Spanish Congress today. That's why we have the debate. And, as I said, it is a European problem, it is European sanctions and it is European credibility against the citizens of Venezuela.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, it is certainly the credibility of the European Union that is at stake. The credibility of this House, which is now dedicated to auditing the work of national governments. Because this is what we're debating here today.  It is not that Borrell said today that, competitively, it is the Member States and governments that apply the sanctions. It's just that a dozen spokesmen have said it over the last few weeks. A European Commission which, by the way, has members of the European People's Party and the Liberals , who have repeated the same message to them over and over again. And, moreover, today it is worth remembering that, this debate, what does it show us? That you care little about Spain and nothing Venezuela. Unfortunately, you bring the debate here to cover up your problems in auditing and doing your work in the Congress of Deputies.  The Socialists remain committed to Venezuela, not to the political use of Venezuelan pain, which is what you do here over and over again. The pain of a people like Venezuela's is not a throwing weapon, let alone to do national politics here in the European Parliament.  (He refused to have Hermann Tertsch ask him a question under the "blue card" procedure)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We shall then turn to the spontaneous speeches. I have more than twice as many speeches as the one we have time for. I will also take into account Spanish colleagues, but the non-Spanish ones, at least. Mr Aguilar. Spontaneous speeches

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, I am a Canary, close to the Venezuelan people, which includes the descendants of the Canarian community in Venezuela. I participated in all the discussions on Venezuela and warned High Representative Borrell that there would be no plenary without a debate on Venezuela. I voted on resolutions which seek to support democratic change in Venezuela and which call for the unity of the European Parliament. But this is not a debate about Venezuela, nor about the suffering of the Venezuelan people. It's not even a debate about Spain. It is a debate brought by those who oppose the Government of Spain, because they are in the minority in the Congress of Deputies and therefore intend to trivialise, multiplying the debates on Venezuela, the position of the European Parliament, also harming the European Parliament and its credibility, which they invoke so much. Because nothing harms both the credibility of the Resolutions of the European Parliament and disunity in the European Parliament, trying to criticise the Government of Spain about the suffering of the people of Venezuela. Therefore, lords of the People's party and citizens, do not make a fool of yourself or scratch in the grotesque. Help the Venezuelan people instead of bringing here a debate that has no other purpose than to criticize the Government of Spain.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, if i still had to, this debate further discredits the more reactionary and misaligned right of this Parliament. The hatred that drives them now leads them to transport Spanish politics here to Parliament. Deep down, it's all about feeding this irrational sanha. A sanha that omits the inothermism of the sanctions they continue to defend, for the Venezuelan people and for the immigrant communities in Venezuela, namely the Portuguese community. A sanha that exposes them, moreover, as to the European Union, to international ridicule for the non-recognition of a government successively suffraged by the popular vote and by the insistence on support for a puppet of Trump, who has lost any credit, even with the Venezuelan opposition. And finally, those who act like this, driven by hatred, and only by hatred, inevitably end up stumbling on their own feet, as demonstrated here in this debate.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Mr President, I do not know about you, but with this debate, I have the feeling of being in front of the tantrum of a child who has had a toy broken. Only in this way can it be understood that the parliamentary group which has lost the most representation in the general elections in my country is trying to keep open a debate which even the European Commission itself understands to be closed.  The truth is that it is regrettable to see that, while our government is making an effort to make good for working families—raising the interprofessional minimum wage, reinforcing public services, fighting gambling—you are engaged, here and elsewhere, in the same way, in the sling, in fanatical veto, and in pineapple with your friends on the far right. I would ask you to do us a favor and save us all and all this embarrassment, now and in the future, and I would suggest a little more responsibility and a little more work for the interests of our people.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Mr President, I think it’s an absolute joke, actually, that we are here discussing this nonsense. I’ve been very open in my criticism of the Spanish Government in different situations, so now, when they do something that’s correct, I will be equally forthright in welcoming the initiative that they took, and in their stance in supporting dialogue in this situation. How else do you think that this situation is going to be resolved! We should be discussing here, actually, the situation where we have supported the imaginary president Juan Guaidó, the chosen one of a nakedly US-backed coup, a defeated attempt, a crowd who have been exposed for embezzling the humanitarian aid and squandering it. We should be dealing here with the impact of the sanctions on the people of Venezuela, the hardship that that has caused, the difficulties there. That is not something that any of us should be standing over – we should be working to end that nightmare. I salute the efforts that have been taken, and I condemn the initiatives taken here to derail that project.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, these are European sanctions. How but, in accordance with European rules, the implementation and monitoring of these sanctions is the responsibility of the Member States. That is also a European standard. Or isn't it? Changing it would need to change the Treaty. You know — or you should know perfectly well - that these kinds of travel restrictions are Council decisions and therefore do not fall under the control of European law, they are not Union law. A normal citizen, a citizen who is not an expert on these issues, may be surprised, but you should not be surprised. Why are you surprised? It is the Council's decision and, as such, it is not Union law. And, consequently, the Commission has no role in monitoring its application and cannot initiate infringement proceedings. You're MEPs. You must know that, don't you? Are you surprised? They're surprised. Well, you'll have to study a little more, because you shouldn't be surprised. That a Council decision is not Union law, you know that, and therefore the European Commission cannot intervene and cannot initiate infringement proceedings. And also, in accordance with our rules, we have said that it is the Member States that have to monitor their implementation. It is then a European rule which has to be applied by a Member State and whose application has to be controlled at Member State level. Where's the logical flaw in my argument? Because if I don't have a logical glitch, you have it.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: in writing. – This Parliament has promoted yet another debate on Venezuela, a country constantly attacked by the most reactionary right that does not accept the struggle of a people who stand upright. This time, the hatred that drives them has driven them to bring Spanish politics into this parliament, continuing to fuel the most undemocratic and unmanageable sentiments, insisting on the non-recognition of a government successively suffraged by the popular vote and the insistence on supporting a Trump puppet, who has lost any credit already even to the Venezuelan opposition. They continue to defend sanctions whose main harmed are the Venezuelan people and immigrant communities in Venezuela, such as the Portuguese community. To the Venezuelan people who resist and do not sell themselves, despite sanctions and all external attacks, we express our solidarity.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the US plan for the Middle East: EU response in accordance with international law (2020/2559(RSP)). I would also like to remind you – while the Commissioner is on the move – that you can request spontaneous speeches and speeches using the 'blue card' procedure, both in the traditional way and electronically. The instructions can be found at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I am really grateful for having this opportunity to address you today on the Middle East peace process. This issue is of fundamental strategic importance to the European Union. For too long, we have been witnessing a conflict that has caused endless suffering for generations of Israelis and Palestinians alike. The increasingly dire situation on the ground, including violence, terrorism, incitement, settlement expansion – illegal, by the way – and the consequences of the ongoing occupation, has destroyed hope on both sides and reduced the viability of a two-state solution. At an international level for a number of years there has been little or no substantive engagement in efforts to resolve the conflict. Indeed, as one observer pointed out to me recently, there is neither peace nor a process. In recent years, we on the European Union side are perhaps the only actor who has stayed the course. We have been vocal in our support for a negotiated two-state solution based on the internationally agreed parameters and in accordance with international law. This means a two-state solution based on the parameters set in the Council Conclusions – our Council – of July 2014, that meets Israeli and Palestinian security needs and Palestinian aspirations for statehood and sovereignty, ends the occupation that began in 1967, and resolves all permanent status issues in order to end the conflict. Our vision, our European vision, is a principled one and a pragmatic one. It reflects our broader attachment as Europeans to the rules-based international order. We are also active on the ground. No other international actor has been as engaged as we have been in practical efforts to build a future Palestinian state. In 2019 alone, the European Union and its Member States had an open portfolio of some 600 million in assistance to the Palestinians. I said during my hearing: it means – 600 million is almost EUR 1.5 million a day. Where are we today? It remains my firm view that there is still a way forward if both parties are willing to resume credible and meaningful negotiations. International support for any such efforts would clearly be crucial to their success. In this regard, the tabling of concrete proposals, such as the United States one, could be helpful, both as a catalyst for deeper reflection on the way forward and as a potential opportunity to quick-start a political process which has been at a standstill for too long. However, as I have said, the proposal tabled two weeks ago clearly challenges the internationally-agreed parameters, and it is difficult to see how this initiative can bring both parties back to the table. 25 out of 27 Member States in the Foreign Affairs Council supported this consideration. Two were against, so it was not a unanimous decision of the Council and I could not present it like this, but as a statement of the High Representative, which I am repeating here again. Last week I was in Washington; they were very busy days, talking with all foreign affairs external policy higher authorities of the US Government. I put this point to my interlocutors. We need to ask ourselves whether this plan provides a basis for progress or not. We need to know whether the proposals themselves are really open for negotiation. Is it the starting point, or the end point? For the European Union’s part, our position is clear. We are ready to work with the international community to revive a political process in line with international law, which ensures equal rights and which is acceptable to both parties. Thank you for your attention and I am looking forward to an important discussion, which I’m sure will follow.

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would say the following to Mr Borrell.  Mr Borrell, you stated that the United States Middle East peace plan departs from internationally agreed parameters. You also used rather pointed language originally when you said that part of this plan, if implemented, could not pass unchallenged. Naturally this evoked a reaction from our Israeli friends, who warned that this type of – what they called – ‘threatening’ language could lead to the EU’s role in the peace process being minimised. Meanwhile, the Palestinian leadership has angrily dismissed President Trump’s plan as a conspiracy.  I think it’s frankly unreasonable to expect that either side would greet this proposal with any real enthusiasm, but I would like to choose to view the glass as half full and not half empty. So this plan could perhaps serve as a basis for resuming talks in earnest with the understanding that there are, in fact, painful concessions to be made on both sides. This is your moment to shine, Mr Borrell. Europe could perhaps assume a much more prominent role, an active role, as an honest broker of just and lasting peace. It could encourage both sides to consider the plan as a starting point for reopening meaningful goodwill negotiations.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we do not know what President Trump’s deal of the century actually is apart from being one-sided, illegal and intentionally provocative, but it is most certainly not a genuine effort at finding a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Let me be clear, negotiations between Israel and Palestine were broken off in 2014 and must be resumed as soon as possible. But that is not what this plan will lead to. This plan disregards the international rules-based order. It not only normalises illegal settlements but also clears the way for the utterly illegitimate annexation of the Jordan Valley and 30% of the West Bank. We must make clear that such actions will have serious consequences for our relationship with Israel if that happens. Inevitably, it will also lead to more suffering for the Palestinian people, whether that is because their land is annexed, their water resources are taken or because they lack control over their own borders. This is a cynical plan of two far-right leaders seeking a cheap popularity boost ahead of elections. This is a slap in the face of Israelis and Palestinians who genuinely want to find a solution. I therefore call on you, Mr High Representative, to continue supporting all efforts that truly involve both parties. The people of Israel and Palestine need a real peace plan and if we, as Europeans, can play a constructive role in that, we should do so.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Dear High Representative, in recent weeks we have once again been sucked into a Trumpian rabbit hole: a two-state solution for Israel and Palestine, with all the benefits for Israel and the crumbs for the Palestinians. Trump's plan was really nothing more than a one-state plan for Israel, disguised as a two-state solution. A missed opportunity, you might say, were it not for the fact that Trump's proposal has now completely sniveed off the fragile relationship between Israel and Palestine. That is why, Mr Borrell, the European Union has more than ever to play. America has drawn the Israeli map far too unilaterally in recent years. The CREDIBILITY of the UNITED States in the Middle East is at a time of tatt. A credibility that you, which Europe still has. So use this credibility, by acting as an impartial partner, as an honest broker, to glue the chunks made by Trump, so that Israel and Palestine can return to the table or at least indirect negotiations. And let us make it clear that our European red lines are widely supported by the international community. I think, Mr Borrell, a high-level international peace conference that you are leading is the way forward. You have our support.

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President and also High Representative, this is a particularly sensitive debate. As the European Union, we have an obligation to clarify our position, especially as Belgium, Estonia and Germany, as non-permanent members, are supporting France in the United Nations Security Council.  Since Brexit has taken place, we are called upon to exercise a foreign policy action that is both new and prospective, in a geopolitics that has been going on for the twenty-first century, which goes from the protection of European security, from the great issue of immigration, from energy, from climate change, from 5G to European investments in those countries. The Treaty of Lisbon gives it the promotion of peace and security in the world. That is why, with regard to the Middle East, I would ask you to consider three main elements: the existential threat to the State of Israel is alive more than ever, and that is unacceptable. Israel is primarily a Jewish nation state. We Europeans, at our deepest root, are Jews. Do not miss, Mr Solana, your most important opportunity to show which side Europe is on.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, a great number of victims of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict have long been languishing for a peace plan. Such a peace plan must, of course, include painful concessions, but concessions from both sides. It must include security for Israel, but it must also include a viable sovereign, contiguous state for the Palestinians living side by side with the Israelis.  This is not what Trump is presenting to us. It’s not a fresh start, it’s a dead end. The so—called peace plan is neither about peace, because it doesn’t overcome it prolongs the conflict, nor is it a plan as a point of departure for negotiations. It’s rather a dictate. When they talk about a peace plan they are effectively pushing for annexation – and a two-state solution is different from one state plus one canton. We cannot …  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, High Representative Mr Borrell, you called on both sides to reengage and refrain from any unilateral actions that would exacerbate tensions. This is a peace plan widely accepted in Israel, but fully rejected on the Palestinian side. Fine, but Palestinians will not even sit down at the table. Many in the Palestinian population prefer violence.  In fact, last month, Palestinian NGOs refused EU funding rules prohibiting our aid to be channelled to terrorist groups. In their refusal, these NGOs, 70% funded by the EU, are calling what they believe to be your bluff. High Representative, show them that the EU means business; encourage long-term re-engagement and easing of tensions; say a thousand times: no, no, no to EU funding Palestinian rejectionist and terrorist policies.  (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Manu PINEDA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr. President, the Trump-Netanyahu tandem, in a boast of unprecedented cynicism, has presented what they have described as the "great agreement of the century." But it is not legitimate to agree when one of the parties concerned, the Palestinian people, has neither been consulted nor signed any kind of pact.  This parody is not legal because it violates international law and countless United Nations resolutions. So if this is neither agreement nor legal nor legitimate, it cannot be called the "great agreement of the century". We could call it the "great scam of the century", which aims to wipe out the Palestinian people and also cover up the shames of two criminals persecuted in their different countries. We could talk about it and it would be more accurate.  Mr Borrell recently made a pronouncement which I think is excellent, and I want you to congratulate and thank him from here. But I think it's time, Mr. Borrell, to move on to the facts. Its pronouncement is necessary, but it is necessary that at a time like this the European Union will break the Association Agreement with Israel and recognize the State... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Lukas MANDL
text: – Mr President, each and every force in this world is more than welcome if this force puts a proposal for a solution on the table, especially when it’s a proposal for a solution with the objective of a two states perspective in it – a two states solution in the end. The EU has not contributed much with a concrete proposal in the past, so we should deal with the proposal from the United States constructively. The EU is contributing a lot in terms of development aid and other terms, but has not proposed anything in the past, so let’s deal constructively with the US proposal. If somebody reacts with violence to a solution proposal, this is not a reliable partner, and reaction with violence in the past has been wrong. Dear Commissioner, take that into consideration in order to deal constructively with the US proposal and in order to be connected with the values of the pro-western powers in this world. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Sven MIKSER
text: – Mr President, it is hard to regard the most recent US peace plan as credible since it does not meet the principal parameters for peace. It is not fair and even-handed, it does not follow the basic principles of international law and its drafters only managed to engage one of the two parties to the conflict.  Whatever domestic political ends in the US or in Israel the plan’s launch may have served, its chances of revitalising the peace process are, unfortunately, virtually non-existent. Moreover, if Israel, following Palestinian rejection of the plan, were to restart settlement activity or go on to annex parts of the occupied territories, it may be entirely counterproductive to sustainable peace and eventually prove detrimental to the two- state solution altogether. The EU must stick to its principal position of holding firm to international law. We must continue to uphold the position that only a negotiated two-state solution can, in a sustainable manner, address the legitimate Israeli security concerns and deliver a Palestinian statehood.  But, in addition to having a clear and principled understanding of where we need to be at the end of the process, the EU also needs a credible plan of its own on how to get there from where we are today. This is ever more critical as the US appears to be abandoning its role as an even-handed broker.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: "Mr. President, how wrong he is! How wrong Mr Trump is with this peace plan, which has only its name, because finally peace, Mr President, is not only that of the balance of power. Peace, Mr President, must be based on enough fairness to ensure a future of understanding, not just coexistence. Between Israel and Palestine, there will be lasting and true peace only on this condition: equity. And it is not her that you propose. So we will not support you, we will not follow you, but will continue to tell our Israeli and Palestinian neighbours and friends that Jerusalem must be the shared capital of two peoples equal in dignity, security and well-being. The blind will say that this is no longer possible, because the facts accomplished would take precedence. But realism, the real one, commands us to stick to the utopia of justice, the one that always ends and must eventually triumph.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Mr President, first of all I think it’s a very important debate because in the last weeks it has been the main topic in the media – a peace plan by the US in the Middle East. First of all, I think it’s very important for the European Union to understand international law, because in international law we have to understand that it has to be respected on both sides, by Israel and also by Palestine.  From the Palestinian side, we have to recognise that they haven’t really understood the meaning of international law – that you can’t support terrorist organisations against Israel. You can’t support the way you’re using your children, how you’re using them like bombing attacks against neighbouring countries. So in this case I think Palestine is really breaking international law, something we have to also recognise. The second thing is there have been many critics against the US about this peace plan, but I’ve never heard of any other solution or any other plan for the Middle East, so I really want ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Mr President! Thank you to Mr Saunders. I would like to ask Mr Borrell for the clear statement on Israel's illegal occupation of Palestine. They have both the right and the duty to say so, whatever, for example, Hungary may think. If the European Union passively allows Israel's occupation to expand, we will not only break the laws of the United Nations, but also our own laws. However, I would like to know what is meant by the fact that annexations will not remain 'unchallenged'. I hope that the European Union will finally respond with action, not just with words.  In 2016, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2334. It also includes "differentiation", i.e. a separation between Israel and settlements. We should therefore make 'differentiation' the EU's guiding principle and stop all cooperation with the settlements on trade, the economy, culture, etc. And then our High Representative has the authority not only to condemn Israel's destruction of eu-paid projects, to soothe the lives of Palestinians, but also to demand compensation. Israel has destroyed millions. That money is going back to the EU's taxpayers. But thanks for the effort so far.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, we can, of course, find everything about the peace plan and criticise all sorts of things. But please don't let us do that today. That really does not take the peace process any further. The added value of the plan is that at least something is on the table. So let's give that a fair chance. I really only have one call to the Palestinian Authority: stop protecting terrorists, recognize the State of Israel and sit around the table, go talk. I emphatically distance myself from the High Representative's statement. You do not go further than to criticise Israel and the United States in your statement of 4 February, in fact saying to Abbas: "I can quite understand that you are not going to negotiate, I would not do it myself." I think that's the wrong message at the wrong time. You wrongly made this statement as a statement on behalf of the European Union. If there is no unanimity on the part of the Council, you cannot express a position on behalf of the EU!

name: Niyazi KIZILYÜREK
text: – Mr President, the so-called ‘deal of the century’ is a plain violation of international law. It was prepared without consulting one of the parties concerned – the Palestinians – and it tends to legitimise illegal Israeli settlements, which is a crime of war.  It rolls back from the agreements of 1967 and denies Palestinians issue to Jerusalem as their capital. I regret to say that Trump’s plan is not only an assault on Palestinian rights, but also an attempt to put forward a new regional order that completely undermines international law. It is a deal which can harm the whole region and is not less unacceptable and not less dangerous than the colonialist Sykes—Picot Agreement from 1916.  In an era of chaotic international relations, the EU must stand firm and continue to support the two-state solution with an independent Palestinian state within the 1967 borders. Furthermore, the EU should make a stand against Israeli settlements which violate the relevant UN resolutions and show support for the right of Palestinian refugees to return to their homes.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I refuse to call Trump's proposal a peace plan, as some would like to do, because the only proposal is a plan, that is how Trump will secure his November election win in the United States and how to secure his friend Netanyahu's election win in the Israeli election. The plan runs counter to international law, gives the green light to the annexation of even more Palestinian land and makes it impossible for a two-state solution in which two democratic states – Israel and Palestine – coexist side by side in peace and security.  At a time when the UNITED States no longer respects international law, it is important that the EUROPEAN Union now shows that we are not only talking about our fundamental values, but also fighting for them, no matter where in the world injustices arise.  The Palestinian people and the Israeli people deserve both their respective states. The time has come for all EU countries to recognise Palestine under the 1967 borders. My Swedish government did in 2014, which I am proud of.  My question to the High Representative is therefore: how will the Commission take concrete action to ensure that international law is respected?

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the When I went to primary school, the line was above the territory of East Germany, that is, that of the former GDR: "Currently under Soviet administration", and in the further eastern areas of Pomerania and Silesia there was "Currently under Polish administration". This was one of the great life lies of the post-war period: the belief that the territories lost in the war would ever come back. Only Willy Brandt put an end to this lie. A similar lie has existed for 53 years with regard to Gaza and the West Bank. Both areas were lost to the Arabs because they lost wars against Israel. When you start a war, you have to reckon with it. The two-state solution of 1967 is the un's great life lie, and it is also the EU's great life lie. President Trump's peace plan is by no means ideal, but it does, after all, bring movement to a completely deadlocked situation. Gaza and the West Bank have been conflict zones for more than 50 years. So do we want to continue to hold on to a life lie? The UN peace plan of 1967 with the two-state solution: it does not work.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: Mr President, the Trump administration's Plan for the Middle East is a dangerous step backwards and another step in the denial of international law. This is not an agreement, but the validation of Israel's fait accompli policy. A one-sided view of the conflict that you have the merit of, Mr Borrell, for condemning. We are decidedly content with very little in the face of the seriousness of the facts. Since Member States are incapable of unanimity in calling for compliance with UN resolutions, let us enforce the law with our means. First, let us demand that Israel compensate or return these destructions of EU-funded projects. No less than 97 structures are affected, worth 500,000 euros in 2019. Let us deepen the policy of differentiation between Israel's recognized international borders and the settlements. Let us clearly condemn the institutionalization of discrimination. Finally, I was going to say, and above all, let us put back on the table, as the Palestinians are asking, for an international conference for peace in the Middle East.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Dear Mr President, Trump's so-called Middle East peace plan is a hoax, is a dirty game and is a blow to international law against efforts to find a peace solution to one of the Middle East's most pressing issues. Peace, so it won't. The US president's plan is another step towards the establishment of a full apartheid regime that Israel is already implementing against the Palestinians, making it completely impossible in practice to establish a sovereign and even possible Palestinian state. Trump is clearly unaware that peace in the Middle East, especially for Israel, will not be achieved without a solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. I therefore support you, Honourable Borell, in insisting on international law and combating the illegal annexation of the West Bank and the Jordan Valley to Israel.  Europe should immediately ban imports of products produced in illegal Jewish settlements and stop all European investment. However, israeli access to Union programmes should be made necessary by progress in the peace process.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, the 1967 Israeli border is not realistic anymore, because the circumstances in the region have changed completely in the past 50 years. The Americans have promised to invest USD 50 billion in the Palestinian state if Trump’s Israeli–Palestinian peace plan is implemented. Israel will also commit not to build any new settlements for the next four years. At the same time, this treaty will safeguard the security of the State of Israel. The EU should support this plan. This could be the last chance to achieve lasting peace after many decades of violence. It is time to put an end to this pro-launch and hard conflict. The EU should not object to this deal because the EU hates Trump.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr. President, Trump's plan is a blast of international consensus on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. It is based on unilaterality, annexation, inequality of rights, contempt for international law and will lead to perpetual occupation and permanent conflict. As my colleague used to say, it's not a peace plan, it's a dictation. In the face of this, I would like to thank the high representative for the courageous communiqué on the matter and also say that it is time to defend the basic international consensuses on this conflict: that we want a negotiated political process, a two-state solution, respect for international law and equal rights. And to this end I believe that Member States, in order to maintain and continue to keep alive the hope of a solution with two States, must begin to seriously consider the recognition of Palestine as a State in order to make this possible. And finally, I would like to ask the high representative - and that is very important at the moment - that the policy of differentiation between the borders of '67 and the illegal annexations of territory by Israel be maintained by the European Union.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I join many colleagues in strongly condemning and rejecting Trump's proposed plan to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian issue, a pure act of electoral propaganda in favour of Netanyahu, who for months has been trying to recover a solid majority and divert attention from his corruption trials, and an act of propaganda for Trump himself. , which seeks to show itself to be a world leader of great influence. The plan is unacceptable. No consultation of the Palestinians, the annexation of the West Bank, Jerusalem israel's exclusive capital: these are just a few points of the agreement that violates international law in practically every possible way. I think it was therefore right, Mr Solana, to reject it firmly and to reiterate the European position for a two-state solution on the basis of the borders of 1967. He was right to warn that any act of annexation will have serious consequences. It is time to start to say this, Europe cannot be condescending. We will never remain silent in the face of the denial of history and international law.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, no peace plan can succeed unless it has the support of all parties to the conflict, and the way in which this plan was published speaks most to the political weaknesses of the two leaders who presented it.
