The plan is an expression of the current U.S. administration's unilateral policies and chronic rejection of multilateralism. Let's think of the Paris Agreement, the attitude towards the Kurds, the role in Syria, the agreement with Iran. Certain elements presented as major concessions have actually already been agreed during earlier negotiations and attempts to find a solution. Of particular concern are the parts of the plan concerning the Jordan Valley and parts of the West Bank.  This proposal only demonstrates the depth of differences between opposing stakeholders. All involved should refrain from unilateral moves and sincerely engage in genuine negotiations to find a lasting solution, which is two independent, democratically consolidated sovereign states, which will allow for the peaceful and secure coexistence of people on both sides of the border. Such a solution must, of course, be based on international law.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Mr President, I welcome Trump's Middle East peace proposal, mainly because it is balanced, some are given to the Israelis, the guarantees of peace and security, and some by the Palestinians, and this country. Democratic states have more or less supported this proposal, and all those others who are not have rejected it together with the Palestinians, who clearly have this status quo and do not want peace. Iran rejected that, too, that proposal. I would like to ask Mr Borrell, who was recently in Iran, have you discussed this proposal with the authorities in Iran? And secondly, have you warned the regime of drastic human rights violations in this country? And thirdly, why were you there in the first respect of just helping to legitimize a regime that drastically violates human rights?

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Mr President, Mr. High Representative, Josep Borrell. I support the statement you issued. I also think it is important in procedural terms to overcome the blockades that often occur in the Council by only one or two countries. And on the subject, which is President Trump's peace proposal, I will not repeat what you have said and what most speakers have said about the problems he presents and which is therefore impractical.  But also, some ladies and gentlemen have alluded to the need for a European alternative. While not a detailed proposal like the one presented by Mr Trump, perhaps some kind of procedural initiative in the sense of a new middle-east peace conference—such as the one that once took place in Madrid in 1991—and, if not possible at this time, start working to make the conditions for it to be done.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Mr President, High Representative Borrell, in the last decades of peace negotiations in the region, the entire international community has affirmed the importance of promoting a plan based on the principles of international law. Any peace plan is welcome, as long as it is in accordance with these principles, is inclusive and proposes the existence of two states, two states for two peoples, coexisting in peace and security. In the absence of such a plan, the current status quo will unfortunately remain. We can't opportunistically rush what for decades has dragged on in pain. That is why I want to mention the idea of Colleague Kautmans, that a multilateral peace conference, which ensures an inclusive format, where we too can be at the table, is the direction we need to go.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I listened to this debate today: on the one hand, supporters of President Trump's plan and, on the other, opponents of the plan. Very few specifics, and there are dramas. Everyone who has even been to Jerusalem, talked, knows that there are many of these dramas, and that a new generation is really growing up, which we can again call a lost generation, because it is prepared to fight with each other, not how to coexist on both sides.  Mr Representative, you have said that you have had a great deal of discussions with your partners in the United States. Please tell me with whom you have had these discussions and what are the conclusions of these discussions. A constructive plan is very necessary. Anyone who thinks about such a plan and presents constructions, proposals, can finally bring us closer to peace in this region. That is why I think, Mr Representative, that... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, the UN has said many times that it is illegal under international law to build settlements in the occupied territories. Thus, the model proposed by the USA is completely unsustainable from the point of view of international law. It is also completely contrary to the two-state principle – the model that would also guarantee the Palestinians their own state. Whatever the model for peace in this region, it must guarantee the Palestinians their own state, full freedom and full right to decide for themselves.  This "peace settlement model" of Trump is quite different. It gives Israel fertile farmland and the Palestinians desert. It fragments the Palestinian territories in such a way that the Palestinians are constantly subjust to Israeli control. Trump's proposal is probably the worst show ever made to bring peace to this region. I hope that the High Representative will take proactive action to get israelis and Palestinians around the same table to hold negotiations in order to achieve a genuine two-state model of peace in the region.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Mr President, we condemn the unacceptable plan of the United States on the Palestinian issue, which is disrupting and shielding the Israeli occupation. The proposed agreement is part of US imperialist planning in the wider region. It provides for the concession of Jerusalem to Israel, the annexation of the Jordan Valley and the preservation of settlements. The European Union and its governments — and the Greek governments of New Democracy and SYRIZA — have very, very heavy responsibilities. They keep an equal distance between the perpetrator and the victim; they have continually expanded and upgraded political, economic and military cooperation with the Israeli state.  Mr Borrell's position, which finds the Trump proposal specific and helpful, is essentially at odds with the interests of the Palestinian people. At the same time, if the position expressed by Mrs Asimakopoulou is also the position of the Greek Government, then it is both unacceptable and dangerous. Such positions reveal the reasons why the decisions of parliaments recognised by the independent Palestinian State are not implemented.  We support the palestinian people's fair fight to end the Israeli occupation and for an independent Palestinian state on the 1967 border with East Jerusalem as its capital.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank all of you. We know this is a very divisive issue. It is in the Council and it is in the Parliament. But I would like to remind you that I’m not expressing my personal opinion. My job is to be the High Representative of the Council and I have to represent what I think is the opinion of the Council. Mr Zver, I haven’t said that this statement was the position of the European Union. I precisely said – and you should have listened to me – that since it was not unanimous – and it is in the records – I could not present an agreement of the Council. It was a statement of the High Representative, representing whom? Representing the 25 Member States who agreed with the statement. I said very clearly – you didn’t notice – so I will repeat it. It was not a statement of the European Union. It was a statement of the High Representative and was not unanimous.  Mr Zver, why did I go to Iran? Because I have a mandate – a unanimous mandate – from the Member States of the Council asking me to go and talk with everyone in the broader region of the far Middle East to try to see if there is any possibility for us, the European Union, to contribute to increasing stability and peace in the region. I have a mandate to go and talk to everybody. Everybody means everybody, and I have been talking with the Foreign Affairs Minister of Saudi Arabia, I went to Jordan, I have been talking with the Emirates, I went to Tehran and I will go to Iraq in order to have a look at what we Europeans can do in order to contribute, if we can, to the peace and stability of this region.  I am sorry, Mr Zver. I was confused. It was not you who spoke about what was or was not in the statement of the European Union. I think it was our colleague, Mr Ruissen. Sorry, I made a mistake. So my answer was directed to Mr Ruissen. My answer to you was relating to what I did in Iran. For sure we talked with the Iranians about everything that worries them and that worries us, but the main purpose was to ask what we can do in order to save the nuclear deal and what we can do in order to stabilise the region. We didn’t spend much time talking about the Israeli—Palestinian issue because the Iranians are very much aware that they have nothing to say on that problem.  Another Member – I think it was Ms Kempa – asked with whom I have been talking in the USA. Well, with the most prominent people, with Secretary of State Pompeo, with the National Security Advisor, Mr O’Brien, with Mr Kushner, the author of the plan, and with Ms Nancy Pelosi. And for sure the first three were very much in favour of their plan, while Ms Nancy Pelosi, who as you know is a Democrat, was very critical of it. As I say, I am not expressing my opinion. In fact my opinion is of no interest here. I am expressing the majority of the Council, and the majority of the Council has supported the statement in which we sent a message saying that, first, everybody has to refrain from any unilateral actions contrary to international law which could exacerbate tensions further. We are asking that no one annexes the Jordan Valley. Yet this may happen. If it happens, you can be sure that it is not going to be peaceful. Maybe for some it doesn’t matter, but for us it matters a lot because we cannot provoke a wave of violence – another wave of violence – in Palestine. We are asking Palestinians to keep calm and not go to violent demonstrations. We asked for the proposal to be considered as a starting point and I said clearly that maybe it could break the stalemate and create the dynamics in which we can go and talk again about what we can do in order to look for a solution to this very old, damaging and painful problem.  I am not denying the possibility of this being a starting point. What I am denying is not this possibility, but the fact that it is being considered as an end point because, if I tell you ‘come and negotiate, but I’ll tell you one thing. If we don’t agree, I will implement my proposal anyway.’ – this is not a big incentive to negotiate. ‘Come and negotiate but be aware that, if you don’t agree with me, I will implement the proposal anyway.’ Do you call that a negotiation? That’s what we refuse. And that is what we have been saying.  And believe me, we invited Secretary of State Pompeo to come to the Foreign Affairs Council to explain directly to all Member States their proposal. I know that there are some who are closer to this position and others who are very far away from it. I know that there is not going to be a unanimous position on this. It’s too divisive. But we have to discuss and we have to look, if not for unanimity, for the majority – whatever it is – and, believe me, I don’t think the majority of the Member States of the European Union are considering this proposal as a good starting point. But we’ll do our best and talk with everyone in order to try to break this stalemate and push for negotiations.  Some very optimistic people asked me why we don’t try to do something like we did many years ago in Madrid – the Oslo process and the Madrid process. I think we have the commitment to do something. We cannot just refuse. We cannot say that’s not good enough. We have to look for something that works and this is going to be part of the discussions that we are going to have next Monday in the Foreign Affairs Council.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – The Trump plan is an assault on the Palestinian people and international law. This plan is part of the bellicose escalation of American imperialism and the Zionist regime of Israel, which serves a strategy of destabilization, provocation and dominance, which could have serious consequences for the peoples of the Middle East and the World. With this plan, decades of UN resolutions that recognise and enshrine the national rights of the Palestinian people are violated. It seeks to legitimize decades of occupation and terror against the Palestinian people, by providing, among other unacceptable measures, the occupation and effective annexation by Israel of Jerusalem and about half of the West Bank of the Jordan River, as well as the legalization and territorial continuity of Israeli settlements built in Palestinian territory, the Trump Administration's plan has as its main objective to impose a new and more serious level in israel's occupation and annexation of Palestinian territories , and the abandonment of the two-state solution, with the 1967 borders and the capital of Palestine in East Jerusalem. The Trump plan is a very serious abandonment of any prospect for a fair, negotiated and lasting solution to the Palestinian issue. It deserves a ready and unequivocal repudiation. Here we underline the importance of unity and solidarity around the Palestinian cause.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the current security situation in Syria (2020/2560 (RSP)." Here, too, I would like to remind you that you can request spontaneous speeches and speeches using the 'blue card' procedure, both in the traditional way and electronically. The instructions can be found at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the war in Syria is now in its ninth year. It is the most severe humanitarian catastrophe and security crisis; it is unfolding right now in the north-west of the country, and in other parts of Syria we continue to see instability and dramatic human suffering.  Last Thursday, we heard the United Nations Special Envoy Geir Pedersen and the Head of the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Mark Lowcock briefing the United Nations Security Council on the situation in Idlib. They described how regime forces led by Russia and Iran are launching heavy military offensives with no regard for the civilian population or civilian infrastructure. ‘We appear to have lost sight of the principle of proportionality’, the United Nations Special Envoy said. The intensification of military operations in Idlib has resulted in the indiscriminate killing of hundreds of civilians. Attacks continue on civilian targets in densely populated areas, on medical facilities and settlements for internationally displaced people. These are blatant and serious violations of international humanitarian law. There has to be accountability for those responsible. Since military operations began in Idlib in February 2019, one year ago, more than one million people have been displaced towards Turkey – we are talking about one million displaced people in one year – and every day more Syrians are fleeing the fighting and another wave of refugees is quite possibly in the making.  We also see clashes between the Syrian regime and Turkish forces, plus the risk of Turkish and Russian militaries confronting each other. These tensions could in turn trigger a wider regional conflict. The ceasefire agreed between Ankara and Moscow must be implemented. This is the situation.  Now, let me say this. After almost a decade of violence, the suffering of the Syrian people at the hands of the regime and its backers must cease. Too many people have died and those that are alive face a bleak future. The EU has major stakes in Syria, and in the surrounding region. We cannot afford more regional instability and another migrant crisis. We must avoid a resurgence of Daesh and other terrorist organisations on Europe’s doorstep.  The EU has a duty to preserve the rules-based international order, including the legitimacy of the United Nations Security Council. Yes, I know, we say that again and again, and we have to continue saying that. Recent military gains by the Syrian regime are not translating into stability. On the contrary, the Syrian regime will not bring peace and stability to Syria if it continues to pursue on military logic and the repression of its people. The economic situation is deteriorating rapidly, exacerbated by the banking crashes in Lebanon. The regime must change its behaviour.  We have stated from the very beginning that only a comprehensive and inclusive political solution, in line with United Nations Security Council Resolution 2254, will allow sustainable peace and stability in Syria and the region. The EU will continue to support the efforts of United Nations Special Envoy Pedersen in relaunching the Constitutional Committee in Geneva. We also need to focus on other parts of this resolution, such as a nationwide ceasefire, the release of detainees, and making progress on the file of missing persons. Let’s recall that the European Union is, and remains, the largest humanitarian donor to Syria and its people, both inside, and to Syrian refugees and host communities in neighbourhood countries. We are supporting the resilience of ordinary civilians and civil society to maintain the social fabric of Syrian society. We are convinced that our support is a fundamental investment – it is not an expenditure, it is an investment – in the future of Syria and the region, which is part of our future, and as a partner of the global coalition to defeat Daesh the EU is conducting stabilisation projects in the north-east of Syria. We are always prepared to do more on all these lines of action, within the limits of our common red lines. These are: no normalisation with the regime, no risking of our funding being diverted to the regime or to the terrorists, and no reconstruction before a political process is firmly under way. We will continue to apply European Union sanctions targeting individuals and entities associated with the regime and responsible for its repressive and inhuman policies – and not the Syrian people. As I said before, the conflict in Syria is a geopolitical struggle. The European Union has a responsibility to lead for the sake of the Syrian people and to protect our own interests. While difficult, we must redouble our efforts to identify common interests with our other international stakeholders – Russia, the US, Turkey and others – and maybe I will have occasion to update on our discussions with Washington about this issue.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, High Representative, thank you for your report. The war in Syria, as you have already said, is in its 9th year. Idlib province is the last battleground in the Syrian conflict, which Assad is likely to deal with the opposition and consolidate its power. Civilians are fleeing from the government's Assad forces to the Turkish border, which is impermeable and, according to humanitarian organizations, is crowding around a million people, some of them moving repeatedly. I agree that the EU must provide humanitarian aid to these people, and I also call for continued projects in the conflict-affected provinces.  We know that around 70% of fleeing civilians are women and children. That is why I want to call for the EU to continue to support the education of children even in the very difficult conditions of refugee camps. We know that it is important that these children do not lose perspective, but it is not a solution that we need to be interested in in the long term. At the moment, idlib's fate depends on negotiations between Damascus, Moscow, Ankara and the United States, and I want to ask: what role does the EU play and will play here? You have very rightly mentioned the role of the United Nations here. I think the long-term solution must be directed by the UN. The sanctions and humanitarian aid promoted by the EU are appropriate, but I call on you to have a much stronger EU role for the long-term arrangements in Syria.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the title of today’s debate on the security situation in Syria carries with it the painful irony of reality because, colleagues, the reality is that there is no security in Syria. There is no security for the millions of civilians first bussed into the province and now besieged, bombed and starved in Idlib. There is only despair, destruction and death for the injured in the sixty-eight attacked hospitals, for the 373 killed, for the 700 000 refugees stuck in the freezing mud with no place to go, no clothes and no food. Once again the Syrian regime, and its Russian and Iranian backers, are using their inhumane tactics. By explicitly targeting civilians and hospitals, they act in direct violation of humanity. Colleagues, I hope one day soon we will see Bashar Assad in my city – the Hague – so some justice can at least be done to the suffering of millions of Syrians.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, since 2018 we have known that Idlib is under enormous pressure, a crucial bulwark of opposition to the Assad regime. America abandoned the Syrian people in October last year. And Europe has failed to do anything for these democratic resistance groups, and we must dare to say that honestly. We are now in a hopeless conflict. Everyone is already saying it here: a proxy war between Russia and Turkey, with millions of people fleeing. The question of what Europe can and must do is, of course, easier to ask than answered. I'm very aware of that. But Europe, we must be honest about that, has left things to rot. Because we have given Putin and Trump free rein, and that is why we are now in this very unsafe situation. What has been a matter for us, we must dare to say clearly, is the divisions in the Council. With, among other things, but not only the Italian government, which sought rapprochement with Assad. I do not blame the Italians, but I do not blame Europe for not achieving unity in this regard.  Europe can only contribute to a sustainable solution if we have one strategy, one strategy that we promote together. Time is running out, because both Turkey and Israel have reasons to loosen their grip on Assad. Europe must therefore come up with a new plan very quickly and increase its commitment, with the first goal for me - perhaps the first and only goal - a ceasefire. That's what the people, the kids are entitled to.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, nine years of mistakes and Europe perseveres. The European Union and many Member States have held radical positions on the Syrian conflict. On the one hand, at first, there was the good: the rebels; on the other, evil: the Syrian government. And then there was the reality: in a few weeks, the favorites of the West and the Americans were sidelined by the Islamic factions, because they represented little in the current conflict. In the rebel camps, attacks were being carried out against France, against minorities, especially Christians. Allegiance was changed to please Mr. Erdogan, sometimes the Saudi Wahhabis, the Muslim Brotherhood in Doha. The European Union wanted to put the white helmets forward; it is discovered that their command centre was next to those of the jihadists in Aleppo. France wanted to ignore the ideology of the groups concerned, it finds itself last week with the spokesman of Jaich al-Islam, who terrorized the Ghouta region, arrested in Marseille on an Erasmus visa. Then came the time of Putin's condemnation. Yet these bombs were as deadly as those of our coalition in Mosul or Raqqa. However, the jihadists in Idlib should now be preserved. But ladies and gentlemen, I remind you of the phrase in the Security Council report last July: Idlib is now the largest dump for foreign terrorist fighters in the world. Yes, we must preserve civilians. But today, what do we do with these terrorists? We don't want to take them back in Europe. Excuse me, either we take them back to Europe, if they are nice rebels, and no one wants them, or we let the Syrian government do what any government on its territory would do, namely: take back control of its territory and bring peace by exterminating the rebels.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her All those people who have not yet made it out of Syria have fled to Idlib. Three million are trapped there – locked in a proxy war on the backs of the most vulnerable. Civilians are being targeted, hospitals and schools are being bombed, cluster munitions are being used – what is happening in Idlib right now is the right of the cruellest. Yes, the EU is providing humanitarian aid. This is important and it must continue. But it can do more: full of diplomatic commitment to a ceasefire, documentation of war crimes, extension of sanctions to those responsible in Russia and Turkey, and yes, quotas for the most vulnerable, should they ever make it out of Idlib. Mr Borrell, no one has this comprehensive political solution for Syria. But that is precisely why it is so important that we also take the small steps that we can take consistently to counter the cruelty in Syria. I hope that we will also take a big step forward in this regard at the Council of Foreign Ministers on Monday.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, Honourable High Representative, I hear from many of you questions about what Europe should do and why it does nothing. Dear, you know perfectly well that nothing can be done on your part, and that none of your governments will do anything. As long as you sell arms to Saudi Arabia. As long as you turn a blind eye to a dictator like Erdogan. As long as you pretend there are moderate Islamists, there is nothing you will do but this debate here, which is pure and simple washing of a guilty conscience and wasting time.  Because, dear, you know perfectly well that "moderate" Islamists are cutting the heads of Christians in Syria. You know perfectly well that these groups that fund your governments are actually war criminals. As long as you support them, there's nothing you can do, I'm sorry. You're wasting your time, you're wasting your time on European taxpayers.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mr Borrell, we do not need Pilates. The tragedy in Syria is now indescribable and every new aspect of it is even more embarrassing. The latest incident takes place in Indib, where seven hundred Syrian students have been kidnapped by Turkish-backed terrorist forces. Others are drugged and others fanked and thrown into the war meat grinder. One million people have been added to refugee flows. The seat belt that Tayyip Erdoğan, the ruthless Erdoğan, would create has opened the gates of hell. Do you hear what's going on? We're not talking about cold numbers, we're talking about people, we're talking about young children who have dreams and souls. Or is that not accounted for? In Syria, the boy of Europe is judged; in the Eastern Mediterranean, the prestige of humanity is judged. Do we take all this into account or leave it to evil minds or to evil, demonic, so-called "agreements of the century"?

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, more than three hundred and seventy dead and almost 600,000 displaced in the last two months. These are the overwhelming numbers of reality in northwestern Syria, the scene of a devastating humanitarian catastrophe in a country destroyed by nine years of conflict that has exposed survivors to atrocious suffering. Indiscriminate attacks hit the civilian population and key infrastructure, despite constant calls for an end to hostilities. Displaced populations are now living in lack of shelter and basic property. It is imperative to continue the provision of humanitarian assistance to the population while employing the necessary efforts for a sustainable agreement, in accordance with UN Security Council Resolution 2254. Mr Borrell and Commissioner Lenarčič have called for the necessary humanitarian corridors and security conditions for teams to assist people. I would like to know what answer they have received to this appeal.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Page February 2019, you mentioned it, Mr Borrell, the conflict has flared up again. There are over a million displaced people, and since December 2019, you have to face this, Idlib province and its surroundings have been bombed almost daily by the regime of Bashar al-Assad, supported by the Russian air force. Since Friday evening, Turkey has brought more than 600 military vehicles across the common border. It is feared that the situation will continue to escalate and that there will be a direct military confrontation between Syria and Turkey. More than 500 000 people have fled to Syria since December alone, 80% of whom are women and children. This expulsion is one of the largest since the conflict began in 2011.  Since then, the conflict has continued – almost nine years. Over 400 000 people have been killed during this period, including 22 000 children, and we Europeans are still watching.  We must now work for a ceasefire, to protect the refugees, to demand a political solution to the conflict, as you too say, Mr Borrell. But what is this supposed to be? Is a Blue Helmet mission the right way? I would also like to remind you that we have a responsibility towards the Kurds and Yazidis in the region and a moral duty.

name: Ivan DAVID
text: – Madam President, the key issue in the situation in Syria is Turkey's position of power and negotiating position. The EU is weak and subject to corruption because it is dominated by multinational corporations, which have significant investments in Turkey. The EU is blackmailable and blackmailed. The EU will not allow really effective trade sanctions against Turkey, but it has helped Turkey with sanctions against Syria. The EU will not even allow accession interviews with Turkey to be cancelled. While the EU has cancelled €150 million in pre-accession aid, it has also increased payments for non-release of immigrants by EUR 500 million. That is why Turkey is doing what it wants in Syria, and it will continue to do so until it encounters resistance.  Turkey has militarily occupied northern Syria, expelled nearly a million Kurds and Christians and others, and is ousting Islamic State veterans there. Nor is the EU able to stand up for its member countries and prevent Turkey from stealing gas, in the ancient occupation of northern Cyprus. The EU is responsible for the situation in Syria, but offers moral positions.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Madam President, the situation in Syria is dire. The conflict has killed almost 400 000 people since 2011. This is an entrenched conflict rife with opposing interests and objectives. A solution must be found. The suffering of the Syrian people and the risk to long-term global stability have been too great for too long. The EU and its Member States have provided more than 17 billion in aid and the Council has targeted sanctions in place. But these are sticking plasters on a gaping wound. EU Member States, the US and other international players must do everything they can to push for de-escalation and the freezing of this conflict so that a cease-fire can be honoured and a fragile peace can be maintained. Europe’s influence in achieving this aim will be severely diminished if it cannot speak with one voice at both an EU or NATO level. There are no elegant solutions available, simply the urgent need for pragmatism and diplomatic determination. Let’s do this.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Madam President! The revolution in Syria started as a popular uprising against a brutal dictatorship. The insurgency was met with extreme repression from the Assad regime, and the insurgency was let down by Europe. Now Syria has become a battleground for regional and global powers. Turkish President Erdogan is using extreme Islamist militias for ethnic cleansing and conquest in northwestern Syria. Putin and the Iranian cleric are using the Assad regime for war crimes and mass murder.  Mr Borrell, the European Union must speak out against Erdogan, Putin and Assad. Mr Borrell, the European Union must support the Kurds and the pro-democracy forces in their fight against Daesh and the Assad regime. Let us recognise the autonomy of north-eastern Syria diplomatically. Let us impose economic sanctions on Erdogan until he stops the invasion, and let us demand the deployment of UN peacekeepers so that the civilian population in northwestern Syria can be protected from ethnic cleansing and abuse. Mr Borrell, it's time for action!  (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Mick WALLACE
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I’d just like to ask the last speaker, does he not accept the role that the EU, the US, Saudi Arabia, UAE have played in destabilising the region? Do you not accept the fact that this is a war made by interference by these powers? You arm the jihadists with the hope that they destabilise Syria; you went for regime change. It’s a nonsense to suggest that the Kurds are even fighting the Syrians. The Kurds have their problems with Turkey, not with Assad’s regime. It’s absolute nonsense. The EU has blood on its hands.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: blue-card answer. – Of course there is due political interest in Syria, but as we all saw, there was a peaceful demonstration by hundreds of thousands of civilians in Syria demanding freedom and democracy, and that cry for help was met with brutal oppression from the Assad regime. What shall we do?  The EU must stand on the side of the Kurds and the pro-democratic forces in Syria to fight for democracy and freedom. That’s the only way we can have stability and peace in Syria and in the Middle East.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, the war in Syria has been going on for nine years, and the escalation of violence in and around the city of Idlib has resulted, in addition to Yemen, with the worst humanitarian crisis in the region. Nearly 400,000 people have had to flee their homes since December last year due to the conflict between the Turkish and Syrian armies. Most were not the first time, 80% of these refugees are the most vulnerable groups, women and children. 53 healthcare institutions have had to stop working, and among refugee children, less than a quarter are in the education system. The number of civilian casualties is rising. A total of 2,800,000 people need humanitarian assistance. The humanitarian crisis is being sharpened by winter conditions. The Geopolitical Commission and the European Union, as the world's single promoter of peace, stability, dialogue, must take over from the passive observer the role of active proponent of solutions. That's our role. We need to intensify our talks with the parties to the conflict, but offer a multilateral platform to reach an agreement. To begin with, let's also consider for this case the format of the recent Brussels conference, which nevertheless achieved some results in the case of Libya.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Madam President, Mr High Representative, dear colleague, I invite you all to watch the videos posted on social media in recent days by Bashar al-Assad's soldiers. We see them destroying graves, digging up bodies, having fun with their victim's head. You can see them laughing - and that fat laugh is a spit in the face of the world. Currently, in the Idlib region, the Butcher of Damascus and his Russian sponsors are razing hospitals, schools, bakeries, and we are letting them do what we have let them do for nine years.  And today, what do I hear? I hear here in this chamber, some of them praising the regime and urging the extermination of the rebels. So let me express my shame and indignation and ask you, Mr High Representative, to never give in to these sirens of normalization with the Assad regime. Let us not forget who the victims are and who are the executioners, and let us not forget that Bashar al-Assad's place is before the International Criminal Court.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, in relation to Syria, we must understand that the European Union has gone through several stages. The first stage of the Union's position towards Syria was when the European Union instantly wanted the head of Bashar al Assad. In the last 2-3 years we have come to say: we will judge him, we do not want his head, but to hold elections in Syria. That shows inconsistency.  In fact, we hesitated from the very beginning to intervene, we did not know how to make the French stop and today we complain about what is in Syria. Syria will remain under Russian control, that's the truth. We complain that Turkey is entering northern Syria. Any state would have entered to protect its border.  So, colleagues, as long as we don't understand that being part of the decision means participating, we're going to sit back and mourn what a disaster it is in Syria. Either we intervene and let the French do it very well, or if not, we must abstain, because we are responsible.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, thank you to the high representative for his approach to the question of Syria. I will not repeat: attacks on civilians in northwestern Syria, deaths, atrocities. Many Members of this House have said so. Of course, we condemn it and insist on the need to ensure access to humanitarian aid, but it is true that we seem to be faced with a situation in which we cannot intervene more effectively and effectively. In the case of Libya, the European Union has been successful in declaring an arms embargo, and the high representative pushed for the Europeans to monitor this embargo at sea. It is clear that the Syrian regime has armaments and ammunition. The question we might have to try to answer is whether we can promote an arms embargo on Bashar al-Asad's regime.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are dealing with great drama and thousands of problems. I wanted to talk about three. Firstly, we are facing a humanitarian crisis and more than one million refugees fleeing hostilities towards Turkey. These people are at the Turkish border. Secondly, with the illegal Turkish invasion of Syria, which neither prevents hostilities nor plays any role in humanitarian aid. Thirdly, turkey's arming of al-Qaeda's successors in Syria and other terrorist organisations. Because turkey is here every time, this is an indication to the European Union to negotiate and put pressure on Turkey. It is also necessary to strongly oppose the persecution of the Kurdish population, mass displacement, looting and war crimes perpetrated by armed and Turkish-paid jihadists in this highly experienced nation.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, let me be clear, Mr Borrell, I am not at all an admirer of the Assad regime, whose hands are drenched in blood. But, listening to some of the views today, I think there is a confusion. I thought until now that we had taken a unanimous decision, that our goal and the goal of the West, the civilized world, is to neutralize the Islamic State and the jihadists. If that's changed, some people might say it in public.  So the question is who is funding the jihadists? Who sends troops to continue their massacres? Who's been funding them for years? He has a name; he is the neo-sultan in Ankara and his name is Recep Erdoğan. That is our big problem and those who say it are not because we forgive Assad's crimes. It is because we have the courage to tell the truth; because we believe in European values.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr Representative, I would like to thank you for your comments. I agree with what you said at the beginning, that there is a humanitarian catastrophe in Syria, as well as in neighbouring countries. There are about 10,000 orphans in Aleppo alone that require immediate support. My country is getting involved. In addition to contributions to the European Union's agendas, as we have committed ourselves, it also commits additional resources to humanitarian aid, particularly in Syria, Lebanon and Jordan. That is why I think what you have said (that support is an investment) is important, but we must be told today, and it is very important that the Union is the largest donor.  I would also like to say that we have information that out of one and a half million Christians in Syria there are only just over two hundred thousand left and their situation is very dramatic. It is necessary to bet on NGOs, on missionaries, on those people of the Church who are there conducting a great help campaign, prosthetic children, on medical assistance. This is a great appeal to the whole world, and Bashar al-Assad has actually already won this war.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, this debate comes at a time when the Syrian Arab army and its allies are advancing at a great pace in the provinces of Aleppo and Idlib, regaining control over regions occupied by terrorist organisations. But what this debate is looking for here in Strasbourg is aligned with what is happening on the ground, with the entry of a Turkish military convoy into Idlib and the Israeli missile attack, and it is nothing more than protecting terrorists, securing control over Syrian natural resources, questioning the legitimacy of the Syrian authorities and the integrity of their territory and occupying that geostrategic region. The interests of imperialism are contrary to the defence of human rights and international law and are expressed, as in this Parliament, in an absolutely hypocritical way. The resolution of this conflict calls for an end to destabilization and external aggression against the Arab Republic of Syria, the defence of its sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity and respect for international law and the Charter of the United Nations.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, the Syrian army is making progress against the Turkey- and US-backed jihadists in Idlib Province. The Syrian Government is restoring its own borders and finding troves of US-made weapons as the jihadists flee. Idlib Province was controlled by Al Qaeda local affiliates for years. These genocidal fanatics were armed, trained and given logistical assistance by the US, Britain, Turkey, France, Saudi Arabia and the UAE under Obama’s Timber Sycamore programme. This  helped prolong the war for several years and resulted in hundreds of thousands of deaths that were unnecessary. The EU is now calling for unrestricted access for humanitarian aid to Idlib Province. You are imposing sanctions that are causing untold hardship on the Syrian people. You let these jihadists into the place: why won’t you take them back out of it? You do not want them now. You were offered them; you won’t take them.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, there’s no doubt about it, the Syrian people have been suffering for nine years and more. But why did it happen? Because the discontent of the people against the Assad Government was hijacked by international players to try and achieve regime change. Armed by the US and some EU Member States, jihadists poured into their country through Turkey. And ten years on, they weren’t able to overthrow the government, who have regained control. And as they regained control they settled with people: some agreed to come back to the Government, some didn’t and went to Idlib. So this day was always going to come. And there is an irony, when we talk about foreign fighters who came from countries here, and we won’t take them back, but we expect the Syrians to deal with them. The key issue here is ending the sanctions, sitting down with the Syrian Government, and restoring peace in that country. Take responsibility for Europe’s role in this disaster and acknowledge the role of the Syrian Government in stopping the jihadists and the rise of ISIS.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, thank you to all the Members of Parliament who have participated in this debate. I can only tell you that I understand and share the sense of frustration of many of your interventions because, in the face of the Syrian crisis, the truth is that the European Union has been powerless. And as much as we say "they must cease, they must, they should, should, il faut, il faut, they should, they should," what leverage, with what strength, with what capacity can we act on actors?  We have spent many years saying that there was no military solution to the conflict in Syria and, in the end, there has been a military solution. There is. Whose side? On the part of those who are able to use military force. And Europe is not in that situation. We will then continue to urge everyone to stop attacks on civilians, to stop access to humanitarian aid, to respect the rules and obligations of international humanitarian law, to protect civilians. But we all know that this is a statement of principles that is not based on a coercive force that allows it to be made a reality. What has happened in Syria is a great lesson for Europe. It's a great lesson for that geopolitical actor we say we want to be. And if we really want to be, we have to take the necessary measures and have the means to do so. Otherwise, we will continue to hold parliamentary sessions like this to continue saying "il faut, il faut, il faut".

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Tomas Tobé, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on a new comprehensive EU-Africa strategy (O-000007/2020 - B9-0006/2020) (2020/2500(RSP)).

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: author. – Madam President, the comprehensive EU-Africa strategy is a window of opportunity for a much needed fresh start for EU-Africa relations, and let us promise each other here today that we will now try to move forward beyond words and good intentions to concrete actions. Let us be strategically action-oriented and not waste any more time. A new strategy must recognise the strength and potential in the African economy, pursue the long-term strategic and mutual interests of the EU and our African partners, and support the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).  For the EU-Africa strategy to be successful, I believe that three things are necessary. Firstly, a clear vision of the end game, and a concrete plan to use a comprehensive approach with all available tools. Secondly, an awareness of what can be gained if we succeed in strengthening our partnership and what is at stake if we don’t. Thirdly, defining how we can better use aid-effectiveness tools at our disposal and that the Commission take a lead in coordinating all EU institutions and Member States.  There are plenty of mutually beneficial opportunities – economic growth, employment and trade. There are also immediate challenges – climate change, poverty, conflict and irregular migration. The high population growth that we see in Africa also means that poverty levels will continue to increase. In 2030, global poverty is expected to be almost exclusively centred in Africa. Conflicts tend to brew in countries facing poverty and with high levels of unemployment. On behalf of the Committee on Development, I have tabled a series of questions to the Commission and hopefully today we can get some clear answers. Firstly, how does the strategy effectively contribute to the implementation of the SDGs and the fundamental objectives of poverty eradication? What measures and what mechanisms will be put in place?  Secondly, how will the new strategy contribute to the strategic interests and common priorities of both partners with a view to good governance, human rights, the fight against inequalities, climate change, etc.? Thirdly, how will the Commission ensure the involvement of numerous stakeholders, like national parliaments, governments, local authorities, the private sector, civil society, in the design of the strategy?  And fourthly, let me also express some concern regarding the potential for overlaps. What I’m talking about is the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI), in which Africa is of course a priority, as well as the negotiations on the future of the ACP-EU Partnership Agreement. To be concrete, how will the Commission ensure consistency and avoid the risk of developing overlapping strategic frameworks?  Finally, development policy coherence is something that is in our Treaty obligations and it’s high time that we tried to deliver on that commitment. Therefore, I would like to know: how will you make sure to incorporate development policy coherence in the strategy design. To conclude, from the colleagues in the Committee on Development: we do look forward to working together with the Commission. We have a huge task in front of us but also great opportunities. Let’s get the work started together.

name: Jutta Urpilainen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking you for inviting me to discuss such a milestone in Europe—Africa relations as the new EU strategy for Africa. As I committed during my hearing to do my utmost to strengthen and deepen the cooperation between the Commission and the European Parliament, I am glad to exchange with you here today.  How more appropriate for my first address to this Chamber than discussing our relationship with the African continent? I value your experience, knowledge and views and believe them to be important for a topic such as this one. On our first trip outside Europe, President von der Leyen and I went to Hear Africa. We experienced a continent of youth, brimming with confidence, full of potential and attractive for the global players. We met a partner that deserves a more positive engagement from us. We have already paved the way for change with the Africa—Europe Alliance for Sustainable Investment and Jobs, supported by the External Investment Plan for sustainable investments, and have achieved, in such a short amount of time, tangible progress. Now we can capitalise on those achievements and go further. It is time for a new chapter that brings a step change in our relationship. For that to happen, we need a new, comprehensive strategy, a strategy that supports Africa’s potential political economic governance efforts and moves to bolster peace and resilience, a strategy with Africa that ensures partners’ ownership and commitment, and a strategy that better positions the EU in the new global context, reflecting the aims of this geopolitical Commission and the ambitions of the European Green Deal.  The Abidjan priorities we set back in 2017 remain valid today. Our approach is not to change direction, but to step up a gear for better results. The strategy’s comprehensive character will be ensured by its inbuilt links with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the Paris Agreement on climate change, the EU Global Strategy, the European Consensus on Development and Agenda 2063 of the African Union.  We will continue to work on economic continental integration, human development, mobility and migration. Thematically, apart from addressing the climate and environmental challenges, we will focus on digitalisation and gender equality, which are major enablers for development. There cannot be development without solid governance, respect for human rights, the rule of law and democracy. Therefore, we will pursue our efforts in these areas, along with the fight for peace and security, and against extremism.  Finally, yet importantly, we would like to work closer with our African partners on the multilateral rule-based system that is being called into question more and more. A key priority through my mandate, I will ensure that the implementation of this strategy supports the power that youth represents. Young people, including young women, must also own this strategy. Work on the new ambitious framework is already ongoing, both at political and technical level. In the meantime, we continue listening and trying to ensure broad ownership of the strategy, both by yourselves and our Member States, as well as by our African partners and civil society, including young people.  We will hold an EU—AU ‘college to college’ meeting on 27 February in Ethiopia and a ministerial meeting in May. Both events will provide key opportunities for dialogue with our African partners. I intend to travel to Africa in February and March to consult as broadly as possible. The proposal for the new strategy will be on our college agenda for adoption in early March. That will mark the beginning of more concrete work with our key stakeholders.  I look forward to our debate and hearing your views on what you see as priority areas for a renewed Africa—EU partnership.

name: Hildegard BENTELE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Why do we need a new EU-Africa strategy? Because the EU Commission has explicitly defined itself as geopolitical for the first time and is committed as a whole to the implementation of the UN Sustainable Development Goals, because of the pressing problems of climate protection and migration, because the Cotonou Agreement has to be re-concluded and we have the Green Deal, because of the rapid development of digitisation and a new free trade area in Africa. These are all new realities that an EU-Africa strategy must address. In my view, it is important that we apply the whole toolbox of the EU and the Member States in a coherent manner and learn lessons from the past. This means, first and foremost, a focus on fair trade relations and the generation of tax incomes in African countries, educational opportunities, democracy and rule of law support, efficient administration and security structures, greater support for women and girls and the involvement of regional and local levels rather than mere traditional budget support. The aim must be for every African to have a secure perspective on life in his or her home country. We need responsibility, both on the part of the EU and on the part of Africa, for a genuine partnership that is mutually beneficial. Last year, our group chairman, Manfred Weber, made it very clear, among other things, with his proposal for an Africa Commissioner, the high priority of the EU-Africa issue for the PPE-DE. I hereby give you all the support and commitment that we will have put EU-Africa relations on a new and better footing at the end of this parliamentary term.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We are glad that you are right here and have a big heart for this new task. Yes – Europe, Africa, we are partners. And we are in a community of destiny, and we will solve our problems together over the next few years – or we will both fail. That is why the first consequence is a partnership on an equal footing. But when we say that, it means: not short-term national interests, not even supposed, short-term European interests, but a partnership for good training. Yes, let the girls go to school – especially the girls, at least for ten years – so that they can help their country; health care for all, good work – and that is more than employability – good work to build countries, to develop sustainable societies, both in Europe and in Africa.  This is our job, and we want to contribute from the heart and support you to the best of our ability.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Congo is the first French-speaking country in the world. Among the most widely spoken languages in Africa are Portuguese, French and English. Moreover, the European Union is by far Africa's largest partner in trade and development. Suffice to say that we, as the European Union, already have extremely close ties.  However, relying on maintaining the status quo could be extremely counterproductive. What we need is a comprehensive strategy covering both the political, security, development, economic and commercial fields. A real strategy of this magnitude must set clear goals over time, as well as a roadmap to achieve them. In fact, it is the transposition, in a way, of the Delors method that, in the 1990s, enabled the European Union to make considerable progress in our relations with the African continent. Today, development in Africa is clearly conditioned by Africans themselves, but also increasingly by China, India and Russia, which are fordesting increasing economic, political and military ties. It is against this backdrop that the European Union's cooperation with Africa must be asserted.  Why do we not have in common a security approach that allows the African Union to sit on the UN Security Council? Why not agree, now, on a common approach to climate change? What is finally expected to put on track trade cooperation to establish a free trade area between the Economic Union and the African Union? Africa must develop itself, of course, which does not preclue sharing our experiences.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, it is no coincidence that, at the turn of Brexit, London launched its UK-Africa summit on 20 January. This initiative reminds us of the extent to which the European Union is in danger of losing further ground, since it is deprived of its British ally, a major diplomatic and trade player on this continent. Especially as similar summits multiply from Russia to China to Japan, with last week's African tour of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. In this context, the vague promises of partnership on an equal footing come a little late, especially since, from unfair fisheries agreements to the desire for increased political interference in Africa, there is no evidence of this so-called new diplomatic and trade departure. But the most appalling thing is the wait-and-see attitude on the migration emergency, which is crucial in the eyes of so many Europeans. The oral question even called for the expansion of the Erasmus programme, even though it is well known that a new African immigration channel will be opened up. In short, the Union is about to repeat the failure of Cotonou, with a lost decade.

name: Pierrette HERZBERGER-FOFANA
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, the partnership between the European Union and Africa is based on a common strategy that underlines new policy cooperation on a negotiated, equal-shared value-based basis. The new agreements on this strategy were concluded at the European Union-Africa Summit in Abidjan in 2017 by the heads of state, who focused on their priorities.  They identified four priorities for joint action, including investment in human capital, resilience, peace, good governance and investment in structures for sustainable development and migration. This choice of cooperation is also a way of distancing itself from the paternalistic relations that have so far prevailed. In addition to the negotiations on economic relations and development, the new aspect of the strategy is added.  However, this new initiative supported by the European Commission raises many questions: how will poverty be eradicated? How can we stop the big words that hinder development and give a safe perspective to young people and women, who make up 60% of the population on this continent?

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Commissioner, we urgently need, above all, a new Union-ACP strategy. We should face new challenges, particularly the problem of migration. Young people migrate from Africa and other ACP countries because their access to education, personal development and decent living is limited. Therefore, today we should ask ourselves and look for answers to them. What do ACP youth need? First of all, good education. The best investment is investment in education. Insufficient access to it is a real obstacle to economic development and the eradication of poverty. So let us focus on education and support the entrepreneurship of young people. Let us give them access to microcredit. The European Union should establish an easy, simple, effective mechanism that will allow young people to set up businesses in their countries of origin. They want to build the prosperity of their homelands.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, it is clear that the European Union needs a new strategy for Africa. The problem is that Europe seems to want a strategy that responds to the interests of its multinationals and political elites and not to the development goals and interests of African social majorities. Why? Let's not cheat. Migration, security, trade or investment are actually the Geopolitical agenda of the European Union.  What Africa and Europe need is a lasting relationship based on human rights, social development and environmental sustainability. And to do so, such strategies cannot be tools of European trade or securitarian interests, but we need to turn our policies around 180 degrees, so that they are consistent from a rights approach. Let us begin by practicing fair trade with Africa, opening up legal and secure avenues for migration and requiring European companies to comply with their tax obligations and with respect for labour rights and human rights.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome the European Commission's choice to assert itself as a geopolitical Commission and to choose relations with Africa to demonstrate this option in practice. The European Union needs, in order to successfully position itself in the changing geopolitical framework, to continue to play its role as a multilateral power that promotes partnerships between equals. The strategic partnership with Africa must contain the tools to respond to peoples' concerns in a framework of respect for human rights. Be aligned with the achievement of the objectives of sustainable development in all its dimensions. Bet on the empowerment and strengthening of civil society. Ensure consistency and close articulation of this strategy with the post-Cotonou agreement that it is one of the pillars and ensure the valorization and involvement of parliaments, in particular by maintaining the parliamentary dimension of the ACP-European Union partnership and the european parliament's relations with the Pan-African Parliament. This is a path of success that together we will follow.

name: Chrysoula ZACHAROPOULOU
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let us look at Africa in 2020: it has a new face, that of its youth and its women. Africa is ready to meet the challenges it faces, and the choice it will make today will have a decisive impact on the future of the world. Let us now look at the Europe of 2020: a continent of values and experience, but also a continent that, more than ever, needs allies. Europe needs a strong and proud Africa, just as Africa needs a united Europe that speaks to it with one voice. This is the condition for sustaining multilateralism and achieving sustainable development goals. Commissioner, the new strategy will have to embody a re-founded relationship between our two continents. We must put a definitive end to the postcolonial era and this narrative. Our African partners are looking for a relationship of equals. We Europeans also want to write this new page with them and develop a strategy not for Africa, but with Africa. We also have another duty, that of enabling Europeans to understand Africa in all its diversity, and no longer from the perspective of migration alone. Commissioner, the new title of your portfolio, 'International Partnerships', opens this new page in our history. As a parliamentarian, I am proud to write it with you, with the Council, with our African allies and with all my colleagues.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, since the end of the colonial period and the independence of African countries, the Union has increased cooperation agreements with Africa. We had, of course, the Yaounde and Lomé agreements, the Cotonou agreement, and so on, but most of these agreements, let's face it, were certainly likely to define our relationship with Africa, but above all often there to maintain our influence and interests on the continent.  The record, after half a century of cooperation, is not brilliant. It is not brilliant if you look at the development indices, if you look at economic diversification, if you look at inequality, or security on the African continent. Far be it from me to abandon our relationship with Africa, and I welcome the initiative of the future European Union-Africa strategy, but it goes without saying that we must be more coherent and more transparent.  Consistency in the various instruments we have, and that is the work we have to do under the NDCI, but also consistency with our policies. We can no longer, for example, defend a trade relationship that does not promote regional development and destroys local agriculture for the benefit of European farmers. Transparency and governance will also be needed, so yes to a Union-Africa strategy, but avoiding the mistakes of the past.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the African continent is not just the continent of immigration, it is the continent of the future, of young people and women, who are stepping harder and stepping further. I believe that this new strategy with Europe has to be a green strategy. The fight against climate change and clean energy needs to be at the heart of our new relationship with the African continent.  In the last century, Africa has contributed only 2% of emissions to global warming. Today, however, it suffers the worst consequences. The effects of climate change are a reality, and it is precisely in Africa that the greatest number of people die as a result of droughts and floods. Therefore, adaptation, resilience, clean energy, renewable energy have to occupy a central element in our new relationship. Europe needs more resources, but above all it needs more responsibility on the part of the European Union.

name: Giuliano PISAPIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in today's debate only one word has been said several times: the word 'migration'. While I recognise its scope and the challenges that go with it, I am convinced that social, economic and democratic development is and must be the priority objective. Reducing it to a mere means of curbing migration is what makes our strategy weak, hypocritical and ineffective. Peace, rights and development are the DNA of the European Union. Let us share them with the African people and avoid the mistakes of the past. European funds must be invested for the growth of the continent and not for financing the lagers that stain our consciences. 2020 could and should be the turning point in relations between the European Union and Africa.  I will end with the words of Nelson Mandela: 'No one was born a slave, neither lord nor to live in misery, but we were all born to be brothers'.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: – Madam President, firstly, I would like to thank Commission President von der Leyen for undertaking her first international trip to the African Union – an important signal. Africa and Europe are at a crossroads, and we need to change our mindset, it is time to see each other as equals. We have the most promising continent right at our doorstep. Highly promising initiatives are being taken, and the African Continental Free Trade Area is the latest example of this. This ambitious project can transform Africa into a bastion of multilateralism. I call on the European Commission to do everything it can to support and facilitate the creation of the African Continental Free Trade Area. The upcoming paper from the Commission should reflect this and contain a number of concrete measures on this. It is very much in our own interest to have a united African Union. We should embrace it when others seek to unite themselves, especially in times when certain forces are out there to defeat us. The partnership between the European Union and the African countries should be one of equals.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, Africa, this neighbouring continent, has to be a priority. We must contribute to their peace and security, to their development, to the improvement of the institutions of African countries and also to the formation of their youth. And it is also important that migration flows from Africa are ordered. It is a continent, as is well known, with a huge demographic challenge. We need a new strategy for Africa and also that next semester's EU-Africa summit is an important milestone. I would like to refer to the southern bank of the Mediterranean, to our nearest southern neighbourhood. It is the 25th birthday of the so-called Barcelona Process, but we have not been able to build that space of shared prosperity, stability and freedom that we were looking for. I daresay that, in some cases even, the presence of the European Union has receded. Which foreign powers are in Syria? Who has the prominence in Libya? Does the European Union play any role in the Middle East peace process? Answers don't help optimism. I stress that we must redouble our efforts in Africa and, in particular, in the southern Mediterranean.

name: Maria-Manuel LEITÃO-MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Africa is now the youngest continent in the world. As with us, digital technologies arouse curiosity and create opportunities. Opportunities to find new solutions to old problems. To combat female genital mutilation, through an app like kenya's young women here showed. For financial inclusion, through virtual currency, with mobile phone, such as MPESA, in Kenya and Mozambique. To reduce the gender imbalance in the area of technology, with the Miss Geek Africa pageant or the Tech needs girls in Ghana. The focus on the digital economy, the prevention of the risks it entails, investment in training, the training of young people and women in STEM are therefore as fundamental in Africa as in the European Union. This strategy must therefore promote and strengthen our partnerships, also in the area of digital transition. We must look to Africa as a partner, with needs, challenges and opportunities equal to ourown.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Thank you for your new approach and new strategy for Africa. This strategy is extremely necessary. We discussed this in the DEVE Committee and thank you. It focuses as in the lens: tribal wars, unemployment, poverty, lack of prospects for young people, which is unfortunately a source of illegal immigration. A very important phenomenon that is still being observed today in Africa is, above all, trafficking in human beings.  In Poland, last Friday we started a great collection campaign, through two organizations: The Church in Need and the HAART Foundation, to support those who are liberating from this powerful process. We know that there is also a need for such assistance for children who are sold into captivity. These are often also five-year-old girls who are sold into sexual slavery. There are countries like Kenya where there are fairs and people are still being sold. A young boy costs three hundred dollars. Commissioner, I think it is worth including this issue in our strategy for Africa, the Union's strategy. It must not be the case that we will be active where trafficking in human beings is legalised.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Urpilainen, I think it is very important that Africa is approached through a genuine equal and equal partnership. It must be a genuine partnership in the fields of education, trade and climate change solutions. Africa and its development are in many ways a key issue for the future of the whole world, but Africa as a continent is so vast and large – as broad as the important issue of Mr Tobé, so it would take a week to discuss it.  I would like to raise one point that I hope to see in the future strategy as strong and concrete, namely the position of women and girls. Improving the position of women will increase the potential for development in all sectors. As in Europe, no continent or country will survive if it does not include the other half of the population. The position of women also improves the position of girls, access to school, sexual health and also family planning, where the number of children is a free and positive choice, not dictated by necessity. I hope that this, Commissioner Urpilainen, will be strongly reflected in the future strategy.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I welcome your statement when you said you went with Ms von der Leyen to Africa, to Hear Africa. I think that was a very important trip and, as you said, it’s a continent full of youth, confidence and potential. I think it’s very important at this stage that we would review and have a look at the cooperation and the operations between the European Union and Africa. I think there has been success there but now, in times when we have developed sustainable development goals, when we have the Paris Climate Change Agreement, it is time for a renewed focus on that relationship. I particularly think the issues around high-level unemployment is somewhere where Europe can act in facilitating and supporting job development and creation. I have visited the continent myself on a number of occasions in the previous mandate, and there is certainly a lot that Europe can do in supporting indigenous industries, in developing jobs there, and certainly through education also. So at this point, I think it’s very positive for Europe that we would develop with our neighbours, Africa, a renewed strategy.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I think the EU strategy on Africa can be loosely summed up as a lot of very nice soft language – we talk about empowerment, we talk about development, we talk about equality – but really in many ways they are just a figleaf for the imposition of neoliberal globalisation. We see it in many of the trade arrangements, where the least-developed countries in the ACP lose their non-reciprocal tariff exemptions and preferences, but meanwhile European, particularly the agricultural file and so on, keeps its protectionist mechanisms that we have adopted for ourselves. I think that neoliberal trade agreements aren’t the only feature of an unbalanced EU-Africa relationship. I think of particular concern is the growing military presence in that area, particularly in the Sahel, led by the French, backing up as a permanent aid to dictators in that region in order to try and support their French interests in raw materials and cheap labour. That isn’t good enough when we’re talking about equality.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Dear Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The new EU-Africa strategy must be adapted to the changing political and environmental situation. Its foundation, as well as the basis of any mutual relations and agreements, must be human rights and democracy. In order to promote freedom of expression and introduce democratic standards, it is necessary to deepen political dialogue and cooperation with the African Union. Actions to improve security, peace, poverty reduction, a good education and health system, the fight against terrorism and trafficking in human beings should be at the heart of the strategy. To this end, financial assistance must be mobilised for countries facing these fundamental problems. We must not forget climate action. The European Union should continue to support the African renewable energy initiative.

name: Jutta Urpilainen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, let me thank you for this constructive exchange. I have to say that I’m confident in our ability to build a new strategic and fruitful partnership with Africa which is focused on sustainable development. Your contribution to the strategy is key in the process of shaping its basis. The Commission, together with the European External Action Service, are still drafting the strategy in order to make it as comprehensive as possible. Dear Members of Parliament, please be assured your comments here today have been noted. I am especially happy that so many of you mentioned youth and young people. The strategy will constitute a significant change in strengthening our partnership with Africa. The strategy will work towards fighting global challenges that both our continents simply cannot, and must not, ignore. 2020 will be a pivotal year for the Africa-Europe partnership. We agreed with the ACP chief negotiator, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Togo, Professor Robert Dussey, that we will aim at closing the post-Cotonou negotiations by the end of March, and we will hold in the run up to the African Union-European Union summit a number of side events, with the main stakeholders all providing opportunities to design our partnership together. We will also strive to ensure that we will dispose of the right means to implement our policies by facilitating the agreement of the MMF in good time. We need to join forces as institutions to deliver on these important milestones. Only together – only together – we can create sustainable safe and peaceful communities in which our planet can recover and all of us can learn, work, grow and build fulfilling lives. I am really looking forward to continuing our fruitful exchange.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Kinga GÁL
