text: Writing. – Europe's security and future depend on the African continent. Our goal must be to keep the Sahel stable. All political, economic and humanitarian assistance should be given to the countries concerned, which are custodians of the preservation of stability and preventing the spread of crises. Infrastructure improvements are needed to improve the quality of life of locals and, more specifically, the functioning of health, irrigation, food and water management systems in the countries concerned. For example, by giving water purification equipment to a particular community, we can contribute to improving the quality of life of thousands of people. Hungary is at the forefront of efforts in the field through the humanitarian aid programme Hungary Helps, with a €16 million ugandan drinking water development programme setting an example to follow. The EU should use its resources to address the roots of the migration crisis, because it is necessary to help where there is trouble, not to bring trouble to Europe. In the knowledge of a liveable African vision, people would not go to Europe risking their own lives and that of their children. African problems can only be solved in Africa, and Europe must take the lead in helping the African population stay in place.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. - Madam Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Even with the population of Africa, its geographical situation and the ongoing political transformation of its countries, Europe must be its primary strategic partner and ally. At present, the biggest challenge linking the two continents is migration. In order to address the root causes of migration, we must, above all, help to create security in African countries and contribute to the eradication of poverty, job creation and, in short, sustainable development. Education must be the primary means of doing this. Access to quality education is the key to simultaneously and horizontally in effect on different sectors. Through education, we enable people from developing countries to help their own communities locally in their home countries. In addition to primary and secondary education, we must also remember tertiary education, which is the engine of innovation. Scholarship programmes are the best way to help in this area, Hungary does so. The new comprehensive EU-Africa Strategy should provide a solution to address the root causes of emigration and contribute to sustainable development, both economically and socially, in Africa. For this purpose, the Commission will have in its hands the main resource group, the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI), which will allocate nearly EUR 30 billion to the development of the sub-Saharan region. I trust that this huge resource will be able to help us stay in Africa.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union's relations with african countries have a very long history dating back to the Treaty establishing the European Economic Community.  Africa is currently undergoing a dynamic geopolitical and economic transformation, taking an increasingly important position in international politics. This is the right time to try to balance our engagement in the region and signal the direction of possible changes. I am therefore very pleased with the vision of our future cooperation contained in the EU-Africa Strategy. We should build it on our common values and develop economic relations on a partnership basis. Our common goal is to ensure security and prosperity. An example of a country with great potential to develop our cooperation in this area is Zambia, which recorded impressive economic growth in 2004-2014, reaching an average of 7.4% per year.  African countries are now giving us great room to develop our activities, including in the areas of agriculture, research and education. However, we must ensure that the implementation of the EU-Africa Strategy does not leave anyone behind. I hope that we will do our best to increase the amount of strategic investment and to strengthen the role of the private sector in job creation.  I would like to highlight the extremely important role of investing in human capital through the development of education, the promotion of local entrepreneurship and innovative solutions. It is human capital that is the key to Africa's development.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the fact that the New EU-Africa Strategy will be developed in cooperation with African countries, i.e. based on the principles of equality, partnership and shared responsibility. This means that we are able to learn from the past when the donor-recipient relationship has not worked. I also hope that it will be based on an in-depth and extensive consultation with civil society, which is aware of the real problems on the ground and will be more involved in the implementation of aid projects.  We have many challenges ahead of us that we would like to address. Let us ensure that the strategy is consistent with development policies, complementary to the new Cotonou Partnership Agreement and contributes to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. The overarching objective of development policy is to eradicate poverty and this should, above all, serve.  We also face new challenges, such as climate change, which will have an impact on the development of migration policy and humanitarian aid. Peace and security should therefore be an important pillar of the strategy. Together, we must ensure that the environment is protected, including access to clean water, renewable energy sources, and that we have wide access to education. Our activities should activate and involve young people! The strategy is the basis for mutual relations and its implementation requires an increase in ODA, our task is to include these commitments in the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on the fight against anti-Semitism, racism and hatred in Europe (2020/2561(RSP)).

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, having recently celebrated the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, this discussion is today more important than ever. For several years now, a worrying increase in the number of manifestations of hate speech, hate crimes, racism, xenophobia and intolerance in Europe has been observed, affecting minorities and other vulnerable groups, including Jewish people. In particular, we note with strong concern that anti-Semitic hatred remains widespread. Let me be clear on this: there is no justification for this phenomenon and we are obliged to take such issues extremely seriously.  There are a number of legal instruments that offer protection against racism and related forms of intolerance. All EU Member States have accepted the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. The EU’s Charter of Fundamental Rights also prohibits discrimination on the grounds of race, colour, ethnic origin and religion or belief.  The EU has furthermore adopted specific legislation on combating intolerance and hatred. I refer in particular to the 2008 Framework Decision on combating racism and xenophobia. In June 2016, the Council invited Member States to ensure the effective transposition and implementation of the Framework Decision and other relevant hate-crime laws at national level. In addition, it asked Member States to develop effective methods to report and ensure proper recording of hate crimes.  On 6 December 2018, the EU Member State Governments also sent a clear message by adopting a Council Declaration on the fight against anti—Semitism and the development of a common security approach to better protect Jewish communities and institutions in Europe. The Council notes that anti-Semitic hatred remains widespread and invites EU Member States to take measures to tackle anti-Semitism and improve the security of Jewish communities.  Social media is one of the main vehicles enabling hate speech to go viral. One possible remedy against this epidemic is a harmonised and determined European response. In this area, the Council conclusions on the application of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, adopted in October 2017, welcomed the measures coordinated by the Commission’s High Level Group on combating racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance. We also welcome and support the ongoing EU level dialogue with major IT companies, and address hate speech online, including through the implementation of the Code of Conduct launched in 2016 by the Commission for this purpose. Last but not least, we should remember and commend the remarkable work done by the Fundamental Rights Agency in this field.  The countermeasures I have mentioned so far would, however, be insufficient without recognising the important role of education and youth work, and, more precisely, the need to develop democratic resilience, media literacy, tolerance, critical thinking and conflict resolution skills in the learning process.  It is important to bear in mind that the measures in place to fight hate crime can only fulfil their potential if victims report hate motivated harassment and violence to the police, and if police officers record such incidents as hate crimes. According to the Fundamental Rights Agency, only a fraction of victims report hate motivated harassment and violence and, when they do, police officers do not always recognise them as hate crimes. Fortunately, Member States are increasingly introducing measures to address this issue. This includes providing relevant guidance for police officers, requiring the collection of detailed data on crime and working with civil society organisations experienced in dealing with hate crime.  In short, the responsibility rests with all of us – politicians, teachers, civil servants, students, parents and, where appropriate, judges and prosecutors – not to close our eyes or ears and pretend not to see injustice, discrimination or hatred. From the horrors of Auschwitz, the world learned its lesson and built an order of peace, founded upon human rights and international law. We are all committed to defending this.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, two weeks ago we commemorated in Brussels the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz-Birkenau. Holocaust survivor Liliana Segre shared with us her moving story about the evils of humanity she confronted as a young girl. She reminded us that hatred, racism and anti-Semitism is still today haunting European societies and endangering our diverse societies and the minorities in our midst.  It is the duty of the EU to prevent history from repeating itself and to uphold the values upon which the Union is based. The Holocaust has shown us where anti-Semitism and racism can lead and its memory is at the very core of the European project of a Europe that protects its Jewish communities and all other minorities.  We have seen that fear and hatred against ‘the other’ has become normalised in recent years. It flourishes in mainstream media, in political debate and in the online world. It is a major challenge to our whole society and not only to the affected communities. The anti-Semitic attack against the synagogue in Halle is only the most recent example but, on a daily basis, minorities become victims of hatred online and offline.  It has been a key priority for the EU to ensure first and foremost the correct transposition and implementation of the relevant EU legislation, including the Racial Equality Directive, the Employment Equality Directive and the Framework Decision on racism and xenophobia. The Commission has been working closely together with Member State authorities and civil society in the EU High-Level Group on combating racism and xenophobia to ensure the effective application of the rules against hate speech and hate crime by the whole enforcement chain. The developed tools will assist Member States in strengthening a practical response to implement. Dedicated formats of the high-level group will ensure in the future that the tools are implemented by Member States to make tangible progress in recording and responding to hate crime and hate speech. In particular, as regards hate speech, the Commission has pushed for stronger action; it initiated the code of conduct on combating illegal hate speech online whereby major IT companies have committed to review flagged hate speech within 24 hours and remove content when necessary. Fast progress has been achieved. In 2016, only 28% of the content was removed. Now it is above 70%, and 89% of the notices are assessed within the committed period.  We regularly monitor the progress. Next month we will present the results of the fifth monitoring exercise carried out together with civil society organisations. We managed to bring together all actors from civil society, IT companies and state authorities to strengthen our response to hate speech online. Our two coordinators on combating anti-Semitism and anti-Muslim hatred have been proactively reaching out to Jewish and Muslim communities, and strengthening the collaboration with international organisations, Member States’ authorities and non-governmental organisations. We also intensively work on implementing the EU-Roma strategy containing measures against anti-Gypsyism.  The adoption of the Council Declaration on combating anti-Semitism was a milestone. All Member States unanimously agreed on actions and were invited to develop national strategies. The Commission created a dedicated working group to ensure concrete follow-up to the Council declaration and support Member States and Jewish communities to work together on developing these strategies. We are glad that the incoming German Presidency has announced already their intention to place the fight against anti-Semitism high on the agenda.  Distorting our common history has been one of the trademarks of fanning the flames of hatred and division, be it by third countries or within our own societies. Where today there are attempts to deny or distort the memory of the Holocaust, where people are vilified because they are Jews, this is where Europe is called into question. Attempts to distort our history are threatening our foundations. Disinformation and fake news attack our past but also, and first of all, our present. Our democracies must be harnessed to respond to this challenge and they must themselves adapt. Online platforms have been misused to disseminate and amplify manipulative messages to distort the democratic debate and interfere in the political process.  For four out of five Europeans, disinformation is a problem for democracy. We must ensure that democracy remains well protected in Europe. To better harness our democracy, the Commission will put forward a European democracy action plan. It will help counter disinformation and support free and independent media and will also aim to ensure greater transparency of paid political advertising and provide clearer rules on the financing of EU political parties. Transparency and accountability is essential, as well as not allowing external interventions in our democratic systems by those who wish to divide and destabilise our Union. This is a common priority for the Commission, European institutions and the Member States. As we see minorities under pressure again today, we must raise our voices and redouble our efforts to ensure that Europeans can go about their lives free from the threat of anti-Semitism, racism and xenophobic hatred.  The Commission is looking forward to working with the European Parliament and in particular the Anti-Racism and Diversity Intergroup and the Working Group on Anti-Semitism.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I have listened to many speeches, but one that will stay with me for a long time to come was given by Marian Turski last month, 75 years after he, weighing all of 32 kilos, walked out of Auschwitz. He called for an end to indifference. ‘Auschwitz did not fall from the sky,’ he said. It happened slowly, because too many people turned a blind eye to justice, too many people found comfort in scapegoats, and too many people accepted prejudiced laws.  That is why we fight anti-Semitism, racism and any hatred everywhere today, because in Europe we know only too well the depths of horror that man has sunk to and can sink to. If we teach people not only about what happened, but about how it happened, slowly through gradually increasing measures, then maybe we can truly learn the lessons of history, even when the voices of the survivors can be heard no more. Now, today, we still witness attacks on Jews and synagogues in Europe, we still see the scapegoating going on, and we are still seeing states move slowly away from the values this Union was founded upon. We see our fundamental rights under threat in too many places.  So we cannot be silent when Europeans live with a packed suitcase by their door, just in case. We cannot be silent in the face of injustice anywhere. Let no one fighting for justice ever look to Europe and be met as they have been met – with shrugs of shoulders or excuses that favour political expediency. Our European history has too often been built on the backs of the broken. When we say ‘never again’, we must mean it, and that means taking action. And in conclusion, Roman Kent coined the eleventh commandment: ‘Thou shalt not be indifferent’. May it become our guiding principle.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, 75 years ago we Europeans agreed on ‘never again’, and yet in 2020 anti-Semitism is on the rise. Hatred and intolerance across the European Union are on a trend of steady growth. Political parties, also in this House, fuel a climate of racism and anti-immigration with their rhetoric, be it against Jews, Muslims, migrants, Roma or LGBTI people. We cannot tolerate populist rhetoric, prejudice and nationalism to become part of mainstream politics; to become the new normal. We cannot allow far-right parties, such as the AFD in Germany, Fidesz in Hungary, Lega in Italy, to become the dominant voice of our public debates. As progressives, we will always stand up for freedom: freedom for all to be who you want to be, to believe what you want to believe. We need stronger commitments in the EU against hate speech and racism, and we will continue to fight for an EU in which minorities and vulnerable groups are protected from any form of discrimination. An EU with respect for rule of law and not the rule of a majority. We believe in a European Union in which we actually do justice to 75 years of liberation; in an EU where we stand up, we speak up and act when fellow Europeans are discriminated against.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, he would have been 37 years old. Ilan Halimi was abducted because he was Jewish. Burned, stabbed, tortured to death for three weeks in a housing estate in the Paris region. That was 14 years ago, almost to the day. His murder is a small part of our humanity. Sarah Halimi would have been 66. Beaten to death, too, because she was Jewish, she was then defenestrated by Kobili Traoré. This trial will not take place, it has been declared criminally irresponsible because under the influence of cannabis. Cannabis, stupidity, ignorance as mitigating circumstances... Curious case law than this one. Anti-Semitism kills. Today, again, Europeans are afraid because they are Jewish, many leave elsewhere. Even today, schools, synagogues and cemeteries must be protected. A third of Europeans say they know little or nothing about the Holocaust. Remembering, educating is essential, but it is not enough. To block the road to the racist violence that plagues the courts, the cities, the social networks, is not to tolerate, it is to condemn, to punish. The whole world had their eyes on Jerusalem a fortnight ago. Fifty heads of state had made the trip to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz camp and make a formal commitment: never again. The Hungarian president was one of them. Yet two days ago, Mr President concludes, in Budapest, several thousand Nazis came from all over Europe to march before the police for their 'day of honour', I quote, an infamous tribute to their heroes of the Third Reich. Commissioner, we all know your commitment. Can we really say today that Europe is doing enough?

name: Filip DE MAN
text: on behalf of the ID Group. Mr President, the lament about white racism was no less so in the Belgian Chamber where I spent 23 years. It is not better in this House: racists, anti-Semites and Nazis are everywhere. But the real problem is rarely, if ever, addressed: the massive influx of Muslim racists responsible for 99% of anti-Semitic violence in the European Union. That's the truth. Colleagues, stop chasing Nazi haunts. You're actually behind a war. I must also call on you to stop calling right-wing nationalist colleagues racists if they choose their own people and protect our borders. There are different cultures and religions and there is a solution to the problems that this presents: borders.

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Breaking the dams was the first thought that so many of us had when we saw the far-right Höcke, the friend of those who have just spoken, and the newly elected Thuringian Prime Minister shaking hands. The dams are breaking. They have long broken when the Hungarian Prime Minister sets anti-Semitic clichés to music, when right-wing radicals in Austria and Estonia co-govern and warm up in many other countries, when Jewish people here in Europe no longer feel comfortable and the Sinti and Roma no longer do so anyway. The dams are breaking, they are breaking in our heads when it becomes increasingly normal to joke about Jewish influence, to complain about Jewish capital, when it becomes normal to have cars at the carnival every year, a few kilometres from here, in Aalst, that have anti-Jewish motives every year, when it becomes increasingly normal, not to say anything against it. The dams - they break. What is the EU doing about it? I ask the Commission, I ask the Member States, I ask us all. Our EU Presidents gave fine speeches in Jerusalem last week. But with words alone, we cannot fight anything, we need more. Because the dams are breaking. And we do not just need concern, we need attitude and action! What do we do? We have equipped the staff of the Commission Commissioners against anti-Semitism here. Does it have enough work resources to do this work? How concretely do the Member States shape the Council's decision in reality, how do they implement it? We do not know that. We are waiting for these answers, and I expect these answers not only as a member of the board of the working group against anti-Semitism in this House, but as citizens of Europe. Because the dams - they break, and we have to withstand them.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it would have been enough to be here two hours ago to hear words of hatred and anti-Semitism. Two hours ago the people of Israel were accused of: apartheid, exploitation of the Palestinians, violent annexation, violation of human rights, violation of international law, war crimes. To say these things are the same people who hide the responsibilities of Islamic radicalism towards most anti-Semitic attacks in Europe, they are the same people who challenge the right of the Jewish people to be able to practise their religious traditions in Europe. Then perhaps Goldschmidt, the President of the Conference of European Rabbis, who said in Italy a few weeks ago: 'Today we have the greatest problems from the left, this is the great novelty on the anti-Semitism front'.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – (beginning of the speech when the micro is switched off) ... of course gross nonsense, what my colleague has just said here, by hacking around here on the left. In view of the fact that synagogues are once again targets of far-right attacks, that they must be heavily guarded in order to continue, for believing Jews to be hostile on Europe's streets, that there are parties in this House that call Hitler fascism a bird's-eye shot in history – in view of these things, it is high time to act. And action does not just mean finding the right words at commemorations or attacks: it is important to fight resolutely the spirit and deeds of the new and old Nazis – indeed, the racists of all kinds – in the state, in society, on the streets, by the judiciary, in parliaments and in everyday life. This includes clearly rejecting the history-climbing in this House, because fascism and communism cannot be lumped together. We are committed to the truth, and so are you who sit there. We owe it to the victims of fascism and racism.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, phenomena such as anti-Semitism, racism, xenophobia, homophobia and other forms of intolerance give rise to great social alarm in several Member States. They feed on prejudice and hatred, which have a worrying spread both online and offline. Protecting people and social groups from all forms of discrimination and violence on the grounds of skin colour, religion, personal opinions or sexual orientation means not only guaranteeing everyone full enjoyment of human rights and fundamental freedoms, but also having a more cohesive and inclusive society.  The European Union and the Member States must take initiatives and measures to prevent, educate and raise awareness, especially for young people, of crimes and hate speech. Most of them are not yet properly denounced and prosecuted. Several pipelines go unpunished, with serious repercussions on protection in support of victims. It is therefore in Europe's general interest to reverse this trend.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: – Mr President, I am a believer and many of you are also believers here. Even those who sympathise with fascism and Nazism pretend to be believers. But God wanted us all to be different. If the neo-Nazis could rule today, believe me, half of us wouldn't be here today. Maybe we differ in religion, maybe we differ in culture or language, we may differ in skin color, but each of us' blood color is the same. Red blood circulates in the veins of a Jew, a Roma and every European, even a neo-Nazi. Millions of people died at the hands of those who considered themselves perfect. In many countries, Nazis and fascists have exploited the perverse ideology of God.  In my country in Slovakia during The Second World War, fascists defended their atrocities with the slogan "For God, for the nation!" But God is not hate. On the one hand, ladies and gentlemen, there is a rich, prosperous Europe, on the other hand, corruption, poor and poor regions where people do not work, where children cannot prepare school for the labour market, where people do not have a sewerage or access road, and even some people drink water from a stream. This, too, is the image of the 21st century European Union. If we ignore these problems, their fascists will take over. We can also defeat the ideology of a superior race by politicians starting to solve people's real problems. At the same time, however, it is important that we approach the ideology of the superior race not as an opinion, but as a crime. Whoever plays preaches that a race is more perfect than the other, it's not about freedom of expression. It's about crime. It's a crime. All democratic institutions must take this view as a crime. History has shown where extremism can go if we allow it to grow. History has shown that extremism grows if we give it an opportunity. Let us not put in the hands of an agenda for extremists that we are able to solve ourselves. In many countries, extremists point to corruption, the non-management of migration problems or poor Roma communities. Europe must significantly address its problems that are plaguing the people of Europe.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Vice-President Jourová, this debate against anti-Semitism, racism and hatred in Europe is full of meaning. Not because the Eurobarometer indicates that discriminatory attitudes are growing against individuals and entire categories of European citizens — whose fundamental rights are protected by European law — but because hate crimes are increasing, because real violence against these people and entire categories is increasing.  That is why this Parliament has a duty not only to express sadness and concern, but above all to motivate it to support all the actions of the Commission and the Council leading to this fight and to strengthen the instruments. That is why we adopted on 1 June 2007 our Resolution on Anti-Semitism and our Commitment to Holocaust Denial.  But that is also why we have monitored the decision taken by the European Council in December 2018 to provide the necessary tools to act in a dual field: that of hate education, but also legislation against crimes that directly instime violence. This is where the correct transposition of the 2008 Framework Decision comes into play and the need for the Commission to have the support of the European Parliament to provide all the necessary instruments. First, training of the competent authorities. Second, the record of hate crimes and, thirdly, the protection of their victims and the security assurance of these threatened communities in Europe, not only the Jewish community , of course – but also the Roma community and anyone who serves hate speech as a scapegoat for attitudes of intolerance and contempt against others that cannot be tolerated because they are deeply incompatible with European law.

name: Anna Júlia DONÁTH
text: – Mr President, recently, in Hungary, an anti-Roma governmental campaign has been launched. The Prime Minister approves of the segregation of Roma children in the countryside, discourages the payment of compensation for the segregation of these children and enrages others by saying that Roma people get this money without doing any work.  Hate speech and openly racist politics are on the rise in many EU countries. They have always been present in society, but in recent years they have been spreading instead of receding. Populist and racist movements have a strong role in this as they build on people’s fear and designate scapegoats: others towards whom to channel negative emotions and fears generated by the changing world.  If we don’t act now this can cause a domino effect, as extremists learn from each other. For example, with the spread of exclusionary law-making practices and propaganda methods. If we do not speak out and take decisive action now they will keep undermining EU values and principles which, like solidarity, respect of human dignity, human rights and non-discrimination will have no role to play in the future of Europe. We must act now.  (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the history of the Western world has shown that anti-Semitism is a litmus test of the decline of a society and foreshadows its collapse. Anyone who cares about the society in which they live should fight anti-Semitism. The fight against anti-Semitism must include the defence of the State of Israel in its territorial, political and religious integrity, since Israel is the bulwark of democratic freedoms in the Middle East. The contribution that the Judaeo-Christian tradition has made to the formation of Western European culture and civilization has been fundamental.  Combating anti-Semitism therefore means not only defending Israel, which at the same time is the home of Judaism and the guardian of Christian memory, but also defending the European Union itself against Islamic terrorism, religious fundamentalism and any illiberal and undemocratic movement.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is almost, but almost almost, sebilising to listen to all the fine words about how to fight hatred against Jews, against Muslims, against those who are different from the crowd – such as me.  Fortunately, there are many of us who are aware that there is a lot of empty talk. Behind rhetorical curvatures are different yardsticks and completely different editions of rights, depending on where you come from, where your parents come from, what name you wear and how much pigment you have in your skin. Racism and discrimination are spreading like wildfire.  We need to take the threats seriously. It is unacceptable that eu leaders, who have had 15 years, have not been able to sign up to the anti-discrimination directive.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Indeed, this debate on the sources of anti-Semitism must be based on truth. So if true, it is not some enigmatic Nazis, not the 75th anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz camp, but the liberation of the German Nazi death camp at Auschwitz. That's the first thing. Secondly, I listened with amazement to the representatives of the left, who were outraged at the sign of equality between fascism and communism. I would like to quote one very mild statement by Stalin about the Jews. He said that workers should be given batons so that they could use the Jews at the end of their work. Polish communists, whose sons also sit in this Chamber today as democrats, carried out anti-Semitic purge in the Polish military in the 1960s. Therefore, it must be said, quoting the great writer Zofia Nałkowska, "it was the people who prepared this fate". Anti-Semitism, on the other hand, can only be eucked if we are very consistently, truthfully, opposed to those who stand behind anti-Semitism in modern Europe without caring about political correctness.

name: Clara PONSATÍ OBIOLS
text: – Mr President, one of the most hideous crimes against the Jewish people took place in 1492 when the so-called Catholic kings ordered the general expulsion of the Jews from Sepharad. This first episode of state anti-Semitism, one that Adolf Hitler admired and sought to surpass, stands as a cornerstone of the Spanish tragic record of intolerance. Today, this intolerance takes the form of contempt for the rights of the Catalan minority. This happens in the background of laughter and indulgence with fascism apologies. While the Francisco Franco Foundation remains legal, Spanish judges use anti-hatred laws to prosecute Catalan teachers that criticise the violence of the Civil Guard. We do need laws to protect minorities from hatred but, without democratic judges to enforce them, they are useless.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating mr Ideally, we would not have to have a debate on anti-Semitism, racism and hatred in Europe, but it is important – and unfortunately it is needed. Anti-Semitism is on the rise in Europe, including in my own country, Sweden. According to Eurobarometer, anti-Semitism is growing most at the moment in Sweden. Jews testify that they dare not wear their star of David or their kippa. Freedom of religion is restricted.  I believe that the work against anti-Semitism should be a much clearer priority on the part of the Commission. I do not understand why it is not even mentioned in the Commission's work programme and would like an explanation as to why it is not mentioned. Finally, I would also like to make three concrete proposals for initiatives that the Commission should take. Firstly, increase funding to educate young people about the Holocaust, racism and hate crimes in Europe. Secondly, be sure to stop foreign funding of extreme faith communities throughout Europe. Thirdly, put an end to the possibility for hate preachers to enter Europe and spread their extreme views.  Show that we are prepared to do something concrete to stop anti-Semitism and racism in Europe, because that does not belong here.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years we have seen a worrying increase in cases of anti-Semitism in Europe and around the world. In my country, Italy, anti-Semitic writings and symbols have recently appeared on the homes of Holocaust survivors or human rights activists. This is a very serious phenomenon that is often covered up by parties that use racism to gain consensus. The leaders of these forces often make anti-Semitic statements, sometimes even denying the Holocaust.  A few weeks ago, this Parliament hosted Liliana Segre, a survivor of Auschwitz. Today it is necessary to follow his example. Just as you have refused the invitation to a debate on anti-Semitism together with members of the extreme right, we must make it clear that only by being clearly anti-racist can we really combat anti-Semitism. We must be as a Parliament in the front row, so to combat all this, and the reconstitution of our working group on anti-Semitism is an important signal, but we must continue in this direction.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: – Mr President, in so as not to forget the truth, according to a survey of Jews, violence or the threat of violence in Europe was directed at them, as a rule, by Muslims. The second largest threat group is the extreme left and the extreme right. All this reins must, of course, be tackled with firm measures.  Racism as a word has experienced full inflation. Accusations of racism are particularly attacking all nationalists. In this Chamber, too, that accusation is heard very often. When you run out of facts, you can at least call others racist by blaming your chest. After all, the Phariseus was happy he wasn't like that wretched publican. Hate speech is a developed new vocabulary that attacks dissidents, that is, nationalists, and even divides sentences in different judiciaries.

name: Salima YENBOU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in January we commemorated the discovery of the atrocities in the Auschwitz camp so that these horrors would never happen again. Unfortunately, crimes and discrimination have continued since then, notably in Europe (in the Balkans), but also against Tamils, Tutsis, Yezidi, Kurds, Copts, Falachas, Uighurs, Muslim Indians, Rohingya, Palestinians, Roma... Today, in the face of this observation, we must rethink the fight against all these moral, psychological and physical abuses. The fight against discrimination must no longer be compared, competing with a specific term that divides rather than brings people together. Intersectionality and the word discrimination are relevant to apprehend this major challenge with solidarity and struggle by all and for all. This commitment against discrimination must be universal, regardless of origin, gender, religion, sexual orientation or any other criterion that may define the oppressed and the oppressed. Indeed, you don't have to be a woman to defend a woman, you don't have to be Jewish, Christian, Muslim to defend a Jew, Christian, Muslim, you don't have to be gay to defend a homosexual. Let us all lift ourselves, every time a human being is discriminated against.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: – Mr President, I think all political talk fades when we look at the figures. Anti-Semitism in Europe today is on the march and it is a huge problem. In just 10 years, 60,000 Jews have left France. It is clear from the data of the European Agency for Human Rights that 38% of Jews are considering leaving Europe. Some of the numbers are terrible. Germany doubling to 44% in 5 years. Sweden doubles to 35% in 5 years. France 44 %, Belgium, where the EP is based, 42 %. On the contrary, Hungary, which is often on the wallpaper here, is the only country where the number of Jews who want to leave has fallen by a full 10%. So, what to do? To set a definition of anti-Semitism, to ban Hezbollah, and to end anti-Israel anti-Semitic foreign policy. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. – I thank my colleague for accepting my Blue Card and for perhaps this institute can also learn a little more. I was very perceiving of his comments and I have to say that he spoke to me from the heart, of course, but I want to give him room to react at the same time to the fact that racism is not limited to anti-Semitism. In your speech, you spoke only about Jewish racism, i.e. anti-Semitism, but we also have other forms of racism. Do you see the other forms as fundamentally important and reprehensible?

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Of course I see them as fundamental and important, but I see anti-Semitism, given the history of this continent, what happened in the 20th century as a mega problem. It is clear from these figures that this is a mega problem, that it is simply related to our policy towards migration. We can't just hide this, and the political talk is fading in light of the numbers we have here. It is a survey in which our agency, the European Agency, asked 16 000 Jews, please nicely. That's not a group of 500 respondents.

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: – Mr President, in the last decade anti-Semitism has raised its ugly head again in Europe. Sadly, though this is factually substantiated, according to a 2019 Eurobarometer survey there’s a striking discrepancy in the perception of anti-Semitism. Almost 90% of Jews feel that anti-Semitism is on the rise, but only 36% of European citizens agree. Europe cannot allow the poison of anti-Semitism to spread. It needs to support, it needs to protect its Jews and it needs to effectively combat anti-Semitic perpetrators, and there is no question that Hezbollah, Iran’s most deadly proxy, is an indoctrinated, violent anti-Semitic group which poses serious threats to Jews in Europe and not just in Europe. Yet the European Union refuses to follow in the footsteps of some of its most adored allies like the United States, like the United Kingdom, like Canada, and to end this false distinction between the political wing and the military wing of Hezbollah – a distinction which, by the way, Hezbollah calls a joke and dismisses. This hypocrisy must end now. The EU must place Hezbollah in its entirety on the EU terrorist list if it is going to be credible and, more importantly, effective in combating anti-Semitism and the atrocious acts it leads to.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – Mr President, as we’ve already heard, FRA and Eurobarometer research shows that anti-Semitic abuse and violence is increasing in the EU. According to the FRA survey, people cannot live a life free of worry for their own safety and the safety of their family members. But racism and anti—Semitism are still denied by many politicians, media and scientists all over Europe. When I was a Deputy Commissioner for Human Rights, I often heard that there is no anti—Semitism in Poland, while dealing with anti—Semitic attacks, hate speech and violence. It is the 21st century and more and more people here in the European Union feel they can treat someone differently or hate someone because of his or her religion, ethnic origin or skin colour. It is unacceptable. The European Union urgently needs a strategy to fight anti—Semitism, racism and xenophobia, to prevent and combat these phenomena and to protect human rights. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "I have a question for my speaker. At the time when you were in office alongside the Ombudsman, do you remember how the police reacted to any anti-Semitic excesses? I had the honour of being minister of the interior and administration in the Government of Law and Justice, and I would like to stress very strongly that every manifestation of anti-Semitism was met with an immediate response from the Polish police and was combated. There has never been acceptance and there can be no acceptance of anti-Semitism, so please do not mislead this House.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Now we have made two mistakes: firstly, you were the speaker, so you are no longer entitled to a 'blue card'.  Secondly, you have not asked a question, but you have made a statement. I therefore leave it to Mrs Spurek to comment on this – yes or no? You're welcome.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I would like to answer this non—question.  It is not enough for the police to react. It is not enough for the prosecutor's office to prosecute and the courts to rule, especially since I have not always observed the determination that is needed. During my time as Deputy Ombudsman, I have been completely condemned by those in high public office in government.

name: Jean-Paul GARRAUD
text: Mr President, the subject of debate this evening is often discussed in this Chamber and that is an excellent thing. But it is always treated in an incomplete, partisan and one-way way manner. Incomplete, because no one here, of the majority, will address in the context of this debate the considerable subject of anti-Christian acts in the world, targeting people but also property, churches daily vandalized, cemeteries desecrated. Partisan and one-way, because a majority of Members of this House do not want to ask the real question, the one that annoys, the one that disturbs: what is the main cause of the sharp rise in anti-Christian and anti-Semitic acts? You know the answer: it is obviously the rise of Islamism, this new totalitarianism that you refuse to see, that you forbid yourself from criticizing, while our peoples suffer and suffer from it. As for the hatred you denounce, you are the wrong target. You always aim for what you call the "populists" with disdain and contempt. You should focus all your efforts on those who hate our European civilization, our cultures, our identities, our individual freedoms. You should fight those who violently want to impose on us a barbaric society that is not ours. This should be our common struggle: to fight with all our might against Islamism, this radicalism, this terrorism which is indeed the most serious threat to our democracies in the 21st century.

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am very surprised at what I have just heard. Anti-Semitism once culminated in the worst, most inhumane and cruel genocide humanity has ever known. He produced the abysmally worst of people. Even by reorganising democratic Europe after 1945, anti-Semitism did not disappear, but it took on new forms. Anti-Semitism became adaptable, changeable and deeply rooted in our society. This was also demonstrated by the debate today. Europe's right-wing populists are not only subliminal in their anti-Semitism; Openly, they are deliberately inciting hatred in order to turn existing anti-Semitism in people's minds into moods and voices. It is our obligation to counteract this cynical, inhumane approach in our society and the political landscape. It is our obligation to eradicate anti-Semitism from people's minds. This requires uncalled heroes – citizens who contradict and resolutely speak out against all forms of anti-Semitism. Ladies and gentlemen, in conclusion: Become unnamed heroes in your countries!

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Mr President, when today is the debate on anti-Semitism, in particular, I pay tribute to Portuguese Aristides Sousa Mendes, consul in Bordeaux, a unique example of world-class humanism, which, during The Second World War, was responsible for the rescue of up to thirty thousand Jews fleeing the atrocities of Nazism. Father of fourteen children, when Portugal was a neutral country, disobeyed the instructions of the government, which had then suspended the authorization of visas to Jews, continuing to assign them without distinction of race or religion. For your act you paid the highest price. He was dismissed as consul, demoted, retired and even banned from the role of lawyer for saving thousands of human beings from death. He lost everything and died in complete poverty, buried even in a dress suit offered by charity. In 1966, the Holocaust Memorial in Jerusalem, Yad Vashem, paid tribute to him and bestowed him the title of Righteous among the Nations. In Portugal, it has obtained, posthumously, but only recently, the widest distinctions. It deserves, however, worldwide recognition and certainly deserves as extraordinary and superior to be endowed with true humanity and love for others, the just evocation in this European Parliament. As a Christian democrat Portuguese I am, I am honored to be able to do so.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – Mr President, 75 years after the Holocaust, anti—Semitism, hatred, discrimination and xenophobia are all on the rise in Europe. In my own country, Poland, we have LGBT—free zones, which the Parliament has rightly condemned. I’m not a Jew and I’m not an LGBT person, but this does not mean that I can stay idle, for hatred and discrimination are evil. They hurt people and they destroy the very fabric of democracy, freedom and solidarity. I also think: what if it were me, if they proclaimed Silesian—free zones, for example? As already mentioned, Marian Turski, a Holocaust survivor, said the Shoah did not suddenly fall from the sky: it took hold step by step, with society accepting small acts of discrimination, then bigger ones, leading to ghettos and extermination camps. We know this history in Europe all too well, and we must never let it repeat. As the European Parliament, we must be firm and fight hard all forms of hatred and discrimination.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the One of the main problems is the enormous mendacity here in this House. Mrs Ries talks about a tortured and murdered Jew in France, but does not even mention his name. By the way, his name was Ilan Halimi, and above all she does not mention who the perpetrator was, namely, of course, a Muslim immigrant. There is no discussion in such discussions that, of course, BDS never comes on the list of terrorist organisations, nor, of course, is Hezbollah, as has just been mentioned here. At the same time, this Parliament is committed to opening up borders, to getting resettlement programmes and to making global compact sequestration, in other words, for more and more Muslims to come to Europe. The Berlin Jews say that about three-quarters of all attacks come from Muslims, and it must be added that the rest probably comes from anti-Zionists and supporters of Boycott, Disinvest and Sanctions. And, of course, you are also funding anti-Semitism in Palestine, namely Al Fatah and Hamas, with 1.5 million a day, as Mr Borrell said today. If you want to fight anti-Semitism, you should stop this funding first.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, I would ask you not to use the word 'mendacity' in this room as an insinuation to other Members.

name: Lena DÜPONT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very The first debate in this House on anti-Semitism in this parliamentary term was before the tragic attack in Halle. Today's debate takes place before the Holocaust Remembrance Day two weeks ago. Both events, although unfortunately not only these two, remind us that our commitment to anti-Semitism is more important than ever. He can and he will have no end. Anti-Semitism, racism and hate crime continue to rise. Our attention, on the other hand, must not be reduced, but our efforts must not be ended.  But what is even more necessary than just attention is our actions, which we oppose this hatred and division. In its latest report on hate crime, the OSCE pointed out that many acts are not classified as hate crimes at all – partly because, at the same time, many victims do not provide the necessary information. They simply fear that it will not change their situation.  For us, this can only mean one thing: we need to take the situation of the victims even more seriously, we must combat hate speech, threats, anti-Semitism online and offline online and take a more ambitious approach here. Because only all together can stand up against it.

name: Rasa JUKNEVIČIENĖ
text: – Mr President, anti-Semitism is a diagnosis of a serious disease in society. However, finding the right treatment requires knowing the causes. They are internal and external. The internal ones are clear. They are like mutating viruses, becoming active in the dirty environment of angry nationalism. We must root them out. One of the external causes wasn’t mentioned today. It comes from the double-faced Kremlin policy against Europe. On the one hand, they attack some countries for being anti-Semitic and pretend to fight Nazism, but on the other hand, they finance nationalistic parties in the EU. Putin’s suggestion for Permanent Security Council Members to discuss threats of anti-Semitism in the UN is fake, because Russia itself is reviving totalitarian Stalinism based on hatred. The fight against anti-Semitism should be seen in the context of the fight against rehabilitation of all totalitarian regimes.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, we are having this debate because we are seeing an increase in anti-Semitism, racism and hate speech. We do not want further escalations, because we know that they can lead to political abuse, as they have led to dictatorships in the past. Today, 81% of the Jewish population in Europe cites fears of anti-Semitism, but this does not shy away from Central and Eastern Europe, where the Muslim population is low. Here, even in Poland, 48% of citizens report feeling anti-Semitic and 42% in Hungary.  How to defend against these hate speech, whether it is racist, anti-Semitic or just ordinary human hatred that is against human dignity? Above all, knowledge of history and also education is needed, and I recommend ethical education, ethical education. Intolerance and intolerance in public space. The Vice-President of the Commission has spoken about many instruments here.  Then a concrete example, and I would ask to be able to give it, because it is a concrete example of a brave speech against hatred, where our Cardinal Duke has clearly defined himself and objected to the hateful inscription on a Muslim mosque in the Czech Republic, and this is to be appreciated.

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, the moving speech of Marian Turski, a former prisoner of Auschwitz, has already been mentioned several times. He showed where Auschwitz came from, explained that it had not fallen from heaven. He described the mechanisms of gradual, initially innocent exclusion, stigmatization, alienation, stigmatization, then aggression, to the extermination of another. Turski's account is terrifyingly timely. It shows that lack of reaction, acceptance, quiet acceptance inevitably lead to tragedy. Always. Therefore, the responsibility lies with all of us. Not only the hate-sowing – they have to remember – but also all of us who look at it and passively accept it.  We have to say 'stop', we have to act firmly. It is our duty. Silence means de facto permission, and then it will be too late if we start treating it as normality. Therefore, Turski appealed to everyone, regardless of religion or worldview: "do not be indifferent". This is the eleventh commandment. Let us not be indifferent to us parliamentarians. We cannot afford the sin of omission when the rights of minorities are violated or the space of life without hatred is restricted. Let's try to imagine a world without hate.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, 75 years after Auschwitz, Hatred of Jews is still very much alive in Europe. The British organisation Community Security Trust (CST) has been monitoring incidents against Jews since 1984. CST recently concluded that there were 1,800 incidents against Jews in England in 2019, the highest figure ever.  Unfortunately, we can mention countless lows when it comes to Jew hatred. Think of the attack by a right-wing extremist on the synagogue in Halle on Great Awe Day last year. But also think of the left: 7 members of the Labour Party recently quit because Corbyn did not act sufficiently against Jewish hatred in the Labour Party. Or think of France, where Holocaust survivor Mrs Mireille Knoll was murdered in her Paris apartment on March 23, 2018. But also in my own country: cemeteries that have recently been daubed in Dordrecht.  Get rid of anti-Semitism. Support our petition on stopantisemitism.eu: all sign, that petition.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Today, we are talking about a very important subject, on which it must be stated very clearly that, after the Second World War, only zero tolerance for anti-Semitism can exist as the only possible approach. In Hungary, there is complete social and political agreement on this issue. Members of the Jewish community live safely, practice their religion and live their identity. Ensuring this, in addition to being a constitutional obligation, is also our moral duty. We are proud that It is thriving in Hungary and is now experiencing a renaissance in Jewish culture, with Jewish people and families feeling safe and nurturing their heritage. In contrast, violence and attacks on Jewish communities are on the rise in Western Europe. In addition to strongly condemning and rejecting all such attacks, there is also talk of the emergence and spread of radical Muslim anti-Semitism in Europe contributing to an increase in anti-Semitic attacks. The attacks on Jews in Western Europe are therefore yet another reason to take decisive action against illegal migration.

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We must seriously repel the hatred, intimidation and discrimination and racism to which Jews in Europe are subjected.  Jews in Sweden are particularly vulnerable. In fact, they are attacked from several quarters, from neo-Nazis, left-wing extremists, Islamists and those who simply have a great hatred of the State of Israel. Who, then, raises its voice when young people dare not show their Jewish faith for fear of being threatened and discriminated against at school? Who acts when the synagogue in Malmö or Gothenburg is subjected to hatred and attacks? Not the Swedish government anyway! I want the EUROPEAN Union to start acting to protect the Jews in Europe, to educate more schoolchildren and to invest in creating European rules that will allow us to stop together funding from extreme faith communities that spread anti-democratic values. That's enough!

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, today in this debate we condemn violence and hate language based on racial, ethnicity, religious affiliation and anti-Semitic propaganda. That makes sense, because such things have no place among us. But now is the time for each of us to ask ourselves an important question - after addressing our constituents and demanding that they have a civilized attitude to these issues, whether we and our behavior are the good example. At last week's mini-session in Brussels, a colleague of ours from Greece in the plenary, in the temple of democracy, allowed himself to tear up the flag of the Republic of Turkey. I ask this example of respect and good behavior, is it or is it a manifestation of hatred. Do we MEPs have the right to treat not only Turkey's national symbols in this way, but also any country? Therefore, colleagues, I think that before we require our constituents not to allow acts of anti-Semitism, racism and hatred, we ourselves, with our actions, must set a personal example of European and civilised behaviour.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Literally a dozen days ago we celebrated the anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz camp in Poland and Europe. It would seem that these tragic events of World War II will remain for all of us a painful lesson in history that everyone will remember. Unfortunately, no one can say that today, in early 2020, our continent is free from the disease of anti-Semitism, racism and xenophobia that led to the tragic events of only seventy years ago. Nowadays, we enjoy the common market or the freedom to travel, but let us not forget that the European Union was born primarily of the need to preserve peace and prevent new conflicts. It is therefore our duty to protect fundamental rights, which include the idea of just, peaceful and tolerant societies. The European Commission, Parliament and the governments of the Member States must work together to eliminate all signs of racism, xenophobia and discrimination in our societies.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Mr President, anti-Semitism, racism and hatred have, unfortunately, been filled with meaning in history, but are important today mainly to identify, name and condemn modern forms of such phenomena in order to prevent them. In today's Europe, it is possible to mistakenly believe that this depends solely on authoritarian leaders who are ingly manipulating people. In fact, a large fire can cause a bunch of matches of stereotypes and prejudices based on a national basis. For example, yesterday in Italy, in an area home to the Indigenous Slovenian national community, a number of neo-fascist inscriptions appeared, which I expect the Italian authorities to condemn and react appropriately to this far-right phenomenon. There is certainly no need or European policy to suppress any form of intolerance.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, I take the floor in this debate because acts of anti-Semitism, racism and hate speech are not the concern of one minority or another, nor of any other community. This is a common European and global problem that threatens our core values. But how to deal with it when in the European Union itself it is empowered. I set an example for my homeland the Republic of Bulgaria, where the extreme nationalist Valery Simeonov was elected Vice-President of the Bulgarian Parliament and with the support of the political forces, members of the European People's Party and the Party of European Socialists. And this is a man who pushed elderly women on the border with the Republic of Turkey, came to vote or just to see their relatives. His motive – that they are ethnically different. Colleagues, let's not be voiceless, it's never too late for evil to catch up with us. Raise your voice, be a people of dignity and respect the rights and freedoms of all citizens.

name: Pierrette HERZBERGER-FOFANA
text: – (beginning of the speech when the micro is switched off) ... Anti-Semitism and violence are becoming more and more widespread in Europe. Debates in meetings, on the streets or in everyday life are becoming increasingly harsh, aggressive and derogatory. Insults are accepted and, unfortunately, legally sanctioned, as in Germany the debate on the N-word. This is seen as a carte blanche by the racists and is indirectly breeding ground for degrading action. Racist attacks are on the rise. People of different skin color or religious affiliation, black people, Jews, Sinti and Roma are often the target of racist violence. After the attack in Halle against the Jewish community last year, a second attack was carried out in the same city against a member of the Bundestag of African origin. Only last week, in the election in Thuringia, we witnessed an alarming taboo breach in which a centre-right party formed an alliance with a populist party for reasons of power. Unfortunately, I and other African people had to endure a play in Ludwigsburg last weekend with racist and derogatory terms like the N-word. The explicit indications of various actors not to allow the play in this form were not accepted. The UN has proclaimed the Decade for People of African Origin for 2014-2024, because we are still victims of racism, discrimination and intolerance. Especially at a time when bad mood is gaining ground and every line of decency is being crossed, it is more important than ever that each of us should stand up for a political culture of equality, respect and solidarity and take a clear stand against racism. Human dignity applies to ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, anti-Semitism is on the rise in Europe. In France, for example, the Interior Ministry's 2019 report reports a 74% increase in anti-Semitic incidents in one year. According to a January 2020 poll, 34% of Jews living in France feel threatened. We must combat this worrying phenomenon. But to better combat it, we must first realize that there are now three sources of anti-Semitism. First, there is the right-wing anti-Semitism, which is the oldest, but which remains. Then, and more recently, there is far-left anti-Semitism, which is a hateful drift of anti-Zionist ideology. Finally, there is an Islamist anti-Semitism that was born in most Western European states as a result of uncontrolled immigration. It is the latter that seems to me today the most dangerous of the three. It has been allowed to prosper for too long without reacting. Today we must put an end to this shameful tolerance and fight it without weakness.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the rise of anti-Semitism and the consequent increase in the sense of insecurity among European Jews is a great defeat for modern Europe. And while European mainstream politicians are telling the story of protecting vulnerable groups in a row, at the same time much of the Jewish community is considering emigration. This is a true example of European hypocrisy and unfortunately it is not the only one.  Some social groups have become more equal today than others. And while it looms over the fate of those who depend much more on the help of the state, more successful communities, such as the Jewish one, are completely neglected. The rise of anti-Semitism is also the defeat of Europe's integration and integration-migration policy, which allows import extremism to flourish on European soil. It has to be put to an end while it's still time.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, we have a great heritage of struggle and solidarity with all those who have been or are victims of racism, xenophobia or fascism. We reject any historical revisions on the terror of Nazi—fascism. We will not allow the fight against anti-Semitism to be used to criminalise the action and opinion of all those who condemn the illegalities and crimes of the Israeli regime against the Palestinian people. We will not allow the accusation of anti-Semitism to those who oppose Israel's criminal policy, while economic cooperation and the European Union's agreements with the Israeli State continue. Freedom and justice are defended by condemning Israel's policy which, with the complicity of the Trump administration and the European Union, is in affront to international law, UN resolutions and international agreements and disrespects human rights. We don't confuse aggressors with assaulted. It is the Palestinian people who have been attacked by a Zionist regime which, in its racist and far-right action, disrespects the history of its own people.

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – (The Member addresses the President in German). I will not talk about the principles that underpin the fight against anti-Semitism, racism and sus. It is very clear that we need a comprehensive strategy and policies applied to combat them. However, I would like to draw attention to the fact that these policies must be developed and implemented as soon as possible, in all the Member States of the Union, from their capitals, but also in small towns, in villages and in communes. Without this general application we will find that we have many situations, such as the Ditrău case two weeks ago in Romania, where two chefs of Asian origin had to accept the position of unskilled workers, so as not to upset the local community outraged by the presence of foreign workers in the locality. The instigation of citizens to hate, to discrimination was not punished by the authorities, and moreover, it was accepted that the two chefs be transferred to work under their training, thus creating an extremely dangerous precedent. We have had more than 1500 years of hatred, bigotry, fear of others, whatever they may be, we call it the Middle Ages. I think we need to act quickly and decisively, so that we don't go back there to the horrors of the past.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am very grateful for the dedication and support of the European Parliament for this issue. I say to the House: I would like to react on several comments. Indeed, you quoted here the survey of Fundamental Rights Agency and Eurobarometer, which really show alarming and shocking figures. When you ask the Jewish citizen in the EU what is his or her main concern, the answer is security. When you ask the European people who are not of Jewish origin, they will say ‘we have concerns about our health, our jobs, our family’. And this is really very alarming that the Jewish people have such an elementary fear and that they plan to leave Europe. Jewish people leaving Europe has never been a good sign, and this is not a Europe we want. And I think it was Ms Ries, who left already, she asked whether we are doing enough. I regret to say ‘no, we are not doing enough yet’, and we have all of us the obligation to do much more. The Commission worked hard to deliver or achieve some tangible results in the fight against anti-Semitism. We decided to promote the adoption of the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance definition of anti-Semitism, which now is used also by the majority of the Member States. We are openly speaking and addressing the sources of anti-Semitism and it was also mentioned here: it is far-right, far-left, it is Islamist radicalism and also old conspiracy theories. That’s why we urged the Member States, the ministers of home affairs, to adopt the decision to create the strategies on a Member States level. The anti-Semitism strategies, which will bring very concrete plans especially into areas, in the security area and in education. The strategies are now in the in the process of creation and under the German Presidency, we will look at these strategies and will decide on how to continue further. We want to see concrete measures accompanied with money. On security, I think it is absolutely intolerable that the Jewish communities have to finance their own security and the protection of Jewish premises, such as schools and synagogues. We have to do much more on education. It should also be reflected in the national strategies and accompanied by money, and here comes also European money because we have in the values programme a dedicated amount for education in this field. I was also in Auschwitz two weeks ago, commemorating the 75 years after liberation of the camp and I was listening to authentic testimonies of the survivors. We will not be able to hear these testimonies from authentic people very soon. We have to find a way how to explain to the younger generation what the Holocaust was, and to change the narrative, because we keep discussing about the results of the Holocaust, the horrifying statistical figures. But we have to start speaking seriously about the sources of the Holocaust. How it started, because this is exactly what Marian Turski spoke about in Auschwitz-Birkenau, at that commemoration event. He didn’t speak about the past, he spoke about the present. How it can happen again. That it will be innocent at the beginning, slow and it will be driven by our passivity and our being indifferent. He warned very strongly against being indifferent. The last comment on your contributions on online hate speech. We have an agreement with the big players in the tech industry to remove hate speech, but it cannot be enough. There must be a ‘crime and punishment’ principle also online. That’s why I urged very strongly the law enforcement authorities in all the Member States to go after these cases and to show that it is not possible just to rely on the fact that, or the impression that, online has no law. We have to do much more. Law enforcement authorities have started to be more active. But what they keep telling me is that in Europe, in the 21st century, crime has no boarders, the digital area has no more borders and that law enforcement authorities are trapped by the national borders. And they cannot reach for the evidence of crime in another Member State. That’s why I wanted to ask you to look at again at the regulation on evidence which the Commission developed because if this is adopted, it will help a lot to go after crime wherever it happens in the EU.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me assure you once again that the Presidency and the Council as a whole rejects any form of anti-Semitism, racism and hatred. We have a legal framework in place which needs to be effectively implemented in practice, but we also need to support it with targeted measures to prevent and tackle intolerance, such as education, public debate and counter narratives. The Council will continue to follow the matter closely, and I can assure you that we pay particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I would like to thank all of you very much for the way in which this debate has been conducted and for the very warm words that have been made to each and every one of you. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – When we talk about 'anti-Semitism', 'racism' or 'hatred', it is worth noting that today we are also increasingly encountering anti-Polonism, including here in Parliament. Anti-Polonism can be seen in attempts to distort the history of World War II, especially when it comes to "Polish death camps", which have never been seen before. Anti-Polonism can be seen in the accusations Polish of anti-Semitism. Meanwhile, the Simon Wiesenthal Centre has published a list of the most anti-Semitic events of 2019. Most of them were in the UK, France, Italy, Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United States. No in Poland. Before World War II, the largest Jewish population in the world lived in the Polish. They have lived on our lands for more than 800 years. And today, in the face of a rising tide of anti-Semitism in Europe, they are once again becoming a safe haven. For centuries, Poland has also been a refuge for other ethnic and religious minorities persecuted in the rest of Europe.  During World War II, it was the actions of Polish heroes such as the rotmaster Witold Pilecki, aimed at drawing the attention of the Western world to the greatest crime in the history of the world - the Holocaust. But the world was silent. Today, in the face of evil, we cannot remain silent. But let us also remember that Nazi ideology rejected the values on which European civilization was based, including Christian values. Without these values, German democracy turned into criminal totalitarianism.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – In recent years the number of cases of anti-Semitic violence in the EU Member States has unfortunately increased significantly. Incidents such as the recent attack on the Jewish synagogue in the German city of Halle, the desecration of Jewish monuments and cemeteries and the attack on the Jewish museum in Brussels are not isolated incidents. According to the European Human Rights Organisation there is an increase in violence against Jews in several European countries, precisely because they are Jewish. Hate speech and all forms of violence against the Jewish community in Europe are not in line with our principles and have no place in a Europe of values and democracy. Such incidents only cause fear and remind us of nightmarish times of the past that we try to forget. Local communities, civil society and education can play an important role in preventing and combating all forms of hatred and intolerance. The school is a unique environment for the transmission of the principles of tolerance and respect, since it can appeal to all children from an early age. We must act together and with determination to combat this scourge, it is everyone's duty.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the continuing threat to the rule of law in Poland (2020/2561(RSP)). I do not need to repeat the "blue card" and the registrations for the catch-the-eye procedure – they are known.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me stress once more that the rule of law plays a crucial role in all our democracies. As recalled by the EU’s strategic agenda, the rule of law is a key guarantee that our common values are well protected and complied with. Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights cannot be seen in isolation from one another. These elements are interlinked, interdependent and mutually reinforcing. One cannot exist without the others. It is a joint responsibility of the EU institutions and the Member States alike to ensure that respect for the rule of law is strengthened and that the rule of law remains the cornerstone of our common project. The independence of the judiciary is of crucial importance for the rule of law. It is also essential to ensure the application of EU law and the sound functioning of our common EU legal order. As regards the Article 7 procedure concerning Poland triggered by the Commission on 27 February 2018, as I had the opportunity to tell you when we discussed this topic at your January part-session, three hearings took place in June, September and December 2018 at the General Affairs Council. Subsequently the Council was kept regularly informed of the developments on the ground in Poland. Updates on the state of play were discussed at the General Affairs Council repeatedly in the course of 2019, in February, April, July, September and December.  The Council remains seized of this matter and our Presidency is ready to continue proceeding at the General Affairs Council. At the same time, we very much hope that a continuing dialogue at the political level between the Commission and Poland will bear concrete results.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, you will remember that on 15 January Commissioner Reynders and I updated you on the state of play of the rule of law in Poland. Since then, the Commission has been in contact with the Polish authorities. Commissioner Reynders met a representative of the Polish Ministry of Justice on 24 January, and I visited Warsaw on 28 January.
