At that occasion, I made the speakers of the Sejm and the Senate, the Minister of Justice, the First President of the Supreme Court of Poland, the President of the Constitutional Tribunal, and the Ombudsman. I carefully listened to the arguments of the Polish Government and explained to them the Commission’s stance. The Commission is committed and available to have an open and fair dialogue to resolve the issues at hand.  At the same time, the Commission will always fulfil its responsibility as the guardian of the Treaties. To that end, it will make use of infringement procedures whenever there are issues of compatibility with Union law. Likewise, the Article 7 process continues as long as the situation points to serious systemic threats to the rule of law.  At our last debate in this House, we informed you in particular about the draft new law governing the functioning of the judiciary. I explained that the draft legislation touches upon matters such as the independence of the judiciary, further raising the Commission’s concerns in this area. For this reason, I sent a letter to the Polish authorities on 19 December 2019. The letter recalled that the Commission wants to work with the Polish authorities to strengthen the rule of law by preventing problems and by working towards resolving them when they arise. I also invited all state organs not to take forward the proceedings on the new draft legislation before carrying out all the necessary consultations. On 16 January, the Venice Commission issued an urgent opinion on this new law raising serious concerns and recommending not to adopt it. On 24 January the new law on the judiciary was adopted by the Sejm, and on 4 February the President of the republic signed the law. This law raises a number of concerns as regards the rule of law. As noted by the Venice Commission, there is concern that this new law may further undermine judicial independence in Poland. It also raises concerns of compatibility with EU law and the Commission is now assessing these issues in detail. I can assure you that the Commission is committed to ensure the full respect of EU law and will take all necessary measures in that regard.  In addition to the adoption of the new law, a number of other developments took place. On 15 January, the Supreme Court issued two judgments implementing the preliminary ruling of the European Court of Justice regarding the independence of the disciplinary chamber. The Supreme Court confirmed the position taken in its ruling of 5 December 2019 and stated that the disciplinary chamber is not an independent court within the meaning of EU and national law.  Furthermore, in a resolution of 23 January the Supreme Court decided that the judges appointed at the request of the new national council for the judiciary, are not permitted to adjudicate cases. The resolution also invalidated all the rulings handed down by members of the disciplinary chamber. Another important development is the fact that the Constitutional Tribunal has been seized on the constitutionality of the approach on judicial independence that had been developed by the Supreme Court following the Court of Justice preliminary ruling on 19 November 2019. On 28 January 2020, the Constitutional Tribunal took an interim decision aimed at suspending the applicability of the Supreme Court’s resolution. As regards the disciplinary regime, you will remember that on 14 January the Commission decided to make a request for interim measures, asking the Court of Justice to order Poland to suspend the functioning of the disciplinary chamber. Meanwhile, I can only observe that the disciplinary chamber continues to operate. To conclude, I regret to say that these recent developments show that the situation is very serious. This is also reflected in the recent decision of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe to open a monitoring procedure over the functioning of Poland’s democratic institutions and the rule of law. At the same time, I want to reiterate that the Commission remains ready to continue a dialogue with the Polish authorities to solve the issues at hand. During my visit to Poland, the authorities expressed openness for having such dialogue both at political and technical level.  I trust that we can embark on an open discussion with Poland. Respect for the rule of law is a matter for both EU institutions and Member States, and it is an essential element for the functioning of the internal market based on mutual trust and recognition.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is telling of the urgency of the situation that we are back here discussing Poland today. We are here because Polish citizens are Europeans too, and they are no less deserving of the same protection and the same rights as anyone in Sweden, Italy or Germany. Where every avenue for justice available to them on a national level has been blocked, neutered or taken over, then we will not shy away from playing our role. We are having this discussion now as a measure of last resort, as an appeal to the Polish Government to choose dialogue over confrontation, to choose justice over prejudice, and to choose European values over the failed populism of the past. I take no satisfaction in pointing out the irony of the fact that the last time the judicial system in Poland was under such pressure from the government was before 1989.  What this Polish Government has done is move to the past. They have used the same tired tactics of regression and oppression that fly in the face of everything Europeans have fought against and everything that Europe stands for today. But, if that is what the Government symbolises, then the brave judges stand for exactly the opposite and we look to those judges with respect and honour. Their bravery to their oath is a true symbol of the Polish courage that the world admires.  There are consequences to being an EU Member State. There are rules of this club that states agreed to follow. So now the Commission must use all the possible tools to immediately apply interim measures to prevent further repression, to protect the European way and to protect the Polish people. The disciplinary chamber, the ‘Muzzle Law’, the continued anti-European path of the Government means that Poland is drifting away and we are here extending a hand. Do not turn your backs on Europe.  (Applause)

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Vice-President Jourová, as you know, I have the honour to chair the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, which debates the fulfilment of the principles enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union: rule of law, democracy, which is not the rule of majority, but respect for minorities , political pluralism and the right of the opposition to dissent, but which requires separation of powers and independence from the judiciary. That is why, unfortunately, we had to implement Article 7 in relation to Hungary. And, again, with Poland, which is the one we are dealing with now. Because in Poland we have seen an accumulation of legislative reforms that seriously threaten the independence of the judiciary: the Judicial Office, the Disciplinary Chamber, which has been declared unconstitutional and incompatible with European law by the Court of Justice of the European Union, and the threats of sanctions to judges who dare to disagree, whose dramatic testimony we have heard in this very European Parliament.  That is why all our support is to continue and to ensure that you carry out the mandate of the LIBE Commission that there is a permanent framework mechanism — framework for fundamental rights, democracy and Rule of Law — that is objective, permanent, comprehensive, involving all Member States and that, on a regular basis, it reviews compliance with the principles proclaimed in European law and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Under no circumstances can we consent to the existence of what has been described as a constitutional breakdown, that is, an anti-constitutional populist backsliding in any Member State of the European Union. Certainly not in Poland.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, I  remember when we had this debate last time, four weeks ago. I remember saying that the situation in Poland is unprecedented and that in fact never in the history of the EU has any Member State government exerted so much control over the judiciary. Now here we are, four weeks later, and the situation is even worse. Poland is now the first Member State where applying EU law can actually get judges fired. Worst of all, the Constitutional Court, which is supposed to be the ultimate guardian of checks and balances, is actually doing the Government’s bidding in its war on independent judges. Time is indeed running out because, if the Supreme Court is fully captured, which seems to be where we are headed, then it could spell the end of the separation of powers in one of our Member States. This is why the EU must indeed act.  As has been said, this is not to punish Poland or the Polish Government. This is for one simple reason: we must act to protect the civil and democratic rights of EU citizens, in this case Polish citizens. I often hear – and we’ll hear it here as well – that there’s a Western bias in our approach to Poland and that people in western Europe can’t understand the legal tradition and what it means to inherit the communist judiciary and try to reform it. So let me say, as a Slovak politician and as someone whose parents and family were actually persecuted by the communist judiciary, that judicial independence and rule of law is not a matter of legal tradition, but is a core constitutional principle of the European Union.  (Applause)

name: Hynek BLAŠKO
text: On the basis of the ID Group. A normal person would think that they would evaluate why the UK left, that the rhetoric would change. The opposite is true. Once again, strong words are being said about curtailing national sovereignty, how to crack down patriotism, etc. Tying up citizens with different directives is another intervention in their lives. We now have a campaign by the defenders of democracy against Poland, which has allowed itself to promote its concept of democracy at home, which is unacceptable to the Guardian. Only their view is the right one, which is why Poles are obliged to accept it.  I believe personally that no one has the right to meddly in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, because history shows that whenever that happened, it never went as expected. The question hangs in the air: Are you doing everything you can to create a domino effect?

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, one thing is true. There is not only one way to build a democratic system; not all legal traditions in Europe are the same. But for all democratic systems there is a pre-condition, and that is that winning a majority does not mean that you can undermine rule of law and fundamental rights. I mentioned both of them, because actually both of these are currently under attack in Poland. The independence of the judiciary and thus the separation of powers, which is the cornerstone of rule of law instead of the law of the ruler, but also fundamental rights, especially of those from whom they are most easy to be taken away. I believe that in our reply in the future on the discussion under the Article 7 procedure and the mechanism on the rule of law and also in the future debate, we should take both of these dimensions into consideration. Poland is a country in the heart of Europe. Without Poland, this Union could never be complete. Polish citizens are indeed European citizens. So instead of blaming Brussels or the European Court of Justice or whoever they want for what is going on, the Polish Government should actually engage in an open and constructive dialogue to solve these very urgent and important problems. And I urge you, colleagues, to also bring this message to Poland. Colleagues, no matter where you stand in this debate, what we have seen in smear campaigns, in hate campaigns, also against Members of this Parliament in Poland in the past month and years, is absolutely unacceptable. We can only engage in a democratic debate if we uphold the rights of, and respect towards, the other.

name: Beata SZYDŁO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Poland supports all actions aimed at strengthening the rule of law framework in the European Union, provided that they are directly empowered by the Treaties, respect the existing areas of competence and the national identity of the Member States, and are objective and non-discriminatory. I therefore regret that the European Parliament is clearly presenting a political tone and is so openly calling for the instrumental use of the rule of law. Polish system of justice needs to be reformed. For the last four years Polish the government has been in accordance with the Constitution, within the competences defined by the EU treaties and in accordance with the expectations of poles, because they are our sovereign, such reforms are carried out. We have started reforming the justice system and we will complete this reform.  The fact is that there is a legal and political dispute in Poland, but the decision of the former belongs to Polish courts and tribunals, and the latter to Polish politicians. The judiciary is an area not covered by European Union law and the involvement of Parliament or the European Commission in these matters violates the fundamental principles of the Treaty of the Union. It is also worth noting that the reforms introduced are modelled on solutions already in place and never challenged by EU bodies in other Member States. For example, the provisions prohibiting judges from speaking of a political nature, which operate in France, or the appointment by politicians of judges in the Czech Republic or Germany, are not called into question.   The reform of the judiciary is expected by the majority of Polish society, and Polish the government is acting in its interest and not in the interests of the chosen social, professional or political group. We want to complete the reforms of the Polish judiciary and, in accordance with the Treaties, like every country in the Community, we have the right to do so. Today's debate unfortunately has a political dimension. I find no justification for doing so here.  We debated the rule of law in Poland here three weeks ago. At that time, no substantiated facts were identified to prove that the rule of law was being violated in Poland. Today we return to the topic. One might get the impression that the European Parliament wants to create such a fictional reality.  Commissioner Jourová was in Poland at the time. It has received assurances from the most important people in the country about the willingness to cooperate and willingness to dialogue, but for dialogue and cooperation to be possible, both sides must want them, and I have the impression that for now this readiness is only on the side of the Polish government.  For 4 years we have been explaining what has been in place for a long time in other countries of the European Union. We explain the reforms that are being implemented along the lines of those in other Member States. Poland is denied sovereign decisions under the treaties. Why is this happening? I leave the answer to this question to you, colleagues, because parliament seems to need to reflect not on what is happening in Poland, but on what is happening here. Consider why Poland is criticised for solutions you know from your own countries. Ask yourself why you are debating the competences that the EU treaties have given to national parliaments and not to us here. Finally, ask yourself if you want to continue to be used for political games that are not yours. Finally, is it not your duty to protect the European Parliament from being treated as a tool in an electoral fight in a Member State? An election campaign is underway in Poland. It is likely that the aim of the initiators of today's debate was to entangled Parliament in its course, thus wanting to influence the electoral outcome in Poland. The EU institutions should not meddle in the electoral process in any Member State. That is why I am turning to you, FELLOW MEPs, do not succumb to the political pressure of frustrated people who, in being incoup with a democratic choice, want to influence this outcome in this way. I can only apologise to you for those Polish politicians who do not understand that national political disputes that are being transferred to the EU arena are harming the Community. I am sorry about this and I just feel embarrassed about it.  Poland is a member of the European Union, but above all it is a sovereign country and as such has the right and duty Polish to care for the interests of the Community and the well-being of its citizens, and this is done by the government in accordance with the Polish Constitution, in accordance with the EU treaties. We are co-creating and co-responsible for the European Union like all the Member States and we want to be treated on the same terms.  I have said many times, also in the past as Polish Prime Minister, here in the European Parliament, and today I say this as an POLISH MEP, that Poland is a rule-of-law country and that the government is acting Polish in accordance with the Polish Constitution and the EU Treaties. Poland is a member of the european union and is a sovereign country. That's the way it is and it will be.

name: Konstantinos ARVANITIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, it is unfair to hear opinions that the European Parliament or MEPs do not love Poland. It's not fair. But we cannot allow opportunistic policies in Member States to define and re-define and change the roadmap of fundamental rights and principles of the European Union. Current government policy in Poland also conflicts with many of these principles: on issues of the rule of law, separation of powers, freedom of expression, minority rights and even women's right to abortion. And in Poland — as far as we know — there is a government, there is no regime. In democracy governments change; our fundamental principles do not. They're getting better, they're renewing, but they're not being overturned. That is our position and I would ask you very much to listen to all the political groups and not the extreme right. The EHR, Renew, the Socialists, the Greens and the Left. We're not all wrong.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Madam President, today we speak about the rule of law in Europe and particularly in Poland. This is very necessary because if part of the Union lacks respect for the rule of law, this affects the whole Union. The problem is, however, if the EU is applying a double standard, acting in a different way depending on the country. If the rule of law in the Union has to be protected, the EU institutions have to be ready to go until the end with any state. To be strong with the weak and weak with the strong is also a violation of the rule of law. People from Poland that are following this debate can ask themselves: ‘and what of Spain?’ Why can Spain ignore the Committee of Human Rights of the United Nations or the resolutions of the European Court of Justice? Why is it okay when Spain imprisons political dissidents and its constitutional court manoeuvres to delay access to the European Court of Human Rights? Seriously, to strengthen the rule of law in the European Union we must finish with double standards. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Puigdemont, with all due respect, how you come to the House to give us lessons on the rule of law and the rule of law. You were the first, as president of the Government of Catalonia, to despise the rule of law when you unilaterally declared independence, going above the Statute of Autonomy and the Spanish Constitution. He repeatedly ignored constitutional court rulings. Don't you find all that stuff you've done inconsistent with the statement you just made in the House?

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Ruiz Devesa, thank you, you give me a great opportunity to explain a clear example of that double standard. Look, if I travel to Poland tomorrow, I am convinced that in Poland my immunity will be respected as a member of this European Parliament and I will not be arrested. If I travel to Spain tomorrow, I am convinced that the Spanish authorities will not respect the immunity granted to me by this Parliament and I will be arrested and put in prison for the rest of my life. That is exactly the attitude that is not in Europe's interest to defend the rule of law where it is threatened.

name: Andrzej HALICKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Indeed, this is not a debate on judicial reform, because there is no such reform in Poland. Access to the courts is longer, charges more expensive, citizens can actually feel let down. This is a debate about one party's desire to appropriate the judiciary, about building a system that gives impunity to power. The symbol of recent days in Poland became the party nominee, the government, who tossed the resolution, acting not only illegally, but arrogantly suggesting that it would go unpunished. This is how the government wants to treat the Constitution, eu treaties or other obligations, and there can be no agreement on that.  There cannot be agreement in our community, because citizens have the right to expect their rights, civil rights, human rights to be protected, and judges are judges who work throughout the European Union for all of us, and they must have a legal guarantee. I hear that Poland is being harassed by the European Union. Well, no. It is you – I say to Law and Justice – who harass judges and Poles. Here is a report that concerns 64 judges who have been repressed illegally by the Disciplinary Board, which should not act. You are the one who use falsehood and propaganda – and there is no permission for that, too. However, I have one good piece of information for the Commission: Polish society has in history been able to cope with those who have been raped and wanted to be unpunished. It will be the same now.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The independent experts of the Venice Commission could not have been clearer in their judgment: if Poland decides on the latest judicial reform, judges will be placed in the – so literally – impossible situation that they face disciplinary penalties if they apply European law. The experts strongly warned the Polish government against passing this law. What did we see last week? The Polish President signs precisely that law against all warnings. This has consequences for Polish society, and it also has very personal consequences. Just last week, the Disciplinary Chamber suspended Judge Pawe' Juszczyszyn from duty and reduced his salary by 40%. His misdemeanour - his alleged: He questioned the occupation of a panel appointed by the new pro-government National Judicial Council. The Judicial Council which Poland's Supreme Court has declared unlawful in accordance with a judgment of the ECJ. And by whom was he suspended? From the Disciplinary Chamber, which should also have been out of function for a long time. It, too, has been declared illegal by the Supreme Court of Poland, and the EU Commission has requested its immediate suspension to the ECJ. So you can see, in many small pieces of mosaic, that many, many small laws mean that the primacy of European law should no longer apply in Poland, and that the independence of the judiciary should no longer apply. We now need action from the Commission before the European Court of Justice and we must no longer allow cherry picking to take place. There are not only rights in the European Union, there are also obligations, and the rule of law is one of them. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Patryk JAKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I wanted to ask you because you are from Germany. You speak very generally, but let us talk about detailed solutions. In the law mentioned by you, Article 107 says that for insulting the law, the judge is liable for actions that may prevent the functioning of the judicial authorities in Poland. On the other hand, I have a translation of the German Penal Code, according to which a judge or other person who conducts cases in the case of bending the law faces between one and five years in prison. I ask you which law is muzzly muzzed in this case: Polish or German.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. So, firstly, I do not represent Germany here, I represent citizens of the European Union here. Secondly, Mrs Szydeo lied a short day by saying that German judges must not engage in political activity. There are even colleagues from the AFD, its much-loved sister party in Germany, who sit in the German Bundestag. So that's a lie. And what you are quoting is a bending of the law. This is something completely different – that's when you deliberately twist laws. What your colleague has done is to appeal to a European court, to apply European law. No one in Germany is certainly being punished for having a different legal view, unfortunately in Poland, and that is the difference.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Madam President, in January, judges from 20 European countries marched silently on the streets of Warsaw in solidarity with their Polish colleagues. We should manifest the same solidarity here with all those in the Polish legal system who are desperately trying to defend their independence – but not in words, in decisions. Commissioner, you are right. What is going on right now in Poland, when it comes to the judiciary, is not reform but destruction. We cannot sit and watch when the Government is dismantling, bit by bit, what defines the identity of an EU Member State, because it is in the Union’s legal DNA to have independent, impartial courts operating in accordance with fair trial rules which are able to uphold Union law. Now the Polish authorities, through their recently-adopted legislation, are moving the country further away from Europe and threatening the supremacy of EU law. I was hearing my colleagues earlier speaking about reform. I think it is that reform, from the time of Arabela and Pani Rumburak and the magic ring, which made EU law and EU rule of law disappear. So please, Commissioner, go back to Poland and remind them that Poland is the main beneficiary of EU funds in the Union and then, when you come back, let’s get that legislation done, making EU funding conditional on EU law.  (The speaker refused to take a blue-card question from Jadwiga Wiśniewska)

name: Nicola BEER
text: Maybe you will have the possibility to answer if you accept a blue card. There were several blue cards, I can take only one, from colleague Wiśniewska. Do you accept it?

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – (start of speech inaudible) somebody sitting in a European institution but ignoring European rules and rule of law.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: – Madam President, with the ‘Muzzle Law’, the Polish Government has outlawed their judges. They are now not only intimidated, but also criminalised for exercising their profession, which is judging independently and in line with EU law. This is another alarming step towards a dictatorial and undemocratic state because this curtailment not only destroys the checks and balances, but it also deprives citizens of their right to be protected against their authorities, and, in the end, it affects all of us as it puts our core values at risk. Impunity also fuels the erosion of the rule of law elsewhere. I therefore urge the Commission to continue its actions and to start infringement procedures, asking for an interim measure in order to suspend the enforcement of the ‘Muzzle Law’.  But I also urge the Member States not to leave the work only to the EU institutions. It’s high time that government leaders take their own responsibility by addressing the Polish Government. They have all the instruments in place – political and legal ones – but, until now, have preferred to hide behind the Commission. The house of the rule of law is on fire and citizens, not only from Poland, rightly demand that we act.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Your predecessor said that judges in Poland were protesting against justice reform. Yes, they protested peacefully, because the Polish authorities ensured the safety of the protesters, unlike France, where protesting lawyers were batoning. That's the first thing. Secondly, where is your left-wing sensibility? Who will be reprimanded by the courts, including, for example, a farmer who, in the face of injustice (because it is difficult to call it justice), has taken away all his life's assets and who has died wrongly wronged in prison? Where is this rule of law?

name: Tineke STRIK
text: blue-card answer. – Sorry, I really don’t understand the context of this question. I’m sorry. There was a reference to the previous speaker, who talked about a silent protest, which is true. We have all seen that. They protested, very rightly, against the curtailment of their professional task, namely judging independently. You think that democracy is only the right of a majority, but that’s not the case. Democracy is about protecting everyone, including minorities, and democracy cannot go without the rule of law.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, the Polish authorities seem to be more interested in confrontation than compromise. After Commissioner Jourová's visit, we hoped that the way would be opened for honest, serious and transparent dialogue. Instead, what we have seen is this new law that is yet another attack on the independence of the judiciary.  Only since January of this year have more than forty judges been put in the spotlight simply because they disagree with government decisions. What kind of justice haunts judges? What is the true purpose of this reform? Improve the administration of justice or bring justice under political control? Justice under political control is not compatible with the democratic values that make us Europeans.  I'm sorry to say it so crudely, but what we see in Poland is not reform, it's repression. When the independence of justice is jeopardized, it is time for the Commission, the Court of Justice of the European Union and we to intervene. The role of judges is to ensure that the rule of law is complied with in the European Union.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – Since PiS took power, the Minister of Justice and Attorney General Ziobro have been destroying the Polish system. Unfortunately, it is aimed at a complete clash with the European institutions and its own citizens. Polish, the government is ready to bring about another catastrophe: the freezing of EU funds and the slow polexit. Of course, he has one goal: to defend his party interests. And this is a real threat that, unfortunately, ordinary citizens can pay for.  Fortunately, there is still no sign of equality between Poles and the ruling party in Poland. Today Poland is people who defend democracy and want to live in a law-abiding country, and through the crazy amok PiS unfortunately can not. That is why, today, when we debate the rule of law, we must remember ordinary people who, through the inedibility and madness of PiS governments, can pay the greatest price: freezing funds and slow polexit. And we, the pro-democracy side, must defend the position of poles against your madness. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Anyone who talks about polexit wants only brawls. I am an MEP elected from Polish. I am a Polish woman proud of her country, of a nation with a beautiful history and beautiful people. Let's not scare people with polexit. It is just as possible as the exit of Germany or France from the European Union.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Dear Mrs. Messenger, I too am proud of the Polish. I am proud of a country that had the second oldest constitution in the world. I am proud of a country that has overthrowing communism, but I am ashamed that there are people in my country who are worse than the Communists because they have destroyed the country more than the Communists have done. And this is the greatest shame of the Third Republic.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Please, no debate, I will not allow a debate. I allowed the blue card but there was no question in the blue card, so I just state that the next blue card has to have a question inside – this is not additional speaking time.

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Madam President, dear Commissioner Jourova, dear Commissioner Reynders, Commissioner for Justice, Mrs Brnjac, Secretary of State for European Affairs, ladies and gentlemen, these are masts produced in Gdansk that support the 27 European flags on the forecourt of our Parliament. We respect the Polish people. We no longer recognize him through his government. This new disciplinary regime against judges who are reluctant to do judicial reforms put in place by this government is not acceptable. We are witnessing the gradual dismantling, brick by brick, of historical achievements. They are the pillars of the rule of law and our democratic model. However, ladies and gentlemen, we need to strengthen the area of freedom and justice, we need strong judicial institutions to implement ambitious and important texts, such as the removal of terrorist content online or the use of electronic evidence by judges. Madam Commissioner, what actions are you going to take to put an end to this situation which is undermining the rule of law in Europe?

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, Madam Vice-President Jourová, I am a proud European from Central Europe, a region where some 30 years ago our leaders followed a political vision of a return to democratic and free Europe. Let’s remember: Central and Eastern Europe’s return to Europe has changed the European Union fundamentally and for the better. Peace and democracy have spread across the continent, and the European sense of dignity, reliable rules and due justice should nowadays be the same across the different parts of our Union. The problem is that it is not. As a Slovak Member of this House, I am concerned about the quality of justice and credibility of European rules across the whole Union, and therefore I am standing here to defend the independence of both Polish and European justice. Do believe me, and I’m saying this is a fellow Central European: there is no hidden agenda other than our concern for quality of democracy and credibility of rule of law in Poland and our Union. Dear colleagues, for the sake of all Europeans, we cannot risk the return of a misuse of justice that will undo Europe as we know it now.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Let me begin by saying that I have a deep attachment to the citizens of Poland. I say this especially as an Austrian. Austrians have historically owed a great deal to Poland. We must also know that Poland suffered particularly from the ideologies of the 20th century. We must also know that the Second World War began with an attack on Poland, and Austrians were also involved in this Nazi criminal state. And the raid was based on a lie. I say this because, at the same time, I would like to say that the Poles do not deserve this leadership, which casts doubt on the rule of law, which undermines the rule of law. Like all Europeans, they deserve all the citizens of this Union, a leadership that lives the rule of law. The people in the leadership should also think about the future, about their children and children who deserve a constitutional state.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, the current Polish Government and the so-called Law and Justice Party proclaims the rule of law, but in fact it acts against the rule of law every day. We should look at the actions of this Government, not at the statements of this Government. What the Polish Government sells to its people as judiciary reform is in fact erosion of democracy. They call it decommunisation, but we know it is censure. They say it is modernising the system, but we all recognise it is authoritarianism. More than this, we know that Poland is more than its current government. Governments come and go. We know that Poland is the honest judge who protects the independence of the judiciary and the rule of law, despite intimidation and repression. Poland is the courageous citizen who protects against the Government’s attacks on the rule of law and Poland is the honest and objective journalist who defies the Government’s propaganda by promoting the freedom of speech. We stand with the people of Poland, and to the Polish Government I say: listen to the people of your country. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear Mate! I do not know if you know, but 20 000 citizens Polish not stand up for the Polish government in order to continue reforming the courts. That's the first thing. Secondly, I do not know whether you are familiar with the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, because you will not read from any article and paragraph the competence of Parliament and the European Commission to have such debates take place.  And finally, a request to the President. Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. I ask you not to use epithets in relation to any country, no country is accused or offended.

name: Nicola BEER
text: There is no question, so how do you want the colleague to answer? For the last time I will give him the opportunity because you tried to have extra speaking time, but this is not acceptable. So please, 30 seconds, but we will only accept questions.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: blue-card answer. – Madam President, the question was clear: whether I know the Treaty of the European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. And the answer is simple: yes I do. And I also know the articles of the Treaty which speak about the European values, and I also know that it is our duty to defend the rule of law in every single corner of Europe, because this is a European value. And I also know about the tens of thousands of people in Poland who have gone to the streets, marched for the rule of law, spoken against the Government – and we are in solidarity with them.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, former Prime Minister Szydło also mentioned the Czech Republic in her speech. My colleague, I have been Minister of Justice in the Czech Republic for 5 years and we do not punish Czech judges for their political views. You're wrong, we don't have this kind of legislation, I've prepared these laws myself.  We punish judges for delays in proceedings and apparent excesses, but if someone expresses their political views, they have the right to do so. He is a citizen of the democratic rule of law. Your law of 5 February, unfortunately, is a great excess, it is not comparable to what is needed in the Czech Republic or other EU countries, and I also regret, as my colleagues, that instead of trying to find a compromise and find a solution, your President has unfortunately signed a law that confirms the disciplinary liability of judges. Instead of punishing judges if they break the law, if they have delays, if they have obvious excesses, you punish them for having an opinion on your reform. It's a really bad adjustment.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – (start of speech outside the microphone) ... violations of the rule of law in Poland, demanding examples. Well, I will give her an example from today. The current government has been trying for years to frame former European Council President Donald Tusk for the imaginary Smolensk attack. His lawyer, also a former deputy prime minister in Jaroslaw Kaczynski's government, said it would be absurd to charge him. However, at the request of the current Minister, he was today brought before the so-called Disciplinary Chamber. So the fact that a lawyer says his client is innocent is already a reason for harassment today. This is not a European understanding of the rule of law. I therefore thank the Commissioner and the Commission for trying to help us restore the rule of law in Poland.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I truly believe that we have common values and common rules, and if these values are threatened, then we must respond. That's why we're having fun here today. I believe that there is a clear threat to the rule of law in one country, and this is damaging our mutual trust. In my opinion, such behaviour is completely unacceptable.  I would very much like Mrs Szydło to remember her speech at this point as Prime Minister, when we were debating the constitutional reforms she was carrying out, and she told us that she would respect the venetian commission's footage. Nothing like that happened. The Venice Commission issued conclusions that were unequivocally against Polish reform. And you dare to tell us today that your reforms are in order? This kind of behaviour is completely unacceptable to me. I think you should be ashamed of Yourself, Mrs. Szydło!

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I was surprised when, after a meeting with Ursula von der Leyen, the Prime Minister of the Polish Government stated that the subject of this meeting was not the rule of law. How is it possible that the President of the European Commission did not raise this issue during her meeting with the Prime Minister of that government? I am concerned when the Croatian Presidency suggests that the rule of law is not its priority, because I cannot imagine that the rule of law debate will be held back for six months. We know that many actions have proved ineffective. We know that Article 7 is ineffective. We also know that without a mechanism linking the rule of law and EU funds, we will not stop the years-long festival of constitutional violations. Of course, this mechanism is intended to hit the perpetrators of infringements, not citizens and citizens. And I will keep an eye on that, but above all, we must be aware that the time of diplomacy is over. Poles and Poles expect clear declarations and actions from the European Commission. They expect what the Commission specifically wants to do to defend Polish citizens and citizens, Polish judges who have been harassed for defending the Polish constitution. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We expect concrete action.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Madam President, the European Union is built on the rule of law, standing or falling on it. As early as 2017, Parliament made it clear that the situation in Poland poses serious risks of violations of the Fundamental Value of the Union and the independence of the judiciary.  We have recently reaffirmed this position and, by resolution, have assessed that the state of the rule of law has deteriorated since the application of Article 7. But apparently all this does not help, because now, after the adoption of the famous "muzzle law", which allows politicians to punish and fire judges, the situation in Poland is even worse. Indeed, it is high time, and apparently also the only way to link the disbursements of Union funds to the financial mechanism of respect for the rule of law, and in the event of infringements, we freeze these funds.  The rules just have to be respected. What is happening in Poland, however, affects the entire legal system of the Union. Let me not even talk about not even talking about the failure to respect the rule of law in some other Member States or in political parties in them.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Every time we are in Strasbourg, we discuss the Polish judicial reform, and I must say that I am astonished at the zeal with which the Polish Members of the Left and the Centre are involved in smashing their own country into the pan. You should have read the decision of the European Court of Justice of 19.11.2019. Just because the judges do not appoint themselves, but because the judges are appointed by Parliament and the Ministry of Justice, the separation of powers is not in question, otherwise there would be no separation of powers, for example in Germany or the USA. What you are asking for in Poland, namely that the judges can appoint and promote themselves, is a special Polish route which has nothing to do with the separation of powers. Separation of powers means: independence in decision-making, independence after appointment, but not appointment by itself.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, Poland has come under fire from the European institutions for wanting to democratise its political and judicial system. It's a sad truth we have to look in the eye.  The misunderstanding that old members and European bureaucracy show towards post-communist members, such as Poland, leads to a conflict that is of no one's interest. Old democracies need to understand that without the lustration of a new democracy, they will never reach their standards.  Corruption and clientelism in post-communist states are no accident. It is a systemic error resulting from the fact that parts of the old communist system survived and as such were incorporated into the new democratic system. They prevent the past from being shed light, protect politicians, judges, public workers and entrepreneurs of communist roots and make it impossible to complete the transition that unfortunately all post-communist states really need.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, allow me to come back to certain issues raised during this debate. First, as regards the new law (because there’s a new law since our last debate some weeks ago), I would like to assure you that the Commission is always open to a fair dialogue with Member States to solve problems but will not hesitate to use all the tools at its disposal to ensure the respect of EU law. The new law raises concerns of compatibility with EU law, including the principle of the primacy of EU law, the requirements of judicial independence under EU law, and the right to refer questions to the European Court of Justice. The Commission is analysing the law in detail, and in reply to comments from some Members, let me reiterate that the European Court of Justice ruled that until the organisation of justice in the Member States falls within their competence, the fact remains that when exercising that competence, the Member States are required to comply with their obligations under EU law. EU law requires respect for the rule of law, in particular judicial independence. This is crucial, because Polish courts are European courts and they have to ensure that Polish citizens can fully enjoy their rights under EU law. This is why I’m seriously concerned by the new law, and I can assure you, as Commissioner for Justice, that the Commission will take its responsibility as the Guardian of the Treaty and take all necessary measures to ensure the respect of EU law. I also note that the Disciplinary Chamber continues to operate, despite the rulings of the Supreme Court. In those rulings, following the Court of Justice judgment of 19 November, the Supreme Court concluded that the Disciplinary Chamber is not a court within the meaning of EU and national law. I would like to stress that preliminary rulings of the Court of Justice are biding and need to be fully respected. National courts must apply national law in line with the interpretation of the Court of Justice. Notably, on 4 February 2020, the Disciplinary Chamber decided to suspend in office the first judge seeking to apply the ruling of the Court of Justice of 19 November 2019. He has also been subject to a 40% reduction of his salary. The Supreme Court also ruled that the National Council for the Judiciary is not an independent and impartial body. However, the Council continues to operate. As an example, on 31 January it selected six candidates to the Disciplinary Chamber, two of which being current members of the National Judicial Council. In the light of today’s debate, let me say a few words on the situation of the Constitutional Tribunal. I want to recall that in its reasoned proposal of December 2017 triggering the Article 7 procedure, the Commission concluded that the independence and legitimacy of the Constitutional Tribunal are seriously undermined and consequently, the constitutionality of Polish laws can no longer be effectively guaranteed. I can only note in this respect that, following the rulings of the Supreme Court and the European Court of Justice judgment, the tribunal has been seized by a number of authorities. Your debate reminds me of statements warning that the current situation leads to legal chaos. I will simply reply that the remedy to such a situation is that rulings rendered by independent courts must be fully respected by all authorities. To conclude, let me add that the Commission is working on a comprehensive European rule of law mechanism. It will be a preventive tool covering all Member States and will provide a synthesis of significant developments related to the different components of the rule of law. It will be based on a variety of sources of information in order to reflect the reality on the ground. This will allow us to identify and prevent early on rule-of-law-related issues. This new mechanism will cover all Member States in the same way. The first annual Rule of Law Report is one of the key initiatives of the Commission Work Programme for 2020. The preparation of this report is already in an operational phase. We have established a network of contact persons of Member States which will help with its preparation. The report will also be part of the new rule-of-law cycle, with strong involvement of the European Parliament and the Council. However, let me be clear that this preventive mechanism does not replace response mechanisms like infringement procedures and the Article 7 procedure where they prove necessary. We will continue to use all the tools at our disposal to promote and protect the rule of law in all the Member States, including Poland.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me stress once again that the Presidency, and the Council as a whole, attach great importance to upholding the rule of law and protecting fundamental rights. They are at the heart of our concerns. I can assure you that the Presidency will pay particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate. On the next steps regarding the Article 7 procedure in the Council, although the rule of law is one of the priorities of the Croatian Presidency, the Presidency cannot prejudge the Council’s deliberations nor the outcome of the procedure. The Council will continue to follow developments closely and will remain to be seized of this issue at the upcoming General Affairs Council meeting.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. Judicial independence is the essential principle of the rule of law on which our European Union is based. In Poland, we are watching with concern how the right-wing conservative government is systematically rebuilding the judiciary. The new law now largely abolishes judicial independence. This is a serious attack on the democratic rule of law in Poland. Judges to control judges politically, the rule of law system, which is based on the separation of powers, is overriding. In addition, it is made considerably more difficult for Polish judges to obtain preliminary rulings from the ECJ. We must not allow ourselves to do so, because Polish courts are European dishes. The European Court of Justice has made it clear in many judgments that the design of the judicial systems in the Member States must be in line with EU law and European values. I would like to stress that all people in Europe have the right to the best possible, confident and independent courts. The success of the new Commission– as guardian of the Treaties – will ultimately be measured by the defence of the rule of law in Europe.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on the protection of the EU's internal market and consumer rights from the negative effects of the illegal trade in pet animals by Stanislav Polik, Sylwia Spurek, Martin Hojsik, Alexandra Louise Rosenfield Phillips, Jadwiga Winiewska, Anja Hazekamp and Eleonora Evi on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, public health and food safety (O-000010/2020 - B9-0003/2020) (2019/2814(RSP)) and – the oral question to the Commission on the protection of the EU's internal market and consumer rights from the negative effects of the illegal trade in pet animals of Stanislav Polik, Sylwia Spurek, Martin Hojsik, Alexandra Louise Rosenfield Phillips, Jadwiga Wisniewska, Anja Hazekamp and Eleonora Evi on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000011/2020 – B9—0004/2020) (2019/2814(RSP)). I would like to remind you once again that you can display the spontaneous speeches and 'blue cards' here both electronically and with the lifting of the respective cards.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Author. – Madam President, I believe that this issue will not be so explosive and that we will have a much higher degree of unity and understanding across political factions. These are oral questions to the Commission and the Council and the subsequent motion for a resolution on the illegal trade in PET animals in the EU. I would like to say that we are building on the work of my colleague Renata Sommer from the previous period. Parliament has already made a number of resolutions in this area in the previous period, but words and the text of the resolution are not enough, and I think action is needed. I would therefore like to call on the Commission and the Member States to listen carefully and to come up with a rapid and effective response. This is a topic that is really important for anyone who is not indifferent to the suffering of illegally farmed animals. These are millions of damaged consumers and, of course, millions of damaged animals, also with regard to their well-being in which they are to be kept. Unfortunately, smugglers now have almost no obstacles in their way, and these smugglers make the most money from the status quo. This illegal animal trade is, ladies and gentlemen, the third most profitable illegal business after the sale of arms and drugs. A huge problem, especially in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, are so-called breeding establishments, i.e. breeding establishments where dogs and cats are bred in appalling conditions with the prospect of fast and easy earnings. Unfortunately, consumers are also, of course, misled, who very often do not care about the origin of the animal at all, or even false documents are presented. Illegal breeders also use various very sophisticated tricks to entice potential buyers to buy a puppy or cat from a breeding house. Unfortunately, they very often hear about them precisely by getting a very quickly desired pet, and often at a lower price. Paradoxically, this is in a situation where dog shelters are overcrowded with other higher quality pieces. At the same time, it is necessary to prepare for illegal breeders, despite the tightening of the rules, to look for ways to circumvent these rules. If anyone is not convinced that animals sick or prone to diseases are released from the breeding plants, I recommend looking at neighbors across the Atlantic to the USA, where they are currently facing an epidemic of the disease, which is resistant to most antibiotics and which is currently associated with puppies from breeding plants. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported in January that at least 30 people have also been given this highly infectious disease. To do this, it is important to remember that, in addition to the negative effects on the animals themselves, the illegal trade in pet animals also has, of course, wider implications, e.g. on our single internal market, consumer protection, which is just unknowingly buying a sick and traumatised animal.  We therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to develop strategies for regulating online advertising of pet animals in order to suppress misleading advertising and better control the online sales of cats and dogs. I think it is quite clear today that unethical treatment of pets is indeed a Europe-wide problem, which also requires a Europe-wide solution, the problem is indeed cross-border. Part of this solution should be the blanket and mandatory marking of pets, their shared records, thanks to which not only pets will be traceable to the store, but at the same time all stray animals, and also, of course, the tightening of breeding conditions. Of course, the suffering of animals in illegal breeding and subsequent transport across Europe, in which hundreds of thousands of puppies and kittens suffer every year, must also be put to an end. This cannot be avoided without rigorous controls, which, unfortunately, are currently toothless. It is the wild breeding houses in the houses of veterinarians that often do not reveal, there are, of course, only those registered breeding stations. There is a lot that needs to be done to improve the situation, so I appreciate the good negotiations with my colleagues. There is a proposal for some fundamental changes that would mark a major step forward in the fight against illegal pet breeding. I therefore appeal to the Commission and the Member States to really pay due attention to this problem and to speak out clearly and decisively in defence of those who cannot defend themselves.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, in the recent years the illegal trade in companion animals has become a growing challenge for Member States’ competent authorities, and it has also raised concerns among EU citizens. The main difficulty relates to the abuse of the so-called ‘pet travel scheme’, the rapid development of online sales of companion animals and the risk associated with these activities. Indeed, we all know that illegal trade in pets may have negative consequences, not only in terms of public health and consumer protection, but also for animal welfare and animal health. I agree that this situation requires our full attention, and I can assure you that the Member States are fully aware of this problem. At the end of 2018, 17 Member States participated in an EU-coordinated control plan on the online sales of dogs and cats in order to gain insight into practices in this field. It turned out that a high percentage of the animals offered for sale was non-compliant. This confirmed the clear need to strengthen controls. I agree that identification and traceability of cats and dogs are key elements in this respect. The existing EU legislation already requires pet animals which are moved between Member States or imported into the EU to be marked. In addition, the new regulation on animal health and official controls offers further tools to fight illegal trade. Proper enforcement of the existing rules is of crucial importance. This is primarily the responsibility of the Commission and the Member States. I should also mention that since the adoption of the new regulation on animal health and official controls, the Council working party of Chief Veterinary Officers has intensively discussed how to better fight illegal trade in companion animals. These discussions highlighted the complexity of the problem and the need for continued cooperation between all competent authorities, including among Member States. We expect these discussions to continue within the Working Group on e—commerce that the Commission has established, as well as within the voluntary initiative group of the EU Platform on Animal Welfare devoted to the health and welfare of pets in trade. Finally, I would like to remind you that the Council, in its recent conclusions on animal welfare, has encouraged the Commission and the Member States to continue their work on the effective enforcement of the existing animal welfare legislation. The Council has also invited the Commission to assess the need for the impact of the possible new legislation.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this is an issue that I personally feel strongly about and it’s something that we, like Parliament, are committed to controlling and stopping. But in order to guide our discussion correctly, we need to start from the fact that the welfare of companion animals in the EU is mainly regulated at the national level. Member States have sole competence for cat and dog welfare, and they also have the sole responsibility for the identification, registration and conditions for keeping and moving these animals within their natural territory. EU rules cover cross-border trade in cats and dogs. Clear rules apply to both commercial and non-commercial movements and cover both animals moved within the EU and also those entering from the outside. These rules are mainly designed to protect animal health and prevent the spread of animal diseases, especially rabies. They also ensure any dogs and cats entering the EU or moved between countries are properly identified and vaccinated. Where illegal trade in cats and dogs is identified, it is therefore not due to a lack of legislation but because the legislation that is in place is not properly enforced by the Member States, and this is where we need to invest a lot more energy. In recent years we have tried to strengthen the legal framework to help Member States tackle illegal trade. The new Animal Health Law, which comes into force in April 2021, has made important changes. Firstly, it requires compulsory registration of all establishments breeding dogs and cats, and all transporters who take dogs and cats between Member States. Secondly, it obliges Member States to improve all shelters and assembly centres from which dogs and cats are moved to other Member States. These new measures will help to control trade of companion animals in a better way, and we consider that they are sufficient for tackling illegal trade. But again, it is crucial that these rules are properly applied and enforced, and for this we have taken several actions in Member States. The first of these is the EU coordinated control plan on the online sale of dogs and cats, this in order to give Member States insight into fraudulent practices and encourage them to control the online market more effectively. And the second is the voluntary initiative launched in the framework of the EU Animal Welfare Platform: the sub-group on health and welfare of pets, and this involves all relevant stakeholders and provides guidelines to ensure better animal health and welfare for companion animals. Thirdly, and finally: training provided for national authorities via the Better Training for Safer Food initiative, which encourages best practices to control imports and trade of dogs and cats. One element the new rules do not cover is the development of interconnected databases, and I believe that this is a question of proportionality. We consider that this would be disproportionate to the animal health risk without a clear indication of EU added value. We will, however – and I want to be clear on this – monitor the situation closely, continue working with Member States and stakeholders to ensure the illegal trade in cats and dogs in the EU is brought to an end.

name: Liudas MAŽYLIS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President. During The First World War, the great soldier Schweich had a reliable business – trading stolen dogs. After a hundred years, we have modernised, pets are bought online, but not always submerged because of responsibility and risk. We understand the threat of zoonoses, alima to name their well-known specimens, that these days there is a growing mention of Coronavirus. We are able to control rabies with vaccines, but the illegal trade in pets increases the likelihood of infection. Rabies seems to have been overcome in both Lithuania and the Netherlands, and va in the Netherlands is again recorded. Vaccination is carried out on too young vaccinated pets. Another threat, the inappropriate conditions faced by animals kept for illegal breeding, their transport. Even a legally purchased pet is treated as a commodity, and after all, it is a living creature. So we are talking about both health and animal welfare and, finally, consumer protection. Mandatory European labelling of cats and dogs would be a way out. And no longer in the first context, in this chamber bears talk about the lack of research. I would also support the strengthening of sanctions against institutions at various levels, which are looking at this illegal business.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, each year a significant number of companion animals is illegally traded across the Member States. They are often subjected to long journeys across the EU without food and water. The trafficking in companion animals has negative implications not only on animal welfare, obviously, but also on public health and consumer protection. We need tougher sanctions on the traffickers, better cross-border cooperation on law enforcement, and stricter animal health requirements. We need training for the law enforcement to better react in specific cases related to illegal trade in companion animals. We call on the Commission for stricter rules on the identification and registration of cats and dogs, as well as the registration and licensing of all breeders and sellers. The systems for registration shall be interconnected among the Member States also to secure online trading, since 80% of the whole illegal trade is online trade. Last but not least, more public awareness campaigns should be carried out to inform citizens about the negative effects of the illegal trade in companion animals and the importance of purchasing only companion animals that have been bred, kept and traded in a responsible manner and with due concern for animal welfare. Moreover, we call on the Member States to carry out more information and awareness-raising campaigns to encourage adopting, rather than buying, companion animals. If more people adopted pets instead of buying, or at least did better research on animal breeders, illegal traders would see their business slowly diminish.

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, dear Commissioner, dear Presidency, 100 000 puppies – that’s the approximate estimate of the number of puppies exported from my country, Slovakia, every year. That’s just the export, and it’s an estimate because a large part of it is illegal trade: trade that is not only a problem for animal welfare of the puppies, of the kittens and other companion animals; trade that is also a problem from the point of view of organised crime, that I actually have witnessed first-hand as part of the animal welfare movement. The same organised crime that’s handling people, that’s handling heroin and weapons, is also handling puppies. It sounds weird, but that’s the case. It’s also a problem of the tax losses, and above all, it’s also problem of human health. There is a new phenomenon that is now dominating the entire trade, and that’s the online platforms. And that’s what makes it even more of a European problem. That’s why we need the European Commission to step up its efforts and to really provide proper guidance for identification and registration of animals across the borders, and for the Member States to actually start properly implementing and enforcing the regulation that’s out there, especially the animal health law. Because what we face is a crisis, and what we need is action, not words.

name: Marco DREOSTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, illegal puppy trafficking must not continue to fill the pockets of organised crime, undermining public health and, above all, animal welfare.  According to Coldiretti, there are over 400 000 puppies of dogs and cats in Italy that are victims of traffickers, for a turnover of around EUR 300 million per year. Recently, the Italian police in Friuli Venezia Giulia cleared out real gangs trafficking puppies from Eastern Europe, transported in horrific conditions, snatched from their mothers in advance.  We therefore need a resolution providing for a compulsory identification system and the tightening of sanctions, in order to effectively combat the deplorable practice of the illegal trade in puppies. I therefore welcome the regulation, but above all we need cross-border cooperation between the customs authorities of European countries in order to combat this illegal trade that is so bad for us, but much more so for our dear four-legged friends.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, in Serbia a French bulldog costs on average three hundred and seventy-five euros in Germany and France, and in Sweden these figures can reach 1,800 and 700 euros.  This price difference between the various countries has exposed the illegal trade in dogs and cats in the European Union. This black market thus encourages illegal breeders to transport these animals to the countries where their sale is most profitable. But this sickening and illegal system, which alters the ages and falsifies the vaccination bulletins of these animals, is only possible due to the absence of a Community register of certified breeders.  This Community omission is the deplorable and illegal conditions under which these animals are transported within community space. And in order to stop this illegal trade, the European Union must create legislation requiring Member States to guarantee official records of all pet animals, but not only. This system will only be effective if national databases can be crossed at supranational level within the European Union. The conclusion for us is clear: any national law without a European registration system will fail.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, pets provide a lot of fun, but behind the pet trade there is also a great deal of animal suffering. Pets are bought on a whim and thrown away with the same ease. Every day in Europe, animals are neglected, mistreated, dumped or killed. Commissioner, did you know that in Ireland greyhounds are given drugs and steroids to perform on the racecourse, leaving them toothless and weakened at the end of the season? Did you know that in Spain galgos used for hunting are punished by being hung from trees until they suffocate exhausted? Did you know that in many Eastern European countries stray dogs are set on fire or fed with antifreeze or broken glass? Did you know that all over Europe stray cats are being poisoned, shot, their tails are being pulled out, ears are being cut off or whole litters are being drowned? Did you know that for the rogue puppy trade puppies are bred in large barns, after which they are sold over the internet? Commissioner, this trade must be dealt with harshly. Puppy barns should be banned once and for all. In addition, all dogs and cats must be required to be microchipped and registered, there should be more checks and more severe punishment, especially for falsifying passports and chips. We must put an end to this organised crime and this suffering of animals.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, those who buy a puppy do not want to finance the third most lucrative organised crime in Europe, preceded only by drug and arms trafficking. Those who buy a puppy certainly do not want thousands of dogs and cats to be snatched from their mothers early and forced on hellish journeys where sometimes only half arrive alive at their destination. Yet this is what happens to a very large number of unsuspecting European citizens who buy an animal through some online ads or without carrying out the necessary checks. This nightmare must end and the solution is at hand.  We need a compulsory identification and registration system that is harmonised at European level, enabling national databases to be set up that are interconnected so that full traceability of animals is possible. It is also necessary to tighten sanctions and controls, to severely punish, not only those who traffic in animals, but also veterinarians and the authorities who are complicit in this business.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Commissioner, commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Who doesn't know them? The dog or cat as a faithful companion. I myself come from a small farm, where people treat animals very dignified and very naturally. Animals cannot speak for themselves, so we must do so here, and many dogs and cats are not treated in an appropriate manner in Europe. Illegal trade in these animals is flourishing, often in very terrible conditions. Savings are being made on the health and welfare of animals in order to create additional profit. We have to do something. I propose four measures: firstly, we need to tighten controls in the Member States, which is Member State competence, not Commission competence, as I am aware of. However, we need uniform standards in animal welfare. Thirdly, we need a single Pan-European registration system and linked databases; and fourthly, we need better regulation in Internet commerce. In Wallonia, where I come from, there are these measures, there is a law regulating online trade, you can take that as an example, then maybe the animals are a little bit better off.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, we are talking about an extremely important issue, both in scale and in severity. I am an emergency doctor in Iaşi, Romania, the "Nicolae Oblu" Emergency Clinical Hospital and I believe, Commissioner, like you, that the life of every being must be protected.  On the one hand, animal cruelty is unacceptable and I believe that this is where we need to come up with much tougher measures. In Romania we have already tabled a draft in the plenary of the Romanian parliament whereby animal cruelty is punishable by heavy years in prison, and here I suggest that the legislation condemning this phenomenon can be tightened. Secondly, we are talking about an important public health issue, and especially in the context of new concerns about the spread of infectious diseases, especially now that we are talking about Coronavirus, I believe that this must also be done at European level.  So from my point of view, three clear things need to be done, even if we are talking about subsidiarity policies here. Unitary legislation at European level, greater firmness in condemning those who trade illegally, and thirdly, education done at European level to protect the lives of these beings.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, I remember when I was little we had a puppy and that was really the best gift ever! Puk has also had a really wonderful life on our farm. Unfortunately, this is not so obvious in the European Union, and that is actually scandalous. It still happens that puppies are born in poor hygienic conditions, that they do not get the deworming cures, do not get the vaccinations, are even mistreated or do not see daylight. Such puppies then come to loving families where the puppies become ill or even die. This is unacceptable animal suffering and it also brings a great deal of suffering to those families. They also have to go to a vet and have high costs. This illegal trade, this breeding of cats and dogs must stop. This is not worthy of the EU, and I therefore ask the European Commission to be strictly monitored and to tackle it harshly.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Madam President, every year thousands of pets are trafficked illegally within the Union. These animals are malnourished, separated too young from their mothers, often sick and untreated, and then sold illegally in Europe. Beyond animal welfare, it is also a matter of public health and consumer protection. These animals sometimes have contagious diseases and unsophisticated consumers may end up with doomed animals, unpaid bills and a broken heart. To stop this illegal trafficking, we call on the Commission, first, to improve traceability by proposing a harmonised animal registration system. Second, to put an end to illegal online advertising. To do this, we require the systematic identification of sellers. And thirdly, to improve cooperation between Member States to stop these traffickers. These measures are urgent and essential to combat these criminal networks.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Madam President, Regulation (EU) No 576/2013 was in the case of the non-commercial movement of pets. And illegal trade within the European Union of such animals violates this Regulation; it also undermines the smooth functioning of the single market, because we are often talking about bad practice in the field of digital sales. The ENVI Commission's action plan to solve this problem is clear: better implementation of the Regulation; sanctions for agents involved in this illegal trafficking: veterinarians, traders, sellers, advertising; establishment of a European cat and dog identification system; encourage citizens to adopt animals as an alternative to sale; and better cooperation and training of customs authorities. This is the way. In addition, we must not forget that animal welfare is closely linked to the well-being of people. Trafficking in animals, many of them un vaccinated or without the necessary certifications, also means trafficking with diseases. A society that protects animal rights is a more humane society.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Dear Chairman, it is estimated that around 46 000 dogs are traded monthly among the Member States of the European Union, most of whom are not registered, many are sick, have not been vaccinated and have forged or no documents, do not know their origin and many animals die shortly after sale.
