Illicit animal trafficking is the most lucrative crime in the world after drugs and guns. In addition to protected and wild animals, pets are illegally trafficked. This has negative consequences for public health, animal welfare and consumer protection. That is why the identification and registration of all cats and dogs is the first step in the fight against their illicit trade.  In the Council conclusions of December last year, adopted during the Finnish Presidency, the Council further called on the Commission to assess the need for new animal welfare legislation. In Croatia, such legislation is well regulated.  Colleagues, this data is a sad reality that we all need to change together.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Article 13 of the Treaty of Lisbon states that animals are sentient beings and as such must be treated and protected. Yet even today they are considered only as objects. Here we are talking about illegal trade, with puppies crammed into trucks and holds like any goods or luggage to be sold illegally in different countries of the European Union, reporting traumas of a physical and psychological nature. But I would also like to raise the issue of the transport of our pets. It is impossible for many European citizens to travel with their four-legged friends, especially if it is an air journey. In fact, not all airlines allow pets to travel, and those that provide for them impose weight and number limits for access to the cabin, and carrying excess animals in the hold as objects. We must update the rules, forcing all companies to accept animals and to ensure that they travel safely. They travel, not that they're transported like packages. Adopt, don't buy!

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, you said in your introduction that the illegal trade in pet animals is a matter for the nation states. I'm sorry, but I consider that alibism. We in the Czech Parliament are trying to push for a tougher regulation of the Criminal Code, a penalty for multiplication, a penalty for this trade, and these debates clearly show that no Member State is able to solve this problem completely. This is organised international crime, this is clearly stated by colleagues here, it is hundreds of thousands of puppies and kittens, it is a huge suffering for these living creatures and without the EU and its institutions, namely the European Commission, preparing effective Pan-European measures, no Member State will solve this problem on its own, however well-willed it may be.  I beg you, pay close attention to this topic. Your answer was evasive. Try to find a solution that effectively affects this organised crime, where billions in taxes are leaked, but mainly innocent animals suffer.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Honourable President, Commissioner, colleagues. Europe banned the slave trade in the nineteenth century. However, at the beginning of the twenty-first century, we cannot create normal conditions for our little friends by restricting trafficking. The European Union, which has been able to create world-class economic prosperity, is at the forefront of technological inventions, but there is still a lack of will to create compulsory registration and labelling of dogs and cats. We do not have a unified registration data system in our Union when we talk solemnly about the digital age, about the achievements that are necessary. By risking animal welfare, deceiving uninformed buyers and violating public health requirements, we support an illegal and dirty business. I call on the European Commission to take urgently binding decisions that will create a European framework for lifestyles in the field of animal welfare. Let us end modern slavery.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I’d like to thank you all for this important debate. I have heard your interventions very carefully. What you don’t need to do is to try and convince me that we need to do more. I am a very proud owner of a companion animal. I have myself been following what has been going on for the last few years online, and really I must admit that I share with you that a lot of what we are seeing is, to say the least, extremely sad and even shocking. So you don’t need to convince me that more needs to be done. Now I’m going to restate that the Commission, and myself personally, are committed to look at finding ways to end the illegal trade of cats and dogs. I do believe that the new Animal Health Law will address many of these issues. It does have compulsory registration, finally, of establishments breeding cats and dogs, and we do now have, if not all the necessary measures, a great deal more necessary measures to help Member States prevent and detect this unacceptable practice. But it is also important that we enforce the rules, and I think we all need to understand that these are not being enforced. All the stakeholders have an important role to play in this by developing guidelines, and I was very interested and I agree that we need to also have more public awareness campaigns of this problem. The new Official Controls Regulation provides far stronger penalties and more tools to address online sales, and I believe that by working together we can stop the illegal trade of companion animals. It is a threat to the internal market and public and animal health, as well as animal welfare, and what I can commit to, as a Commissioner, is that I will be looking at this even more closely and seeing how the Animal Health Law is implemented and, if necessary, what else we can do.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, to conclude, I wish to thank you for this useful debate on the protection of the internal market and consumer rights from the negative implication of illegal trade in companion animals. This is a complex issue which has to be tackled by Member States’ competent authorities, which remain primarily responsible for ensuring, together with the Commission, enforcement of the rules adopted by the co-legislators. The recently-adopted Council conclusions on animal welfare are an important contribution for making further progress in this area. Finally, let me also emphasise that we are looking forward to the continued discussion in the context of the EU Platform on Animal Welfare in the Working Group on e-commerce.

name: Nicola BEER
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 136(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 12 February 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – The illegal trade of companion animals is a highly organised criminal activity that puts animal and human lives at risk. The illegal dog trade alone impacts approximately 8 million puppies annually, is the third most profitable organised crime network in the EU, and poses a massive public health risk to European citizens. Illegally bred pets are seldom vaccinated. They can spread infectious diseases and cause a re-emergence of once eradicated diseases. They are also subject to unequal and appalling living conditions, leading to genetic defects and behavioural problems. To fight the criminal trade of pets, the EU must create a common definition of puppy and kitten farms. A common definition would eradicate differences in animal welfare standards, price inconsistencies and pet exploitation. We must also implement a mandatory, EU-wide system for pet identification and registration. All Member States should provide registers of authorized pet breeder and sellers. I also encourage people to adopt animals instead of purchasing them. Finally, I call on the Commission to implement tougher sanctions for criminals participating in the illegal pet trade. Member States must shut down these crime networks for the sake of our citizens' health and safety of our pets.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. – Mr President, as the trade in animals expands online, more and more people are buying their pets online. Already in 2017, according to a survey conducted in EU countries, more than half bought their pets online. However, most EU countries do not have legislation for online animal trade. The lack of regulation is fuelling illegal trade and facilitating the activities of dishonest sellers. The illegal trade in pets increases the risk of diseases in both animals and humans. When the origin of the animal is uncertain, it is impossible to verify the authenticity of vaccination cards and passports. If the vaccination card has been forged, the animal imported from abroad may spread animal diseases not seen in the Member State. Pets can have hereditary diseases, puppies are born and bred in poor conditions, and the breeder also does not always care what kind of home the puppy ends up in. All this also often backfires as suffering and financial loss to the owner. Every cat and dog deserves a life of its worth – like all of us living – without pain, terror and suffering. We need companion animal legislation at EU level, including the pet chipping obligation and a European register.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: Writing. – Illegal trade in animals often means torment, pain and blood. We have heard about trafficking in several EU Member States, such as Spain or Greece. Our Member States need strong legislation and assistance. The illegal trade in animals is comparable to other forms of the black economy, such as the drug and arms trade. It is estimated that it is the sector in question that follows these illegal areas. I would also like to draw attention to the sale of souvenirs of animal origin. Animals are still killed because of ivory, fur or other artifacts. The European Union also needs to focus on this form of unfair practices.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – I have long called for tougher measures in the fight against violence against animals and their illegal trade. Smuggling and illegal trafficking are linked to drugs and weapons. The truth is that another illegal business is experiencing a boom - the pet trade. In a day in Europe there are nearly 400,000 dog sales announcements. Given the cost of hundreds of euros, it is clear what the annual profits are. Drug dealers earn $24 billion, according to Europol. amounts of the illegal dog trade are similar. A serious problem is the lack of a mandatory pan-European identification and registration system. It would limit the illegal sale of domestic animals, because checking the status of the animal is easier - when it was born, who is the owner, what vaccines it has. This will help to better control public health and better protect consumers. The system must be linked to the passports of the animals in order not to be falsified. It is important that society imposes civil controls and insists on compliance with legal animal welfare requirements. This acts as an engine for the introduction of changes. I call on all responsible institutions to develop a European legal framework for the protection of pets and stray animals aimed at tackling illegal trade.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: Writing. – The illegal trade in pets is on a huge scale in the European Union, does not stop at national borders and causes the death of many animals every year. In most cases, it can be said that illegal trade in animals leads to the breeding of domestic animals. Breeders often separate puppies and kittens from their mothers at up to 4-5 weeks of age and sell them from one Member State to another without a good registration or vaccination. Furthermore, undertakings breeding dogs or cats for commercial purposes are unduly using EU standards for non-commercial pet travel. In addition to the inherent risks to public health, animal welfare and consumer protection, such illegal trade in animals has also become a major source of revenue for international organised crime. Therefore, the illegal trade in animals must end immediately! Eliminating the phenomenon, however, is a very difficult task. I believe that the solution to this problem, which has been going on for years, can only be found through an EU-wide regulation that can save the lives of thousands of pets and provide us with a better life. There is a need for tightening and the introduction of penalties.
